description:
I will preface this by saying I have spent a lot of time in Japan. While the prices here more than what you would spend in Japan at an izakaya of this level, the food and experience are pretty close for not having to leave SF.

Sitting at the bar is the way to go on a date. The sake list was also impressive.
author: Wendy C.

description:
Good Japanese izakaya in SF!

We came here around 7 with reservation and waited 5 minutes to be seated.
We ordered zensai (five tastes appetizers) recommended by waitress
1) Black tofu with wasabi - 2/5 very interesting texture but was not a fan of it. 
2) Hodo yuba (tofu strips) -  2/5 interesting texture but had no taste.
3) Animo (fish liver)  - 1/5 very fishy..least favorite
4) Wagyu tataki (seared wagyu) - 5/5 juicy and soft. It just melts in your mouth. The BEST!!!
5) Fruit based appetizer - 4/5 don't know what it was but it was good.

Yakitori:
chicken oyster ($12) 3/5 - It was tender and perfectly seasoned but nothing special.
rintaro tsukune ($9) 4/5 - juicy chicken meatballs.
chicken thigh + onion ($9) 5/5 - my favorite yakitori, that onion was so good. Just perfect with chicken thigh. highly recommended!!

kama tama udon ($12) 3/5 - carbonara udon, it was very simple yet flavorful. Udon was chewy and soft. I wouldn't order it again but it's worth a try.
maguro no yukke ($18) 3/5 - soy marinated tuna over rice, tuna was fresh and good. 

Overall, this place was good izakaya place. HOWEVER, the waitress was kind of like saleswoman. She kept telling us to order more by saying that this is too little for 2 people but the portion was actually huge for us. We couldn't even finish most of what we ordered..

The atmosphere and ambiance was hip and great, but I just wish the waitress was not pushy... Will I go back? maybe not...
author: Clare L.

description:
We had reservations here for 10pm or so, and we wanted to sit at a booth instead of the tables, so we waited a few more minutes and were able to sit at a booth with our large group. 

The interior reminded me of the restaurants I have been to in Japan, very traditional decorating with wooden beams, etc. 

I wasn't super hungry because I had eaten a little earlier and since we had reservations so late, they were out of a few of the menu items that I wanted to try.  We ordered the maguro tuna sashimi, scallop sashimi, thigh and onion yakitori, the kabocha karokke, duck breast salad, natto don, and the mille feuille miso katsu.  They were out of the cheese tori katus which I really wanted to try.  The natto don here was delicious and tasted a lot better than natto I have had at other places. 

The duck breast salad had really tender pieces of duck in it.  We also ordered the cheesecake, and the sesame ice cream.  The cheesecake was super light and fluffy, a cheesecake I could eat over and over again.  Next time I will make earlier reservations so I will be able to try more of the items.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
A coworker of mine recommended Rintaro to me based off of places she knows I love (Ippuku, Soba Ichi). I called to make a reservation on Friday the 14th at 5:02 pm; I was put on hold for over five minutes and when the hostess came back and I told her I wanted to make a reservation for Saturday evening, if possible, she said, "Oookaaayy, let me see what we have..." in a tone that could only be described as exasperated and annoyed.

When she asked my first and last name for the 6:00 pm reservation, I said, "Angela, [brief pause] and the last name is [slowly] M as in Mary, A-R-R-U-J-O." The hostess replied, "Ok, what was the first name?" I said, "Angela." She then quickly, confidently, and in the same annoyed tone said, "And the last name is M-I-R-R-A-G-O." I paused so I wouldn't snap and said, "M-A-R-R-U-J-O," and pronounced it (the J is pronounced as an H). She said back, "Marrugo." I said, "No. Marrujo." She repeated it back correctly.

When we showed up for our reservation, my last name was Marrugo in their system.

Not a good first impression.

Luckily the rest of the night was markedly better. Rintaro is a beautiful restaurant: high ceilings, minimal, modern Japanese styling, light wood, and lots of natural light even into the later evening hours. The courtyard in the front of the restaurant is peaceful, and it looks like Rintaro offers lap blankets for patrons eating outdoors when the evenings get chilly.

First things first: I highly recommend making a reservation, even if you have to deal with the unpleasant, unprofessional hostess I spoke with. Two women who walked in ahead of us tried to get a table without a reservation and were told it would be an hour and forty-five minute wait. When I called to make a reservation, the only two slots available were for 6:00 pm and 9:15 pm.

Rintaro's menu has an interesting, varied array of food. On Mondays, Rintaro offers yakitori tenju, and on Tuesdays they serve okonomiyaki. Their main menu changes daily. We went with the yosedofu ($10), hanetsuki gyoza ($15), mabodofu don ($14), kama tama udon ($12), nakatani no kakiage ($15), and the momotaro shukuriimu ($12).

Our waitress highly suggested the yosedofu (house-made, fresh tofu), which was the first dish of the night to come out. The tofu was creamy and cold, and tasted delicious with the accompanying shoyu, ginger, and scallions.

The hanetsuki gyoza came next, which was the most visually interesting gyoza I've ever ordered. A crispy, edible layer (of what, I'm not sure) housed the gyoza and looked almost like a net, with a bunch of greens laid over the top. The menu claims this dish includes chicken feet jelly and "wings"; if there was chicken feet jelly in the gyoza I couldn't tell you what that tastes like, specifically, nor do I know what "wings" means in this context. But the gyoza were delicious and so was the dipping sauce, so I suppose ultimately that's what matters most, but I was thrown off by how vague the description of this dish was.

The nakatani no kakiage came out while we were still eating the gyoza. It was a mix of greens and scallops deep fried in tempura batter. This dish was impressive in how flavorful it was for being so simple. It's also the first time I've had scallops I've actually liked, as the scallops were sweet and not at all fishy or briny in flavor. The tempura remained light and crisp and not too oily.

Our final two dishes, the mabodofu don and the kama tama udon, were very impressive and so, so good. If you like mapo tofu, you'll more than likely enjoy mabodofu don. It's essentially the same dish but doesn't contain the numbing spice of Szechuan mapo tofu. The ground pork was flavored so well and the tofu was a perfect amount of firm while still maintaining creaminess. The kama tama udon was an interesting take on pasta carbonara, with Rintaro's own hand-rolled udon served with a single egg yolk, butter, ginger, scallions, and shaved katsuobushi (or bonito flakes). Once everything was mixed together the dish really was the Japanese version of carbonara and was delicately but significantly flavorful.

Dessert was the momotaro shukuriimu, which was a large cream puff pastry with peach ice cream and blackberry sauce. I'm not much of a cream puff fan so my boyfriend ate the majority of it, but it was sweet and light and well baked. I focused more on the ice cream, which had large chunks of peaches, and went well with that tasty blackberry sauce.

Service at Rinatro was spot on. Our waitress was nice without being annoying, attentive without being overbearing, and every other waitress that came around to either bring out dishes or clear plates was informative and kind. There was little wait between dishes, and it never felt like we were sitting around waiting for our food. Everything was paced well. I also appreciated that the dish for our dessert was chilled, keeping everything from melting prematurely.

I highly recommend checking out Rintaro.
author: Angela M.

description:
I actually picked this place on one of my second dates because I saw that it had great ratings and figured if the date was going to go south, at least I could come away with hopefully a fully satisfied belly.  I also love izakayas and frequent them quite a bit in NYC and Japan when I visited.  Thankfully, I was able to make a reservation and requested the bar/chef's counter.  Not many people like smelling like smoke, but seeing the chef sear the meat, to see the busyness of the kitchen and sous chefs, it makes me appreciate my meal so much more.

One of the things that I love was the entryway: it was super quaint and well decorate - almost a modern country feel, topped with small tiny lights strung up overhead.  It would make for a perfect night out with friends for a birthday dinner, especially on a relatively warm day or even a chill night with hot sake.

Things we tried:
Beef Meatballs
PROS:
- great thick round meat balls: they were not skimpy
- meat was well seasoned, very tender
- not overly drenched with sauce: one of the things I don't like about izakayas is that they tend to put way too much sauce on their skewers

CONS: 
- slightly heavy-handed on the salt

Cheese Katsu
PROS:
- nice quantity for a small plate: definitely shareable between two or three people
- katsu was crispy, not soggy
- not super oily
 - cheese was on the inside, came out nice and melting hot

CONS:
-none

Chicken Oyster
PROS:
- super tender, probably the most tender piece of chicken I've had
- not overly salty
- shareable but probably only between two people.

CONS:
- none

Gindara: black cod
PROS: 
- good flavor: nice char
- well cooked: melting in your mouth

CONS:
- way too small for the price.  I mean, these pieces were TINY.  I wouldn't get this again.

Chicken Shoulder
PROS:
- much larger cut of meat, definitely more shareable between three people
- well seasoned (not overly salty)
- not overly greasy or dried out (overcooked)

CONS:
- slightly more tough (but not in a bad way) compared to the chicken oyster

I'd definitely come back again.  I haven't had too many izakaya experiences in the Bay, but I would love to come back and host a dinner with friends outside and get more of that chicken oyster!
author: Vera L.

description:
Delicious food and decent service. I was in SF for a conference at the end of last month, and a new friend had made a reservation here months in advance for herself. Luckily she was able to call and add me to the reservation to sit at the chefs table! 

I had the Suzuki No Sashimi, Iwashi No Nanbanzuke, and the Kake Udon soup. Paired with the meal, I tried two different cocktails, both of which were fabulous. (I don't remember the names!)The Suzuki No Sashimi was the perfect start to the meal, the Baja striped bass was extremely fresh. I'm a fan of anchovies and if I see them on the menu, I typically order (even on pizza lol). So I had to try the house dish Iwashi No Nanbanzuke. This dish included fried anchovies in a spicy vinaigrette topped with carrot, and I thought it was a nice way to break up the fresh fish dish and the udon soup. 

The udon soup was the star of the show for me. The noodles are made in-house and the broth was the right amount of salty and yet still light.
author: Sabrina G.

description:
Came here on a date night and absolutely enjoyed my experience! The atmosphere was great--relaxing and beautiful. We sat at the bar area because we love watching chefs at work. We ordered several skewers and they were all juicy, tender and perfectly cooked--my favorite is the chicken oysters, had to order it twice!

It seemed liked the Cheese Katsu was really really popular so we also tried it, but to me it was a big underwhelming. The cheese was melted through, which is good, but wasn't evenly distributed throughout the katsu, so some bits are packed with cheese while others weren't. Overall, not a deal breaker.  

We rounded out our dinner with Bukkake Udon and Maguro No Yukke (rice bowl) and wow what a great way to end dinner. The hand-rolled udon was thick and chewy, all the toppings (especially the fresh cherry tomato) complimented the milky broth with varying layers of flavor and texture. The tuna on the rice bowl was finely minced, fresh and milky. 

Overall, would 100 come back from the ambience to the food everything was perfect.
author: Rene C.

description:
O M G 

This is and will be one of my fav fav fav places to eat. I think I finally found a place that I can keep going back to. The menu here is different during lunch and dinner. I've tried coming to both and absolutely loved both of my experiences here.

Lunch-
I ordered the Chiizu Tori Katsu ($26). This was a whole lunch set that came with a miso soup w an egg, a small mackerel, side of salad, and rice. For this price you can't beat the quality of the food. One of the best katsu I have had in a long time. I loved it so much it's the only that that I get every time I come now. 

Dinner-
Completely different experience and loved the ambiance of the restaurant, it kind of has a Spirited Away vibe to it!! I came with 2 friends so we were able to try different things!! The chicken shoulder was my fav skewer bc of the flavor, texture, everything about it!! The dinner menu includes skewers, appetizers and other sides vs the lunch menu having only lunch sets. 

Be sure to make a reservation as it does get pretty jam packed in there. I can't wait to go back to try the rest of their amazing menu!
author: Coco C.

description:
Best REAL Izakaya in San Francisco. I have been there at least 30 times or more and I loved every visit. 

The decor is authentic. Japanese persimmon tree, Usu (traditional wooden rice cake pounding pot) and Kamado (traditional wood stove for cooking) in the front yard invite you into Showa era Japan. When you open the door, you will notice the beautiful Japanese shrine and old farm house like woodwork throughout the restaurant. I am always mesmerized by Sylvan's father's (who apprenticed as a temple carpenter in Kyoto) work.

Their Yakitori is authentic. No Japanese-American BS with teriyaki-sauce here! You will find hands down the best Stukune (chicken meatball skewers) outside of Japan. They make their Stukune the way I like... three little balls instead of one oblong pice per skewer. You get more surface area that way. Grilled well on real wood charcoal. Just like my favorite Yakitori-ya in Tokyo where my family have been eating there for over 40 years.  

Sashimi here is seasonal and elegantly plated on beautiful had crafted Japanese plates. Quality of the fish, attention to the detail and traditional skills shine through.

Agemono (Fried food) are pleasure to eat. When you are lucky, you get to eat a whole fried flounder, bones and all, with their special ponzu sauce. 

Dangerously great selection of Sake. Their house sake is affordable yet drinkable (not like other fake Izakaya)
author: Chie J.

description:
I really liked this place! I made a reservation on Resy for bar seating for my s/o's birthday. We got there a bit early, but were seated immediately when we arrived.

The bar seating was super entertaining, as you're able to watch the chefs' work their magic. Just keep in mind that the bar stools here are a bit uncomfortable to sit on throughout dinner.

We ordered: yosedofu (housemade silken tofu), tuna sashimi, tsukune (chicken meatball skewers), ten layer pork katsu, mapo tofu with rice, and the hand rolled udon with fish cake. All the dishes here are on the smaller side, but we were perfectly satisfied with 6 dishes and a dessert to share.

I highly recommend starting off with the tofu and chicken meatballs! I would've wanted another order of the meatballs, but wanted to pace myself during dinner. The pork katsu was nice and crispy - delicious paired with mustard! I'm not a big fan of raw fish, so didn't get to try the sashimi. The rice and udon were also mehs in my book - the rice was good, but mapo tofu isn't something I'd normally go for. The udon broth was amazing, but the fishcake had way too much edamame, imo.

We finished off the night with the japanese souffle cheesecake and they were nice enough to put a candle on it :)
 
Service here was attentive, but there was an odd lag right in the middle of our dinner where we didn't get any other dish for a solid 15 min. I also wish someone would've wiped our table down throughout the meal and provided actual napkins (other than the wet towel). 

Overall, I'll be back!
author: Shirley H.

description:
This place was lit. Definitely on the more expensive end, but if you're craving and willing to splurge on some Izakaya then LETS GOOO!

We came here and ordered some dank ass food. We ordered the Hamachi Sashimi appetizer, some thicc chicken oysters/chicken gizzard/chicken heart skewers, chicken karaage, an assorted clam dish and a tuna poke bowl with a soft yolk on top. And yes, this was for two. And yes, it was way too much food. 

It seems a little ghetto outside, but walking in, it opens up into a really nice tea-house ambiance. The waitresses are all very nice and attentive.

I would definitely make a reservation whatever day you choose. We went on a Tuesday around 6 for 2 and there was a wait. 

I have to try some of the other highly recommended places around SF to compare, but this set the bar pretty high!
author: Bryan C.

description:
What an awesome place in SF! Unsurprisingly, this is one of the most popular Izakaya style Japanese restaurants in the SF area, and I definitely see why. The decor of this place is stunning and really adds to the feel of the restaurant.

Izakaya is basically Japanese small plates, so be prepared to be a bit adventurous! 

Rintaro prides themselves in their skewers, which were delicious and very unique. I'd recommend trying out multiple skewers to get the full experience. 

While Rintaro doesn't have as much raw fish as I'd expect from a Japanese place, the ones I got were absolutely delicious! The yellowtail and albacore were quite exceptional. 

We also ordered multiple small sides, such as the karaage (classic) and tofu. All were delicious!

If you're planning on coming here, I'd highly recommend reservations. This place gets pretty packed on the weekends, and though the place is a bit larger than it first seems, it's still not that big. The restaurant itself is even a bit hidden. The surrounding area isn't the nicest area, but it wasn't too hard to find street parking.

Overall, definitely recommend this place if you're looking for an Izakaya restaurant! The creative menu and decor put this place at 5 stars for me.
author: Steven L.

description:
I was so excited to check out Rintaro for my birthday lunch while visiting SF. I'd never experienced an izakaya, plus I had read so many good things about Rintao on Yelp. I made a reservation for lunch online, which was a nice convenience. Rintaro is located a little out of the way north of the Mission, tucked off the street beyond a little courtyard. The interior was really nice with lots of light colored wood and a really airy, light feeling. They have outdoor seating in front as well. 

The lunch menu includes 6 different lunch sets, sort of like bento boxes. Each set comes with a bunch of different sides like Korean banchan - we had miso soup, anchovies, black cod, pickled wasabi leaf, and some pickled veggies. My favorite by far was the black cod, although the flavor was really subtle. I didn't really care for any of the others besides the miso soup, which had clams in it (different than I'm used to, but good). The pickled items were pretty bland in terms of pickle flavor but odd-tasting, kind of strange. The chicken katsu was just okay. It got really soggy and the egg was just kind of congealed under the chicken. I was honestly pretty bummed as I had been anticipating this place for so long while planning my trip. We did order the Japanese fried chicken wings to share and those were really good, but they only came 3 to an order. I wish I had just ordered more of those! Service was polite and pretty prompt, and the atmosphere was unique and fun, but it didn't really make up for the food for me. From the rave reviews it seems like dinner is really the way to go here. I definitely wouldn't come back for lunch.
author: Katy C.

description:
Ambiance:  4 / 5 Cool, relaxing atmosphere.  We sat at the Chef's table.  It was interesting to watch them prepare the food, but the chairs were quite uncomfortable. Next time I'll grab a table.

Service:  4 / 5 - Friendly and provided good recommendations.  Food came quickly.  Hard to get their attention to get another beer.

Food - Overall 5 / 5
     - Sashimi:  5/5.  Big, fresh pieces

     - Tomato sunomono salad:  2/5.  Was kind of mushy and without much
        flavor

     - Silken tofu 5/5.  Phenomenal, esp. with the scallion, bonito flakes,
       ginger and unfiltered soy sauce

     - Yakitori 4.5 / 5 We tried chicken meatball and liver.  Well executed 
        and tasty

     - Chicken Katsu 6 / 5.  I don't like fried food, but this was so good I
        was basically crying. I will never not order this.  

     - Green tea panna cotta:  5 / 5.  Delicately flavored panna cotta, served with syrup in the tiniest and cutest cup I've ever seen
author: Holly P.

description:
Came by on a Friday for an early dinner. We made reservations online but apparently we weren't early enough to grab a table. They offered us the inside which is very cramped or the outdoor seating. It was starting to get a little chilly but they did have heat lamps and offered to turn them on. Outdoor seating was very quaint and honestly I prefer did to the indoor area but it was harder to get service if we needed anything. 

For our meal we ordered the following; 
1) Suzuki Sashimi w/ fresh wasabi & ponzu: The most beautiful suzuki I've ever laid eyes on. Is contour for fish a thing? Cause if it is, that's what this must be. Every slice was beautifully cut. Bright and mild. Semi-firm and pairs perfect with the fresh wasabi and light citrusy ponzu. If you're not a sushi fanatic, the extra high pricepoint may not be worth it but if you love appreciating the a fish's natural beauty, you gotta see it in person. (4.5/5)

2) Chrysanthemum, Kumquat, Duck Breast salad: A love fresh spring salad. I love using chrysanthemum leaves in salads. Their grassy herby flavor paired very well with the fatty meaty duck breast and the kumquats provide some nice relief from the duck's richness with a nice bright zing and some mild sweetness. (4.5/5)

3) Chicken thigh w/ sansho: Juicy chicken thigh that's well seasoned but the sansho just didn't stand out very much for me (4/5)

4) Chicken Heart: My favorite skewer of the night. So flavorful with just the perfect bite. I don't even know how to describe it. (4.75/5)

5) Tsukune: A very good chicken meatball. Slightly charred outside but moist inside. Very well seasoned, almost a bit sweet. (4.5/5)

6) Layered Pork Katsu w/ Black Hatcho Miso & Hot Mustard: I feel like I didn't eat this dish correctly. I didn't find a point where the hot mustard seemed to fit in the dish. I tried it throughout with the cabbage and the pork and it was fine but never seemed to fully belong. I really enjoyed the sweet tangy miso w/ the katsu. The most interesting part is definitely the texture from all the layers. Each layer was still juicy despite the fact they were really thin and it was mostly lean meat. Breading was decent but nothing special. The cabbage on the side was rather plain and I would've loved some dressing on it though I appreciate how well it was cut. Eating it gave a great mouthfeel. (4/5)

7) "Carbonara" (Handmade Udon, raw egg, butter, ginger, scallion, hand shaved bonito): Honestly the only disappointing item of the night. It's not bad, just not what I expected. The best part was definitely the handmade noodles which had a creamy exterior and that perfect QQ bite. The other components of the dish were just there to highlight the natural flavor of the udon. Which is fine but when I think carbonara I think decadent creaminess which is definitely not this dish. (3.5/5)

8) Pork ginger gyoza w/ chicken feet jelly/broth: I was debating this for so long because just how good can gyoza be. The answer? Damn friggin good. Filling was full of flavorful soup and juicy pork balanced w/ the perfect amount of ginger. The lace on the gyoza was beautiful and crispy too. My only complain is that I wish the wrap was slightly thinner and the sauce a bit lighter. (4.5/5)

Overall, I left very happy with my meal and honestly the bill wasn't too bad ($70/person before tip which is well worth the quality). Not sure if I'd HAVE to come again since I felt like I got a decent sampling all across the menu but would happily come back if a friend asked.
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place is so cute! This is the perfect place for a date night. Upon walking in, I saw them making noodles outside. Super cool! Make sure to make reservations because they get packed.

Tender & chicken oyster yakitori - Both were juicy and tender. It was perfect to start off our meal.

Gyoza - This was standard. If you love the crust of pot stickers, then you'd like this one.

Sashimi - I can't remember the exact name of this, but there was a variety of fish such as salmon, tuna, yellowtail, and uni. This dish had a beautiful presentation with flowers. Each fish was extremely fresh. If I had to describe it, it felt as if I was eating mangoes because of the buttery texture. Yum!

Hojicha panna cotta - This melted in my mouth. It was the silkiest and softed panna cotta I ever had. The hojicha flavor was perfect. Definitely must save some room in your stomach for this dessert! Before you start pouring the cream all over your panna cotta, beware that the cream that comes with it is pretty sweet so a little goes a long way.

Sesame & matcha ice cream - Both flavors tasted amazing. They make the ice cream themselves! Texture and flavor was on point.

Everything was fresh and delicious. I'm recommending this place to all my friends!
author: Julian Y.

description:
There is a LOT of hype around Rintaro. Before I came, a friend told me this was by far her favorite izakaya place in the city. My expectations were high! I love izakaya food and given my high expectations I tend not to attempt any visits unless highly recommended because I usually expect to be disappointed. And so, I have very little to compare Rintaro with in terms of izakaya spots specifically in San Francisco. Overall as an izakaya goes, it's pretty good to me, but just don't go expecting levels of what you'd get in japan. I'd say this is like "average" Izakaya level in japan to me.

That said, most dishes here were super solid, and a few I'd come back for. Oddly, their yakitori to me was not their best dish. As we came with a sizable group, we ordered at least half the menu. A few memorable dishes in order of how much I liked them:

1: chicken katsu with cheese - perfectly crisp and fried just long enough at the right temperature that there was no greasy after taste and the cheese was nice and melted, juicy meat.
2: curry croquette - again, fried perfectly, and the flavors worked
3: udon carbonara - ok this isn't THAT small some pictures make this look like it's one mouthful worth of noodles but you could share it between 3 if you all just wanted a few bites for a taste. It was good. But there's no cheese in this it's really just butter and egg and dashi. Japanese flavors + butter and yolk for sure. 
4: Tsukune skewers (chicken meatballs) - by far the best of the "standard" grilled skewer dishes. The others were not so flavorful. Thighs were fine.
5: okra skewers - only because I love okra! 
6: this was quite bad - leaf baked whole fish. Too dry, and the server deboning it said it was the first time she was deboning but kind of massacred the fish and left too many bones. We felt bad since she kept saying it was her first time and so didn't complain but it wasn't so good. Anyway, the meat was dry. Definitely the most disappointing dish.
7: hojicha panna cotta is actually way up there for me but saving it for last because it's dessert. It was amazing. Flavors really came through 
8: momotaro choux cream (shukurimu is how they spell it) was underwhelming. I did not get the taste of momo (peach) at all. Which I expected since that's part of its name!! 

Ok anyway, I wouldn't come here with a big group because there's no space up front for a group and you'll inevitably be shoved in the room at the back and it gets really stuffy and dark even when it's freezing out! I got really upset about it because I don't enjoy eating in an uncomfortable space and I was feeling stuffy and a little claustrophobic. But otherwise, food was really decent, and it just might be the best izakaya spot in the city. Temper your expectations though! San Francisco is not the place for Japanese food...
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
If I could give them 10 stars I would! On a personal level, it's my #1 favorite restaurant in San Francisco.

Everything here is AMAZING! The vibe is reminiscent of a traditional restaurant in Japan (to me at least). I've been to Japan + this place always takes me back to my time there. Staff + service is amazing, too.

My favorite thing to order for lunch is the Chiizu Tori Katsu Set. The chicken is juicy + crisp. And the Katsu sauce is traditional. Well, the entire set is traditional. For dinner, we like to order everything! Nothing on any of their menus has disappointed. 

Keep in mind, before making a trip over, try to make a reservation. For dinner, I believe they only accept reservations. Call + check. Otherwise, if you're walking-in, expect a long wait.
author: Rosa D.

description:
Woot! When I first moved to SF, I was so disappointed by the food BUT I now know there are pockets of cuisine worth looking out for -- one of which is Japanese izakayas. Rintaro is a gem. I will be coming back again.

First of all, I absolutely LOVE the space. It takes me back to Japan, and the restaurant is QUITE spacious. The stand-out food we ordered were:

1) Duck breast with Chrysanthemum Greens - the greens had this light bitterness and great crunch, that I think was better than the duck breast itself. Though the duck breast was cooked perfectly. Very thin slices, high quality. Beautiful presentation...

2) Gyoza - I usually don't order this, partly because I just hate the spelling (knock-off of the Chinese word "jiao zi" but anyways...). It was SO good. It was pan-fried with a light crust on the bottom. Also beautiful presentation. 

3) The DRINKS. OMG. So delicious. I loved the pina colada one the most. All of them are sochu based and worth every drop. The flavors are so light and not overwhelming.

Oh yeah and dessert. I'd skip the panna cotta and just go for the ice cream. You can't go wrong.

Great for date-night. You can peek over the counter and watch the chefs grill over the fire. I love chef's table seats. Also good for groups of 4. Make a reservation though!
author: Cindy W.

description:
2nd time here! First time to try to food. 

First time I came, didn't make reservations and it was super packed and fully booked. So had to drive to another restaurant.

This time I came afternoon around 1:30pm. The place is pretty empty, no reservations needed but just in case you can still make one. The atmosphere here is very calming and relaxing. The music is not really my type, traditional Japanese music, but that's the experience right?

Sat down by the countertop so I can look at what they doing. It's pretty interesting! 

The menu is pretty small for lunch time so we ordered 2 sets and 1 appetizer. 

First came out fried chicken! I love how they present their food. The chicken taste great, skin is crispy and a daze of sweet taste. The way they season the chicken is great, love it. 9/10 is a bit small for 12$ 

Then comes our entrees ! I got the Sashimi over rice set and my friend got the katsu set. Both sets came with soup and side dishes. 

The soup is not just simple miso soup, it has big tofu piece and real seafood inside. 

The 4 side dish is very small but delicious.

The main bowl is great, I love the sashimi over rice with REAL WASABI I can taste it's spicy but not super strong.

The katsu bowl is great I got a bite and the outside is super crunchy and inside is with cheese !!!!

Very delicious meal. Love it. Will come back again to try the dinner menu.

9/10 a bit pricy and crowded at night.
author: Sandy C.

description:
This review is about Rintaro's teishoku lunch menu. 

We ordered the Katsudon set and Millefeuille Miso Katsu set.  They are SO. GOOD.  It is the closest to what you would get in Japan.  I will definitely be back!
author: Christine A.

description:
Hubby and I decided to come here rather last minute for a date night. We we're lucky enough to get reservations for two on a Saturday night.

We ordered: 

Pork salad: GET THIS. Great balance of flavors. I could eat a whole order to myself.

Chicken meatball skewers: so good! Juicy and flavorful and bright. 

Chicken thigh skewers: well executed but not memorable.

King mushroom skewers: SO good as well. Would definitely order again. Perfectly charred and flavorful.

Chicken karaage: I have this thing where I have to order chicken wings if they're on the menu. Well fried but not my favorite item. It was good but not a standout.

Udon for two!: Noodles we're fresh, broth was light but flavorful and the egg was perfectly cooked.

Yuzu ice cream profiterole: very good, love the flavors

Overall it was a great experience. The ambiance was cozy and the service/attention to detail was perfect. I will definitely be back to try their lunch menu!!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Love to ring in my '18 Elite badge with this review! 

Five-star deliciousness. Lovely ambiance, especially on the patio. My only gripe is the small portion of uni I got on my rice. I paid for the uni, fresh and creamy, btw, more than anything. I'll be back, hoping for a bit more generosity. Staff seems nice enough.
author: Paulina F.

description:
I had great experience here. I was craving for yakitory and here is the best restaurant in SF. 
Started with dressed dish. The grilled duck breast salad was divine. Definitely the yakitory is my favorite part. We had to order chicken meatball twice so we don't have to fight for it. 
Service was very nice our sever was very attentive and hosts were very polite and charming. 
I was bit sad that I missed their kama they only had 5 pieces for that day. Other than that everything was perfect!
I adore the ambiance. We'll definitely coming back!
author: Cindy S.

description: Had a great dinner here. The service was excellent. Everyone was very friendly, helpful and attentive. We enjoyed the food a lot. The gyoza was incredible. I could have eaten that over and over :) their tofu was also amazing. There is a cute bar area too that you can sit at. I recommend trying to make a reservation before going as we went on a Tuesday and it was pretty packed.
author: Makenzi B.

description:
Their teishoku are sooo great!!
The rice was little bit dry though....

I definite come back again!!
author: Iguanatte S.

description: It was incredible!   Get the udon carbonara and the tofu!   Great service and ambience!   Definitely coming back.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Love this place! Especially Hanetsuki gyoza and Udon. Very authentic Japanese food and cute atmosphere. 
I love to sit at a bar and look at chefs cooking.
author: Saki ..

description:
I enjoy Rintaro quite a bit even if I always need reservations to get in. Rintaro is one of the better izakayas in the city - largely I suspect due to just higher quality ingredients. The fact that I always have to make reservations certainly takes the spontaneity out of what a proper izakaya experience should be, but the quality of the food is quite good here. 

My go tos are always their skewers of course - they have great skewers, the agadeshi tofu, and then their udon. I would avoid the sashimi pieces since I think it's too costly for the amount of food, but some of their other fried pieces are good here. I had a mille feuille style chicken the other day that was more aspirational than tasty, but hey, I appreciated the creativity. 

In general, Rintaro is a great place to have a meal with a group of friends (more people more dishes) or also a nice place to grab a quick snack assuming you can find last minute seats!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Absolutely delicious! Had a reservation made early Saturday morning for that evening at 5:45 (yes, we eat early- so sue me!). The outside of the restaurant is very simple looking so don't pass right by it. Once you step behind the fence you enter a lovely patio seating area and then into the lovely exposed wood beam restaurant with great diffused lighting. We got to sit up at the bar to watch all the kitchen at work, highly recommend if you're at all interested in how they make the plates. Sipped on hot tea while waiting for our: tofu, veggie dish with apples and spring onions, squash croquettes, chicken tender yakatori, beef curry rice, and udon carbonara. I especially recommend the carbonara- was so good I couldn't wait to take a picture! 

Get something with wasabi, they make their's fresh in house which is pretty rare! Without drinks or tip it was $71.
author: Ally B.

description:
Food: 4.5/5
Atmosphere: 5/5
Service: 5/5

Had a lovely evening here at Rintaro, it's a more classy and less smokey yakitory as you will find in Japan. The decor is lovely, and you feel a sense of calm walking in. 

The food is delicious, I would highly recommend their karaage, there's a sauce on it that both my friend and I have never tasted. The handmade tofu was only so-so, the texture too grainy for my tastes. The yakitory is good, I'll highly highly recommend the chicken knuckle. The udon was simple but soothing and quite delicious.
author: Terrie C.

description:
One of our go-to in the city for Izakaya fix. Great vibes & hospitality, feels like you're in a Tokyo spot (minus the all non-Japanese chefs who execute like a CHAMP). Some dish highlights below.

-Kanpachi No Sashimi (yellowtail)
-Yudofu (tofu, maitake and ponzu)
-Shungiku Kamo Sarada (greens with duck breast and kumquats) 
-Inner Thigh Skewer
-Tender w/ Wasabi Skewer
-Breast w/ Umemiso Skewer
-King Trumpet Skewer
-Chizu Tori Katsu (chicken and cheese katsu)
-Maguro No Yukke (rice with amazing stuff atop)
-Kama Tama Udon
author: Alex B.

description:
Decent upscale Japanese izakaya style; mind the larger portions (albeit delicious)!

Came here with a date late Thursday night as a walk-in; we probably waited 15 min for a seat and were seated at the counter right in front of the grill for the yakitori.  

Venue / Service: we were seated pretty near to the cashier and the kitchen so we experienced a lot of traffic where we were.  That being said, also means food came out quicker.  Fun to be able to watch the chefs making the food.  

Shungiku Kamo Sarada (hikari farm chrysanthemum greens with grilled duck breast and pluots)($16) - surprisingly a rather filling salad, especially with a good amount of grilled duck breast and a huge pile of the greens.  The pluots added crunch and a bit of acidity.  Even though we shared this, it was a lot of salad; maybe for 3+ people if you are trying to try more dishes

Liver yakitori ($7) - not for everyone, but I liked it out of the three yakitori we ordered.  A little funky tasting and slightly chewy, but I found the texture and flavor interesting.  Seasoned well too.

Rintaro Tsukune Yakitori ($8) - yay juicy meatballs!  They give you three per stick (and 2 sticks).  Slightly crusty on the outside but not burned and very tender on the inside.  

King Trumpet Yakitori ($6) - not too oily and tough; this one was recommended by the waiter and we both liked it.  Very lightly seasoned to let the natural mushroom flavor shine.

Hanetsuki Gyoza (Becker Lane Berkshire pork gyoza with chicken foot jelly and "wings")($14) - while the dumplings are delicious, this is a rather big portion.  The pork filling was nice and juicy, the outside crispy without being too crunchy, but would probably only get this if you have a larger party or are planning on ordering less dishes.

Nijimasu no Shioyaki (whole salt grilled rainbow trout wrapped in a fig leaf with grated daikon and ginger)($34) - again, a massive portion, given it is a huge whole fish being served.  This dish also takes a while to prepare so there was a bit of a wait time between this course and the previous one.  Fish was beautifully cooked- firm but flaky and the fig leaf, daikon and ginger added a lot of bright notes to the fish.  Again, recommended only if you have a large group and are ordering fewer dishes.

Hojicha Panna Cotta (Japanese roasted green tea panna cotta with hojicha syrup and almond cookies)($10) - probably the highlight of the meal.  The panna cotta had a great, light but present roasted tea flavor and the hojicha syrup wasn't too sweet.  Not sure if you need the almond cookies but they were good anyway.

In summary, food is good, but perhaps not as conducive to sharing many plates given the large size of some of the dishes, especially if you have a small party.  Probably better for larger parties if you want to try the entrees, but perhaps smaller groups should stick to the izakaya and smaller dishes so you won't walk away feeling too stuffed.
author: Audrey H.

description:
I've been on an Izakaya kick these days. First it was ippuku in Berkeley then it was Ginto and now Rintaro. First thing when walking in is how cozy and beautiful the place is. You can't see anything from the outside until you walk through the door which you'll land in the outdoor area. Nicely decorated with light strings above. The best part is they offer blankets if you choose to sit outside. The inside is just as good! The exposed wooden arches above just sells the place. 

We sat outside since we were walk-ins and had no problem with being next to the heater and a few blankets to keep warm! Service was great and attentive. Our waitress was pretty informative as some of the dishes I was unfamiliar with. 

Standout dishes to me were the fresh tofu with yuzu, udon soup, all the yakitori dishes were delicious. I mean anything grilled on a stick is gonna taste good, right?! 

They also have special requests if you ask ahead of time. If you ask if they have anything off menu, chances are they might have something! We saw a few tables with dishes that were definitely not on the menu and confirmed with our waitress. 

Definitely coming back here. I'd love to have an event in the patio area. It's a perfect spot for a bday or a large get together.
author: Andrew S.

description: Honestly one of the best dining experiences I've had in SF. We sat at the bar so we could watch the cooks in action. Our waitress was amazing- super friendly, took her time explaining the menu and overall wanted us to have a good experience. The food runner was also very friendly and knowledgeable. The food itself- great presentation and most importantly a-ma-zing. The skewed mushrooms and hot tofu dishes were absolutely delicious. Stay away from the natto (fermented bean dish), though, unless you are into trying something very different (but very common in Japan)- it has a very distinct taste.  The sardines didn't even taste like sardines! Sake is expensive, though- about $33 for a small-ish bottle.
author: Rob M.

description: Big thanks to Rintaro for fulfilling my dreams. I've been craving Uni pasta comparable to Miyabi Uni in LA. What happened today was even better. Carbonara udon with Uni. So glad they still had Uni at 9:30. We didn't even have to wait long. It was definitely worth trying and I can't wait to keep coming back.
author: Gwen M.

description:
Loved it!

I really enjoyed the setting and the decor.   I loved walking through a courtyard with outdoor seating to get into the restaurant.   The exposed beams and high ceiling was great.   The music was great.   It was all very hip, but not too hip and didn't feel douchey.   Service was nice and friendly.

Food:

Squid salad with mustard miso:   Different and unusual.  Served cold.   Recommended.

Omelet:  Nothing special here.   Was a little boring.   The diakon radish on the side was not enough to really elevate the dish to anything beyond average.

Chicken meatball skewers:   Awesome.   Good flavor.   Nice char.

Croquettes:   Amazing.   Get these.   Curried potato and kabocha croquettes with a nice, thick, crunchy panko crust.   Very different.   Very tasty.

Gyoza:   Holy cannoli!   GET THESE!   Best gyoza I have ever had.  

The cocktails were low ABV.   The one I had tasted good, but was pretty weak.   I ordered a Hitachino IPA for my second drink and was pleased.

Recommended.
author: Christian C.

description:
This place is insanely cool. I'm not sure if it has a Michelin star or if it even wants one, but it deserves one.

The space is beautiful. I love the combination of an old reclaimed warehouse with very modern Japanese style seating and decoration.

I came here with my 3 year old daughter for a Friday lunch. The lunch menu's pretty rigid. I got the "mille feuille" tonkatsu and it was a ridiculously fancy take on a classic. The pork was super fatty (maybe even Kurobuta?), sliced insanely thin, put back together with a light egg batter, and then breaded and deep-fried. Then there were about 5 little side accompaniments -- like a little picked fish thing, a radish thing, something with seaweed salad -- all super yummy.

My daughter loved the tonkatsu, the white rice, and a Japanese melon soda we got. She doesn't have soda much so it was a very special experience for her.

But beyond the food was the service. I know bringing a 3 year old to a fancy restaurant is pretty risky but all the service people took it in stride and loved how open my daughter was to new experiences. And then to me, all the niceties of fine dining happened -- The chef came by to check on us, our waitress came at the end and had a real conversation about how we enjoyed our meal and expressed an interest in our story and my daughter's experiences with Japanese food.

Highly recommend. Probably need reservations, especially for dinner.
author: Jon E.

description: Wow, tough place to get into.  I came here on a Tuesday to find this place packed and unable to get a normal dinner table so definitely consider placing a reservation.  Fortunately, there was an okonomiyaki popup that they do which made for sort of a beer garden type atmosphere.  There wasn't much to choose from for the popup, but at least it left us with something.  Taste-wise, it was good, but I didn't get any sense of meat in mines which I thought I had.  Also not quite as big as a typical okonomiyaki, we ended up hitting up the SOMA Street Food Park afterward for more food.  But I'll have to come back for dinner some time, it looks really good and popular!
author: Bryson L.

description:
This is maybe the best Japanese teishoku in the Bay.  I had the pumpkin korokke, and it was extra crispy.  The rice is cooked in a stone pot - it was a little dry for my meal, but it's probably perfect for a donburi.  The tsukemono pickles and nutatsuke were fresh, I think homemade.  And the green onions for the miso soup were grilled for a nice smoky flavor!
I didn't have the oyakodon, but I watched them make it and I don't recommend it.  It was over cooked and looked like an omelette!
author: Dan D.

description:
A small plate of Udon with Uni was $24.

Skewers are $6 each.

VERY OVERPRICED.

Food was delicious though. Drinks are not absurdly priced but I might only feel this way because I just came from vegas.

Service is excellent. Food comes out fast. 

Come here if you don't mind spending $50+ per person.
author: Sang P.

description: Consistently outstanding. Excellent service/staff, really nice food and a constantly changing menu, great ambiance, and good drinks and dessert menus. Highly suggest this Izakaya to anyone that appreciates this style of Japanese cuisine.
author: James T.

description:
As far as Izakaya's go in the bay area, this is one of my favorites. Been there twice, here's a rundown:

Ambience:
Great atmosphere. If you can make a reservation at the bar, do it. I was lucky enough to be seated by the grill and really enjoyed watching the kitchen's hustle & bustle. The tables are also very cute, and there's a lovely courtyard with adorable stringed lights out front, though I'd recommend sitting inside.

Food:
Excellent food, be sure to order their gyoza & house-made tofu (yudofu). I'm always curious how chefs choose to do their gyoza; at Rintaro, the dish is HUGE and very beautiful. Dishes I'd recommend:
- Hanetsuki Gyoza $14
- Hotate no Sashimi (I love raw scallop) $20
- Kama Tama Udon $12
- Yosedofu (house-made tofu!) $10
- Teba no Karaage (chicken wings) $12
 
They also offer an assortment of Japanese Beer & Sake, I usually go for the beer.
author: Sijia W.

description:
Is Rintarou named after director Rin Tarou?

Dammit, one of the few places in America that purported to have oden but they don't have it anymore. Was so looking forward to this. Guess I gotta stick to the south bay for oden... Damn.

How weird is this? The hot towel (oshibori) the waitress gave us, she told us to use as our napkin too. What the shit is that? A cold wet towel I've already rubbed my filthy hands all over is not what I want as a napkin.

Handmade udon! Haven't had this since my favorite place for that in Torrance started using store-bought udon (and I consequently stopped going).

Was disappointed it wasn't nearly as good here, though. Just glad the carbonara had no cream or peas in it (pet peeve of mine is people who think carbonara is a cream sauce with peas). The udon with white wine clam sauce at Musha in West LA is the best wafu udon I've ever had and is consistently good.

Yosedofu (house-made tofu) $10 - I've had this many places and this was fine but did not stand out. 

Gyoza was not on the menu but they had it. If we hadn't overheard the waitress at another table we wouldn't have known. Wish she would have told us too.

They turned out not great, though. They were shaped like Chinese dumplings, but a kind I don't like, and had a dough "skirt" (like Squeeze Burgers' cheese skirt), which is a thing in some regions of China that just isn't for me. When I want Chinese dumplings I'll go to a Chinese restaurant - preferably in NY, HK, or LA, not SF. When I order gyoza I want Japanese dumplings.

Yakitori are 2 skewers per order, which imho is too many because I want to try a bunch of them and this way I only have room for half what I normally could order. There were 2 not on the menu, tail (pope's nose or parson's nose if you're British - "Open this door! We're British!"), which was just okay, a little dry, and soft bone, which was really crunchy and hard to eat and had small bits of dried out meat clinging to it.

The regular chicken meat we had (thigh with onion, oyster) was too dry.

Liver: the sauce was too sweet. This is better at Gaku.

Kanzuri (throat) was our favorite. Chewy, fatty, lots of umami. Probably too "gristly" for the average unadventurous American.

The Rintarou plum and lemon soda was really sour. Is it umeboshi plum? The paper straw was really think and got too soggy to use after 2 sips.

This was a 2-2.5 for food but the waitress was great and i want to differentiate it from Nihon Whisky's 2, so a 3 it is. But don't mistake this for a pure 3.

~

Update: the food was meh enough that I was going to give it a 2 ("meh" rating according to Yelp's own descriptions of star levels) but it wasn't as bad as Nihon Whisky Lounge and I wanted to delineate the difference using my star ratings so it got a 3. But then the owner or manager or whoever of Nihon Whisky was so unprofessional in their response to me that I bumped them down to a 1. I was going to come back and give Rintarou a 2, but now that I think about it, the waitress went out of her way to help track down a missing order after last call, so I can't in good conscience bump Rintarou down another notch. Good job, you saved your restaurant from a 2.
author: ben l.

description: One of our faves in SF. Super cool atmosphere.  Authentic and delicious food, friendly staff that makes you feel as if you have stepped in their home. We love the chicken katsu and gyoza.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
My new favorite izakaya in SF. I'm Japanese and have lived in Japan especially Tokyo for more than 25 years.  This place reminds me of Japan. Especially the menu and the atmosphere there is really legit. 
I made a reservation for 5 on the same day afternoon at 8:30 and then pulled in to 7:45 at 7:30. It was easy to make a reservation.
We ordered
-Rice beer; taste beer!
-gyoza, pot stickers. So good!!
-teba karaage; good
-sashimi: nice!
-udon: great
-tonkatu: not so much

I definitely come back
author: Nazuki Y.

description: This place is remind me of Tokyo. Intimate setting with outdoor seating. It's perfect The food was both authentic and excellent. We had chick oysters, hearts, gizzards, Katsu, Tsukune (chicken meatballs) Overall, it was a great experience. Service was outstanding. We will definitely be back. Highly recommend need RSVP for dinner.
author: Katie E.

description: Food was good except they sat us all the way in the back, which was dark and depressing. Ask if we could sit in the front, was told no
author: Kenny L.

description:
Favorite of the night: the chicken skewers 
We wanted the gizzard and livers. But they have sold out. We ended up getting things we didn't expect for, the hearts, softbone, and tail. I swear to god the chicken hearts are the best I have ever had. So good that the next day I went to wholefood and get chicken heart and look up some recipes. 
Udon was average. Sashimi was fresh too.
author: YingTung W.

description:
I was a walk-in on sunday night. Even though there were some free spots near the bar and peoplewere leaving i was offered to sit outside only without options. That was dissapointing. 
The food taste was good but the portions really small. Not sure it was worth the price. 
Not sure will come back...
author: Lizzz K.

description:
Hi!
Okay so my boyfriend and I just sort of searched random places for our visit from Houston and we chose Rintaro based on the online menu and reviews. We were so pleased with our experience! The host, the waitstaff, and the manager were all very accommodating. Our first interaction was with the hostess. We loved her energy even just on the phone and in person she was even better! She even assisted other servers with food service, awesome! Then Jen was our actual server, she was extremely informative and all her suggestions were great! We ordered udon noodles (fab) the chicken wings, chicken oysters, yellow tail, and the duck and chrysanthemum salad. Fantastic! The manager also heard it was my boyfriend's birthday and make the evening extra special.

This passed weekend was so amazing and Rintaro was a big part of that! Thank you guys! We will definitely come back next time we're in San Francisco! 

Also we came in on Friday, June 22, 2018.
author: Ty H.

description:
damn, this place is delicious. seriously. it's not much more expensive than your typical izakaya. i spent 180 here after tax for 2 ppl with just a drink each though. 

come earlier in the day because at night, when we arrived, almost everything we wanted was sold out. you'll NEED to make reservations in advance and they charge you $25 to do so incase you flake. You are not charged the $25 unless you flake. 

highlights were everything. the house tofu is amazing. the gyoza is so good and we were about to pass because.. well.. you know... how good can gyoza be? good. 

I would pass on the chicken thigh, both of them, it was whatever. The knee was okay. If i were to be picky those would be my choices as to what to skip. 

There are 2 katsus and you'll want to pick the cheesy one. That seems obvious but the other one has a tempting description as well. Go with the cheesy one.

We had the shrimp w fried shrimp heads. Yes. Always a yes.

The meatballs were bomb.

Just go already.
author: Michael A.

description:
Rintaro was amazing! We had a great experience there sitting at the chef counter. The chef even gave us some free sample to us (a couple slices of the grilled duck breasts that were sitting in front of us waiting to be cut). Thanks chef!

We started with the scallops sashimi, and what a way to start our meal. It was unbelievably fresh!! Next, we had the special salad with deep fried Dungeness crab... the crab was fried nicely (very light) and it was tasty too. 

On to the yakitori section, I think we had almost everything on the menu: tsukune (chicken meatball), thigh and onion, liver and roast garlic, chicken oyster, knee cap, king trumpet mushroom, kanzuri (chicken bit between the heart the liver), and the ribeye. Everything was grilled to perfection and seasoned perfectly. Some of them were a little salty and some of them were a little sweet. My favorites were the thigh and onion, liver and garlic, ribeye, and the chicken oyster. 

Next we had the fried chicken wings and the gyoza. Wow, they were both so delicious and perfectly prepared. The gyoza had this really nice crispy crust on top... what a nice presentation! The battered on the chicken wings were so flavorful, and they were fried to perfection (not greasy at all).

Okay... we are almost at the end of our meal. We had the whole steamed fish with sake, soy and mirin. For me this was just okay. I thought the sauce was too sweet. I wanted more salt or soy flavor. Our grand finale before dessert was the kama tama udon aka udon "carbonara". I thought it was pretty good. The udon was nicely cooked..chewy and slippery. The egg and the butter gave the dish the richness of a carbonara, but it was still pretty light. Overall, it was a nice comforting dish to end our meal.

For dessert we have the roasted green tea panna cotta. It was a wonderful dessert. Nice texture and unique flavor.
author: Sam M.

description: Late post : Friday :This place is really good. The menu is small and diff all the time but it's sooooo gooood. I had no complaint about anything. The service is great and I love their decor! Super cute place and reminds me of Japan. Even though I wish I had more selections and I don't give a 5 much but yes this place gets a 5 star. Everything fresh and yummy!
author: Christy V.

description:
Thank you for a great and wonderful experience! Our server Yumiko (I totally forgot and sorry If it isn't) was courteous and AWESOME! 

The food was delicious and as usual, it was a great Valentines night to remember! 


Thank you!
With Great service always comes with better tasting food!
author: Wu T.

description:
Trendy hipster ambiance with Japanese decor and set up. Delicious Izakaya. Good service. I went on a Tuesday night and it was still a 40 minute wait. Drink sake while waiting. 

MUST GET: Udon Carbonara. Omg so good. Mix that egg yolk with udon to get that bomb umami flavor. I'd come back just for this. For myself. 

Everything else we ordered were 4 stars. Yakitori (heart, inner thigh, chicken oyster) and fried appetizers (potato croquette and karaage chicken wings, which were surprisingly very flavorful). A bit pricey though as 2 sticks were $8-11 bucks. 

Overall a nice Japanese Izakaya place in SF, I'd come back and I'd take friends. Even the bathroom was nice, which is always a plus in my book!!
author: Raquel Y.

description: Fantastic meal at Rintaro. Great atmosphere and lovely staff. The yellowtail sashimi, swordfish sashimi and tuna sashimi were so fresh and delicious. Unique and memorable was the cold silken tofu - one of my favorites of the night. We devoured the pork gyoza and also rice topped with fish roe and uni (although for $12 extra dollars, there was very little uni)! All in all, a wonderful dinner.
author: Sol C.

description:
5 stars. Finally, a great izakaya that I can return regularly, with delicious skewers and small bites to fill your stomach little by little with the progression of the meal. 

Sit in the main dining room where natural wood booths and skewer bar seats line the two sides of this long dining area. Good lighting/ambience and great service. 

The skewers are excellent. Some are a bit too salty for my taste (gizzard) but for the most part solid. My favorites were chicken heart, chicken liver, chicken thigh with scallion, and King trumpet mushroom which was very moist and flavorful (unlike most other mushroom skewers I had in the past). 

We had also rintaro tsukene (meatball), asparagus and bacon (the asparagus was a bit too big for skewers in my opinion) - I don't really care for these. But the plain asparagus ones that they have in March 2018 was really good - can be seasonal in terms of quality. The kneecap, neck and tail were pretty good but a bit too much tendon / chewy for my taste. 

The chrysanthemum salad with duck was quite delicious - unusual greens and good quality meat. But salads are not the specialty here and according to one regular who is here, describe them to be a bit too saucy. 

We also had the tomago (hot egg omelet) which everyone bragged to us here (it's served off the menu, only available some of the time). It was pretty good and very tender and moist. Make sure that you try it with the daikon with soy sauce to add a bit more flavor. I myself prefer chawamushi (not served here) when it comes to egg-related Japanese dishes. 

The chicken wings are amazing. I tried one from the person sitting next to us at the bar (my colleague whom I randomly bumped into!). It was just the perfectly cooked wings with crispy skin, moist meat, and balanced spices on the outside. It doesn't get better than this when it comes to wings. 

If you are in the mood for sashimi, there is a toro dish with chutoro, otoro, and California blue fin tuna. Great quality.

The yutofu (silken tofu with maitake, shimeji mushroom, Napa cabbage, etc) was pretty good but it's not a brothy soup, the hot water is only to keep it warm. Solid but not the best. Very clean food. Your stomach and body will thank you for it. 

The kake udon with soft boiled egg and fish cakes were pretty good. I liked the udon but some of the other specialty udon places have more flavorful broth than the version here.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
My boyfriend brought me here for my birthday, and we had a fantastic experience! I love Izakaya and Rintaro was no exception. We were seated at the bar and watched the chefs as they prepared our food with the utmost care. Some of our favorites from the night:

1) Yosetofu - so silken smooth. Soy sauce added a unique flavor.
2) Scallop sashimi - very fresh and sweet
3) Chicken gizzard skewer - great texture and flavor
4) Wagyu suteiki - I was too full at this point to eat anymore, but BF claims this was delicious 
5) Hojicha panna cotta - you have to try this! So so so good :)
author: Jennifer X.

description:
We had a reservation via Resy, which was a must. There was constantly a line even on a Monday night. We were seated right by the door, so the line was essentially next to our table. It did feel a little awkward because we felt pressured to finish faster. 

Drinks: sake/wine only, no liquor. The sake pours were a lsmaller than I expected for the price. Nonetheless, the food is best with sake. 

Food: I think most dishes are good for 2 or 4 people to share if everyone wants to try a little. 
- Hotate sashimi: think sliced, super sweet and tender. Soy sauce and wasabi come on the side 
- Yosedofu: assemble on your own. It's a pretty sizable piece of tofu, and the texture was very smooth but dense and still a little firm. Soy sauce, bonito flakes, and ginger come on the side 
- King trumpet mushrooms (skewer): good flavor 
- Chicken breast skewers: 2 per order and pretty filling. They were tender; however, they didn't get quite the same char as some other places (I'm thinking of the one at Sumika..) 
- Kabocha karokke: nicely fried, a huge portion, served with tonkatsu sauce. 

We were actually both very full after this, so we skipped the rice and udon dishes. Again, I think it's best to go with 2-4 people so that everyone can try different things. 

I'm not sure I would make Rintaro a destination from the peninsula, but the food was all pretty solid. Next time, I would probably skip the skewers. They had a wagon wheel cheese + chicken katsu dish that sounded interesting. 

Other notes: 
- The patio area is really nice on a warm day 
- Parking is hit or miss around here
- I think servers aren't specifically assigned to tables, but everyone steps up to help out with service
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Super cool vibe, really nice food, and that Udon Carbonara!  

Definitely get the octopus and greens veggie side, so good with a horseradish kick, great start.  Then the Karage was beautifully cooked, the Thighs and Onion skewers were bomb, and the cheese fried chicken was phenomenal.  Was super stoked we were able to reserve a kitchen bar spot on the same day! And that was before the Green Tea pana cotta, which is what you should be ordering as well, so now you know. 

Knocking off a star for the price (fairly high if you want to get full) and that one of the skewers (wasabi chicken) and one veggie dish we got were pretty meh, but overall it was definitely a quite pleasant experience.
author: Matt C.

description:
Pretty solid izakaya experience in SF.

I can't go comparing to LA or Hawaii, but this is one of the better places I've been to in the Bay Area.  The menu changes often, so you can keep going and trying new things.  Yakitori is always on the menu though, and pretty solid.  I had the chicken oyster, gizzard, and liver and they were all executed well.  Sashimi choices are also always fresh and well curated.  

Always end the night with a nabe or udon, this time we had the nabe udon for 2.  The noodles were housemade and had a good chew.  Everything was tasty, I have no complaints!

Tips and Tricks
-Go early, they tend to get crowded and half the sashimi menu was sold out by the time I got there at 8
-Ask your server for suggestions, and what's sold out that day before you get your heart set on that deluxe sashimi platter!
author: Jessica L.

description: Loved everything. Prices are SF standard but quality is amazing. Liver skewers, fish cake and pork katsu were the standouts. Service was very helpful and I appreciate the amount of info they give you. We waited a minute for our res, but they gave us menus and updates. Will come back.
author: Evan M.

description:
I considered not writing a review because I don't want this place to blow up and not be able to get a reservation anymore. But... I suppose that's not fair to Rintaro. 

I eat a lot of katsu. A lot. I even make my own katsu on occasion (with varying degrees of success). So when I found out there was a place that stuffed its chicken katsu cutlets with ooey gooey melted Cowgirl Creamery Cheese, I made plans to go. 

We got the gyoza, the katsu con queso (not called that so don't order it that way), the millefeuille pork katsu, the udon carbonara and some sides of rice (because the katsu unfortunately doesn't come with rice and I NEED rice).

The gyoza was really tasty however given that it's almost the same price as the CHEESE STUFFED FRIED MEAT CUTLET, next time I go I will be ordering katsu on katsu. The millefeuille katsu was equally delicious though I would prefer it sans hot mustard and with the traditional katsu sauce. The udon carbonara was really simple and delicious (a little too small but I love heaping mouthfuls of noodles so that's probably a personal issue). 

I did have my heart set on chicken heart skewers but they weren't on the menu that night :( 

Still, best katsu I've had in SF. It has cheese inside its fried folds.
author: Sam P.

description:
Just went here with my boyfriend for date night. A super cute spot in the mission. You would never guess it was here! 

Here's what we had:

- Bamboo rice: Delicious and fragrant but not worth $18. 
- Softshell crab: W-O-W, I would come back just for this. 
- Hotate sashimi: It's not a sushi spot and you could spot the ragged edges on the scallop. I wouldn't get it again, despite being very fresh. 
- Yosedofu: Very simple. The soy sauce was a weird addition. Would have preferred dashi.
- Duck salad: Very yummy but not very Japanese. 
- Yakitori: Come here for this. 
- Strawberry mochi: Save yourself $12 and just go to Japantown for mochi that'll cost less than half that. 

Overall, very pricey but quite good. Might just have to come again for that soft shell crab....
author: Courtney C.

description:
Udon 
Udon
Udon
Udon
Karage
Karage
Karage

from the zen garden entry to the exposed wood carpentry to the umm fizz cocktail to the French soap in the bathroom

The food is amazing the experience is deeply pleasurable 

Not to miss
author: Hallie C.

description:
Booked this place for my husband's birthday this year after quite a few recommendations from friends. I'm glad I did! 

The location is great - tucked behind a lively, well lit patio. Natural wood interiors, warm lighting, it was a very cozy feeling spot. The back room looked awesome, I would definitely book that space for a nice group dinner. 

We sat at the bar/chef's table area and I'm glad we did. It was fun to watch everyone in the kitchen at work. Service was prompt and friendly, and despite what other reviewers have said, we didn't have to wait an unreasonable amount of time in between dishes. 

We ate our way through: 
* Magura No Sashimi
* Rintaro Satsumage
* King Trumpet
* Teba No Karaage
* Kabocha Korokke Set 
* Kama Tama Udon x 2

All were delicious, we especially enjoyed the Udon. I also had this kickass sour lemon soda that I'm still dreaming about. Like nothing I'd had before, and I'm desperate to figure out how they made it. 

Overall, we had a really enjoyable evening and I'd recommend the place to others. My one disappointment was how much of the menu had sold out, though we sat pretty early in the evening. 

We ate at 7pm, but still had to swap out 3 of the larger dishes we had wanted to try. So if you have your heart set on the famous pork katsu, I guess get there at 4pm?
author: Brittany B.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for our anniversary and everything was great! 

We got the duck salad, hamachi sashimi, udon carbonara,  a few yakitori skewers which included: chicken thigh and green onion, asparagus, snap peas, chicken hearts, chicken oysters and chicken knee caps and we finished off with a strawberry profiterole. 

Everything was delightful, well, I wasn't into the chicken kneecaps but my boyfriend liked them. I couldn't get over the texture. My favorite was udon carbonara. The cocktails made with soju were really light and freshening as well. Would definitely recommend this place. 

Con: it's definitely pricey but worth it for a nice dinner out.
author: Katlyn H.

description:
Highly recommend. I came here with my boyfriend around open for dinner and were seated promptly at the bar. They have booths + seating outside, but the bar had a view into the kitchen where you got a peek at the action.

One thing right off the bat: they use real wasabi from Half Moon Bay. The difference between genuine wasabi and what is typically served in Japanese restaurants in the states is pretty staggering.

First dish: silken tofu w. shoyu, wasabi, and shallots  The tofu was solid but almost the texture of Yuoghurt

Next we had some skewers. The king trumpet (it's a mushroom) was amazing, but also get the meat skewers.

We also ate some more things, but really I don't know if I need to list them out. You should go here for dinner. Feel like a party of 4 would do well. Seating outside on a nice warm evening is how I'll return to this restaurant.

Oh, and I was going to be vindictive and take off a star since the iced tea wasn't free refills. But whatever, they choose their pricing model and I chose to order 2 iced teas so really it's not a big deal.
author: Andrew C.

description:
This place was utterly delicious. 

I cannot remember everything we ordered but I know we had: 

Viking Village Diver Scallop sashimi with Persian lime and half moon bay wasabi.
Curry potato and kabocha croquettes
King Trumpet and sweet pepper skewers
Japanese roasted green tea panna cotta with hojicha syrup and almond cookies. 

I know that panna cotta was to die for. I think I need to go back :)
author: Karen G.

description: Loved this place!!! The hostess and servers were super nice and attentive. The karaage wings were so good. They were better than the ones we had in Japan. The chicken thigh sansho skewers were also yummy. I could eat these everyday. I also enjoyed the maguro no yukke. It was a great finish to our dinner.
author: Michelle K.

description:
After an amazing dinner at Rintaro, my tummy feels so spoiled!

I made a reservation for 6 for my sister's birthday on a Sunday night. As soon as we walked into the front gates, we knew we were in for a treat. The lighting on the outside patio, the cute booths inside, sliding doors in the bathroom, all set the mood for a delightful evening.

First, we started the meal with the sashimi moriawase and house-made silken tofu in hot water.
- Each piece of sashimi melted in our mouths and we were all passive aggressively fighting for each last piece. 
- The tofu was creamy, and flavorful with the toppings + ponzu on the side.

Second, we ordered yakitori, chicken wings, and the 16 layer katsu. Again, jaw dropping plates. The first person to try each dish was quick to announce to the table that everyone needed to get in, fast.
- My favorite skewer was the chicken oyster, super tender and juicy + I liked that our server told us it's the part of the chicken in-between the thigh and butt haha.
- The chicken wings are cooked perfectly and have all the highlights of karaage but better.
- The katsu is made fit for a king, from the intricate layers to the hot mustard on the side, to the refreshing cabbage salad

Next, we ordered all of our final plates. Half of us ordered the mabotofudon and the other half ordered the kake udon with a hot spring egg.
- The mabotofudon was super comforting and had chunks of braised pork with a spicy sauce. yum!
- The udon is made with hand-pulled noodles and the egg... perfectly cooked with a custardy yolk.. Get the egg!! 

Lastly, we ordered the hojicha panna cotta and the souffle cheese cake.
- The panna cotta was awesome. I wish I could drink the hojicha syrup our of a jar. Intense roasted tea flavor with the right amount of sweetness.
- The cheesecake was fluffy, creamy, and far from your traditional new york cheese cake. More like all the best elements of a traditional cheesecake, transformed into a fluffy cloud.

All in all, this was an extraordinary dinner and we'll all be dreaming about our meal until our next visit.
author: Angie S.

description: Wonderful atmosphere, cool interior design, friendly and attentive staff. The food, well, the food was good. It wasn't outrageously overpriced, but in my opinion it was a little bit more than we should be paying for what we got. For instance the Gyoza has an amazing presentation, but flavor and texture was basically a standard potsticker. My boyfriend and I enjoyed the chicken skewers the most., In fact we had a lot of chicken. Chicken wings, Chicken Katsu.  I also tried a bowl of udon too. There was nothing wrong with any of the food, I was just expecting a more unique flavor experience. So I'm giving the place 4 stars. But it's really up about 3 1/2.
author: Gary B.

description: Cute restaurant and great selection of food. Came here for date night and enjoyed the service and food.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Absolutely insane.  Really fantastic restaurant and ambiance.  The sashimi was incredible - it was totally worth it.  The Kinki No Nitsuke (whole fish) was amazing.  Found the udon slightly underwhelming so I might recommend going other dishes instead.  The Yakitori were also great.  Wonderful sake as well.
author: Jessica L.

description: My friend made a reservation for dinner for 2 but upon arrival was offered to have seating at the bar, which we declined.  We were then told that there's a table we could have but the next guests are arriving at a certain hour as a way of telling us how long we could sit there for dinner.  Sheesh!  Worst of all, the food is meh.  We had multiple appetizers, followed by 2 entrees, a sake carafe, and a dessert.  Everything was overpriced for the quality.  This is a place for San Franciscans who don't know what a real Japanese food should taste like.
author: Kelly M.

description:
What a gem hidden by the freeway, I wouldn't have expected such a charming restaurant. Unsuspecting doorfront led inside to a restaurant with high wooden beams, ceiling windows, and little booths. 
Lunch menu I was told had fewer options than dinner, but we enjoyed a delicious Oyako Don. Best part was that the proceeds from this particular dish also benefited a local charity. 
The dessert was the highlight of the meal - green tea panna cotta with hojicha syrup and homemade almond cookies, the flavor was not overwhelming. It all fit perfectly. I will be back in the future to try the dinner menu in which they have yakitori!
author: Wendy L.

description: I wanted to try an izakya in San Francisco and came across Rintaro. My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our meal and just ordered green tea ice cream! :)
author: Amna H.

description:
made reservation online on Friday at 615pm. It wasn't crowded that time. And since we made reservation, waitress was able to seat us in within 5 mins. 

Food is above average. We ordered Yakitori and pork tonkatsu. The portion is really small.
Their menu doesn't have too many selections. 

Environment/service are good.
author: Tina H.

description:
I have sort of a conflicted relationship with izakaya-style (essentially Japanese gastropub or tapas-style small bites) restaurants. On one hand, I like getting to sample a variety of dishes and it's great for sharing among a group. On the other hand, prices are almost always excessive compared to portion size, and I often end up feeling slightly underfed, ripped-off, or both. Rintaro largely manages to sidestep that conflict for me by making up for it with amazing ambiance, presentation, and menu selection.

The restaurant is hidden away behind a very non-descript gate, but walk inside and you instantly feel like you've been transported into a cozy, relaxing bistro in Japan. The decor all feels very natural with bamboo fences, interesting plants, and elegant light wood-focused interior design that looks like it was taken straight from Japan. Even the bathroom locks with a nice sliding wooden bar, which I thought was a cool touch.

As for the food, you really can't go wrong in ordering. I tried the yosedofu (incredibly clean-tasting), thigh, chicken oyster (highly recommended), and liver yakitori, teba no karaage (fried chicken), pork katsu, kama tama udon ("carbonara"-style without broth), and the panna cotta for dessert (very interesting texture, almost egg-like with mild syrup poured over and seeping into it, great for sharing). I'll only say that the udon was a little underwhelming for the price, but the yakitori and fried dishes really hit the spot. Sadly they were out of croquettes, but I'll have to try those next time.

This place would be a great choice for a date or a small group (ideally four).
