It's busy and small enough to feel lively, but the tables are separated enough and the noise level is well-suited for boisterous conversation without having to shout. Rintaro is definitely a gem in the SoMa/upper Mission area, and after dinner you can pop in next door at Nihon Whisky Lounge (provided you have cash to burn, but that's a topic for another review).
author: Terry L.

description:
Have been here enough times and have been to Tokyo quite a few.

Service is good and I'll give 3 stars for that and the place kind of transports you out of the city.

Skip the sashimi altogether.  It's not good.  Actually, it's terrible.  And it's expensive.
Tastes frozen/defrosted and icy and overall lacking in flavor.  I keep getting it cause it's there on the menu.

The yakitori is tough.  Poorly cooked and executed.
Good ideas but needs better execution.  Especially at the price tag.
author: J S.

description: I came here for dinner for my friends birthday! Like usual parking can be a hassle in sf but it's so worth! We had a reservation at 5:30 and was immediately seated. The interior design is beyond aesthetic with a Japanese touch (of course). Their menus are super cute! This is definitely a small tapas type restaurant- we did not get full the the food was delicious! We ordered the fresh tofu (it comes with bonito flakes, ginger, and a soy sauce dip, the limited pork katsu, two yakitoris ( thigh and the tsuskune?) and the udon Kama tama. My favorite was the udon Kama tama- it comes with an gooey egg on top!! All in all would definitely come back for the udon again and the wonderful ambiance that the restaurant has!
author: Darlene D.

description:
Hailing from a city where izakaya is one thing done exceptionally well, I'm fairly picky when it comes to trying out new izakaya places. In all honesty, I am never looking for something innovative, fusion-y, or trying-so-hard-to-be-unique - I'm looking for places that serve the classics, well, and then once that is mastered, get a bit creative from there. Rintaro was certainly that for me.

THE OVERVIEW.
~ Parking can be a pain in the area, so come early or take a car service
+ Reservations are advised, although you should be able to book not-too-far in advance
+ The menu has a heavy emphasis on skewers, sashimi, and house-made udon (the chicken skewers are especially incredible)
+ Impressive sake selection, as well as creatively made cocktails
~ Slightly higher in price than your average izakaya place, but the quality is worth it

We had the pleasure of chatting briefly with Chef Sylvan Brackett, who was impressively solo-manning the skewer section of the kitchen in increasingly larger orders. Very nice, very talented guy - worth a visit!
author: Claire S.

description: Everything was perfection. The yakitori was sooo good, and I found my favorite sake from one of their flights. Not usually a fan of uni but they had fresh caught uni and it was delicious. Definitely recommend the sashimi platter. Will come back again for sure.
author: Nicole T.

description: We came here for my birthday and everything was amazing.  It had a really great look and the waitstaff were all really nice.  We had the sashimi, skewers, whole fish and two of the udon dishes.  The sashimi and udon were definitely the highlights, the whole fish was a little disappointing.  It was mostly skin and bones, but it was easy to overlook considering how good everything else was.
author: Salini N.

description:
Nice simple Izakaya near bar nihon. This is where your good for good basic Izakaya with a good sake selection. 

The yakitori and udon are both well done. Nothing I had here was break through but all the food was well prepared. The space has a nice outdoor area.
author: Ian C.

description:
Came here today for dinner with two other friends. This is the place that I wanted to go for a while, happened to be on a few Sundays, sadly, they don't open on Sunday morning, so check their open time before you go, and also, better to make a reservation first, because the seats are hard to be guaranteed for walk-ins. We got some luck today that only for 15mins walk, we got a outdoor seating, which was not too bad even it's in San Francisco, because they have heating above you, so it's very nice for dinner. 

Recommendations on the menu: skewers are a kill!
Yakitori:
Duck, thigh + onion

Fries: 
Fried chicken wings are pretty good too.

Dessert:
Green tea flavor icecream are pretty nice.

The sashimi, udon, tofu are just regular, you can try somewhere else. Just remember, order Yakitori won't be a mistake .
author: Christine Z.

description: Hands down my favorite izakaya in SF. The ambiance is great and I've not found anything on their menu that I didn't enjoy. Be prepared to get the bar seating if you go in small numbers.
author: Yad L.

description: Wow! I was super impressed with this place. For two people we ended up ordering about 5-6 dishes and we were quite full. My favorites were the house made tofu, the udon noodles, and also the tuna bowl. Definitely will be back to try the rest.
author: Tristan G.

description: Despite being located in a seemingly shady area, this place is GOAT. Everything we ordered was amazing, from the hirame sashimi to the chicken skewers. I'm so glad I found this place because it'll be my go-to "treat yourself" spot for sure. Everything here's high quality - one tip though is that the "final" dishes (mapo tofu/natto) might be acquired tastes if you're not familiar with them.
author: David Y.

description:
We came for a Sunday lunch and the food was sooooo tasty. 

We came specifically for the millefeuille katsu and it was just what we expected. Ever since we had it in Japan, we've been craving it again it they do a great job of it. All the accompaniments tasted great as well!
author: Katarina M.

description:
Probably, if not, the best Izakaya place in the city, top 3 for sure tho!  Make sure to book a reservation in advance as this place is very popular.  

The one thing I love about this place is the decor.  Bon Appetit wrote a great article about the meaning behind the inspiration and the way the restaurant was built: https://www.bonappetit.com/restaurants-travel/best-new-restaurants/article/rintaro-no-8.

Some highlights and food Recommendations:

SHUNGIKU KAMO SARADA - the grilled duck salad is to die for.

MILLEFEUILLE MISO KATSU - I might be just a little bit biased towards katsu tho...

AMADAI NO NITSUKE - WHOLE FISH.  Definitely worth ordering, even with a party of 2.  I think this is the most "bang for your buck" but also the fish was succulent and beautiful.  Warning, jopefully, you are good a deboning fish.

Definitely a MUST TRY if you are looking for an izakaya place within the bay area.
author: Ryan G.

description:
There's a spot in many neighborhoods that's for lease almost as often as it's tenanted, usually in a block that's more known in your perambulation as a space through which you pass to get from Somewhere to Somewhere Else.  This spot might be affectionately known as the place to which restaurants go to die.  Where as the renditions come and go the most noteworthy aspect in your short memory is what was there before.  Not so much what is there now.  And as a consequence of you and everybody else thinking thusly it's only a matter of time.

This, my friends, is not such a space.  

Because you-know-who is on it we respected the tradition of those without reservations and arrived early and earnestly waited outside looking forlorn and humble in a totally honest way and hoping that maybe just maybe there'd be a spot for us.  Moments before the clock struck the hour there were other parties entering the garden looking like people that actually had reservations and I was all creeping sadness mixed with the feeling that I'd been here before but when.

And it wasn't until today after reading many pretty uniformly excellent experiences recounted and then going back almost a decade in my recollection (which is way hard) and I realized that the place I told rabbit was near here was actually once indeed really here it was Chez Spencer and I had visited years before it burned down in 2013 with different friends.  I may have known this but if I did the recollection litters the floor of the canyon that has always existed between my short and long term memory.  You'd think by now that the canyon would be full of what I've forgotten and new memories could just walk across their fallen forebears from the short term space to the forever remember space but no that isn't how it works.

To the earlier point, this is not the place restaurants go to die.  It's the opposite.  This is a place they (and you) come to live.

As we were unreserved we only had 90 minutes at the table and I was all gee that's a lot of time we shouldn't have troubles with this at all and then.  Then we started tasting what they had prepared and I wanted to stay all night.

Chicken thigh skewers, paper thin halibut sashimi on leaves w accompaniments and a little sauce.  Udon.  Rice dish.  I should have taken better notes.  The menu changes.  The food was delicious.  The setting is sublime.  The experience is well-staffed and the people that will be assisting you are invested in your satisfaction.  Beer and sake no full bar but daydrink options abound nearby so worry not, my friend.  I would recommend the reservations, however, because there will be evenings where even the most honest plaintive look will not get you in the door.  For as there are more well informed and better prepared people in this world than me, and they'll have seen to that little detail and snatched up that spot your sadface might have otherwise attained..
author: Markus N.

description:
Good but so expensive. To put things into perspective, izakaya dishes are small. They are Japanese tapas essentially. We ordered a scallion squid salad that cost $10 and it was TINY! (See pic)

That said, the food we had was delicious and quality. A trademark of Japanese cuisine is that it doesn't feel heavy as it sits in your stomach. We ordered two katsu dishes and even though they were deep fried they didn't feel greasy or fatty but rather moist and tender. 

Service was pretty great as well. They provide blankets for guests on the patio which is a thoughtful gesture.
author: Loose Seal A.

description:
We ate at Rintaro our last night out in San Francisco earlier this year. It's pretty much right next to the freeway overpass, and this part of the neighborhood definitely has an industrial feel to it. The restaurant itself doesn't really stand out on a very quiet street, although once you step in, you find yourself in a very nice outdoor space that feels Japanese but is contoured with the industrial surroundings, and an indoor area that has high ceilings with warehouse fixtures - and then had a cozy Japanese restaurant's interior overlaid on it, giving you a spacious yet intimate setting. We sat in the back room, which is maybe more for reserved parties; this felt like a bit of an extension and didn't have the same airiness or modern, sleek feel that the rest of the restaurant did. I did appreciate the service, where food came out as quickly as it was served. The drinks here were a bit more limited, though. None of the Japanese beers (even the crafts) were ales, really leaving you only with very traditional lager flavors. One of our friends was a bit disappointed in the lack of unfiltered sake.

If anything, the drinks menu was a bit of an indication about how I felt about the whole meal - while there were a broad variety of items, the menu, particularly when it came to larger-type dishes, was surprisingly limited. I'd arguably say that the best thing I ate here were the karaage-style chicken wings, which had an absolutely delicious fry done on them and were marvelously crunchy and flavorful. The yakitori was okay but not that remarkable...we went a little off the beaten path in term of chicken parts and did the shoulder and the kneecap. The kneecaps were of varying quality - namely, some did not have all of the bones removed - making it a little adventurous to eat. The shoulders were a bit overcooked and basically came off as tougher version of chicken wings. On my 'main' courses, I will say that I did enjoy going for the more fusion-style carbonara udon, which was able to really soak up the egg and the parmesan to make it a well-done Japanese interpretation of an Italian pasta dish. Then I went with the natto...I love this dish that virtually everyone else hates, but for $9, it was served with umeboshi  and mustard - what are the chefs thinking? The flavors are just set up to clash with each other and make you wonder what you are eating...I stuck with eating the beans by themselves, which, while good, certainly did not warrant the vast markup over the frozen kind sold in stores.

In all, there were enjoyable parts of the meal, and other parts that were a bit wanting. I loved the ambiance but didn't love what came across as the lack of variety relative to other izakaya spots I have eaten at. I might come back to see if there's something that I missed, but I would probably try a different Japanese spot in town first before returning.
author: Asuka N.

description:
I went there on a Monday for dinner date. The restaurant is very cute and looks very authentic Japanese. The vegetarian items are limited, so I was able to sample through all of them.

-Salad: very nice with yellow mustard and a little wasabi taste. Much better than what I've expected!
-Mushroom stick: very nice and juicy. I feel it was good but not uniquely great.
-Cold tofu: very nice cold dish. Adding some ginger and soy sauce made it a very refreshing dish. 
-Kabocha croquette (!!): this dish does not exist on the menu, and you'll only be offered this if you explicitly say that you're vegetarian and are looking for sth to eat. The croquette is pretty great, goes well with beer, would recommend for vegetarians and carnivores
-Natto Don: I felt the portion was a little to big. It is a huge bowl of rice and natto. If you're not in love with natto, I don't know if this is worth it
-Houjicha Panna Cotta: I felt this was a little too sweet. You can taste the tea flavor, but I would have liked it better if it was less sweet but more tea-like. 

All in all, a solid 4.5 stars for me, -0.5 for the limited vegetarian items. I think it's a great place to go with friends for a fancy Japanese experience. They have a good sake selection too with home-made plum wine, which I would recommend trying.
author: Yu-Hsin L.

description:
it's 4.5!  -0.5 for the location!!

it's tucked in right next to the freeway, def not the ideal location for such unique modern decoration of an Izakaya. 

5/5 for the ambience
5/5 food was amazing and authentic!! Literally came back from Tokyo a month ago and made me felt like I was at Tokyo's Izakaya but only 10 min away from my house!
4/5 it's on the expensive side especially for the skewers (quite overpriced for what it really worths) Ehw it's SF in general...

Highly recommended it and will def come back
author: Kandice Z.

description:
overall very nice, i thought it would be a more japanese feel place, but it's actually feel very american in some ways. food is very authentic.

tsukune - 4 stars. had better tsukune before, but it's definitely decent quality. it's kinda dry for my taste.
knee - 5 stars. what a surprise. very tender, juicy. with crispy outside. love it.
pasta with raw egg yolk - 5 stars. first time having this kind of dish. delicious. very rich flavor.
 
definitely will come back and try something differnet
author: Harucus S.

description: Good food with good friends. I liked the wings and anchovies. The waitress was considerate. They keep the place clean and tidy. My friends and I had a good time catching up.
author: Gomz G.

description: If there's a worse example of customer service, please tell me so I can avoid it. We've tried to go here multiple times. Hostess is incapable of providing accurate information on seating time, or sitting you at tables that have been/are open. We've waited over 30 minutes on each occasion without any update and have left to grab pizza next door.
author: Eric D.

description: Outstanding! Really simple dishes that pack a punch! Use ingredients that are uncommon to make it a memorable dish.
author: Brandon F.

description:
We have an addiction to Izakayas and this place was better than we expected... by a lot! So much so we just booked my hubby's birthday party here.

What i recommend:
- chicken tail
- chicken neck
- fried smelt
- chicken oyster
- chicken meatball
- chicken heart

The only thing we were disappointed with was the layered pork katsu. It felt like we were eating shabu meat with a too sweet of a sauce. Besides that we loved it and want to come back x 10!

Also their "pina colada" is addicting... i finished 2 but could probably have a lot more!
author: Christina C.

description: This is my favorite Izakaya in San Francisco. Always great food that changes seasonally. Great sake. Nice atmosphere with a fun and pretty interior. The chicken meatball yakitori is everytthaaang as is all of the fried section.
author: Wendy K.

description:
My friend and I went here on a Thursday night and were seated right away. Seems like they were reserving a lot of tables, though, as we took the last one for 2. Rintaro has 3 seating areas: outside patio in the front, main room by in the middle, and a back room. 

The menu is very detailed and contained a lot of terms that we weren't familiar with. Luckily, our waiter was really nice and recommended a few dishes for us. Aside from the udon and donburi options, the other items are small plates and are meant to share. 

- Yellowtail sashimi: Standard sashimi, so it was good. 
- Croquettes: these were pretty good! One serving comes with 2 large croquettes. Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside - also comes with a good sauce that makes it so flavorful!
- Gyoza: So delicious, you cannot go wrong with dumplings! Comes with a dipping sauce.
- Skewers: we ordered a few skewers (each serving comes with 2 skewers). The waiter recommended all of them to us: mushrooms, chicken breast, chicken oysters and chicken meatballs. I think the skewers were my least favorite part of the meal. There wasn't anything really special about them. The mushrooms and chicken meatballs were good. The chicken oysters were also good but were considered to be deluxe and I just didn't think it was that special. The chicken breast, however, was by far the worst dish. It was very bland and dry. 
- Profiterole: This was our dessert and it was actually one of my favorites. It is a cream puff stuffed with a large scoop of ice cream. It was yuzu-flavored and very well done. Not too citrusy, not too sweet. The cream puff was baked perfectly (crispy on the outside, soft on the inside) and the ice cream was so flavorful. Definitely a good way to end the night. 

Our bill ended up being ~$100 total for the both of us, which isn't horrible, but I wasn't extremely full after either. Would recommend this place if you have money to spend and not a huge appetite! Good quality food, regardless.
author: Lillian B.

description:
Such a cool vibe with kind of "whatever" food. 

The good: The architecture of the space. The staff is lovely and very helpful in either Japanese or English. This is totally a place to take someone who doesn't care about food and loves chic spaces that you can instagram.

The underwhelming: The food. The yakitori, which I think is kind of their focus, was very unmemorable. The whole fish we got was beautiful (again, think instagram) but literally had no flavor. The katsu was good but not good enough that I'd go back on food alone.

Overall like, I'm not dying to go back here (it's overpriced for what it is, not that it's crazy expensive). That said, if I was entertaining some business person or friend from out of town who didn't care about food and wanted to chronicle their SF trip in photos, then I'd gladly take them here.
author: Ryan J.

description: This place is so good! Came here on a weekday for lunch and sat outside since we had a dog with us. They were super accommodating and even brought out some water for our corgi :)  Their lunch menu is a bit different from their dinner, but we ordered a katsu dish as well as a sashimi dish. Both of these main dishes came out on beautiful trays filled with other side dishes. We also ordered a side of chicken wings as well as the infamous green tea panna cotta. Everything was really amazing. The bill did come out to around ~$100 (after tip and tax) which is pretty pricey for lunch, but highly recommended still!
author: Megan K.

description:
I've come to Izakaya Rintaro a couple times now and I've loved it every time. I absolutely LOVE the skewers. The standards are some of my favorites. The oyster from the deluxe menu is also very delicious, though it's a bit on the sweeter side. I think I've only tried the king trumpet from the vegetable section and it's definitely worth trying.

Some of the other items I've tried are:
Shungiku Kamo Sarada - The duck is delicious with the chrysanthemum greens
Teba No Karaage - I'm a sucker for good karaage and this karaage is pretty awesome 
Chiizu Tori Katsu - The chicken katsu is so yum especially since it has cheese in it :D
Natto Don - This was a great dish to end on. It's a little soupy with some meat and tofu and it was definitely a favorite amongst the table

Izakaya Rintaro is one of my favorite restaurants in the city now. The staff is very nice and knowledgeable which is really helpful if you aren't too sure what to order. Definitely make a reservation soon if you've never been.
author: Radhika G.

description:
2.5 stars. My friend Nina Y. is currently tackling this year's 7x7 list. On that list is the yakitori from Izakaya Rintaro, so naturally she added this place to our calendar of food adventures and made a reservation. Let me summarize this review by saying that Nina and I actually had a debate at the end of our meal about whether we should give this place 2 or 3 stars. I've settled in the middle with 2.5 stars only because I thought the food was excellent, but I would not come back here again if it keeps up their horrible and awkward service.

When I first arrived, I was not greeted. Not that I'm trying to be pretentious about this, but I made eye contact with several waitresses, and they all ignored me. Fortunately it was easy to find Nina, sitting at the barstool area. I'll also take this moment to note that the chairs were small and uncomfortable, even though I'm a relatively tiny person. The plus side of the restaurant setup is that they have a beautiful front courtyard with seating.

As for food, we checked yakitori off our list. Our selections included Rintaro Tsukune, Thigh and Onion, and Chicken Oyster. These were super fresh and made right in front of us. Delicious! We also got the Kama Tama Udon, which is udon carbonara with ginger, scallion, butter, and shaved katsuobushi, topped with a freshly cracked raw egg. This was a small portion but still tasty. The textures and mixture of flavors were on point.

Back to the service. Nina and I are generally patient people and try to understand that restaurants get busy, but there were SO many staff members working there, and it took at least 15 minutes for anyone to ask about drinks or generally make us feel welcome. Perhaps it's the hands-off culture of the place. Who knows? Then once our cocktails were brought, it felt like another 15 more minutes to gather our food order. 

During our meal, I felt uncomfortable when the waitresses kept reaching over me without my permission to clear dishes and wipe the table unnecessarily. I appreciate the attempt at service, but it was done with zero tact. Is it too much to ask for basic human interaction? And as predicted, it took forever to get the bill. I could spend hours talking to Nina, but something about the experience at this restaurant screamed sleepy and slow. It was so miserable having to be here for so long and sitting in this uncomfortable chair. I wish I had better things to say about this place, but my impression was... great food but terrible service!
author: Stefanie C.

description: We had the chicken meatball and chicken negima thighs with onion yakitori (both solid); pork gyoza which comes with a layer of the crisp shell over the dumplings (very stuffed dumplings vs the thinner gyozas that I am used to and prefer); the potato and Kabocha squash croquettes (two tasty and filling large patties) with a thick sauce that tastes like A1; the Suzuki sashimi (lots of thin slices of white fish- maybe it was snapper); and the mabodofu rice bowl with tofu, pork and a mildly spicy chili sauce.  Generally this was the perfect amount of food, and it was paced really well.  There was always Something on the table.  I found that the flavors were quite mild, and found myself wishing I had some kind of hot sauce to add some kick.  Everything was solid, but not particularly memorable.  I found izakaya yuzuki to have more memorable dishes, as well as Nomica which is a bit further afield from izakaya but has some elements of it.  But overall a solid meal.  We sat in the courtyard where it was key to have one of the tables under the heat lamps.  They provide blankets.
author: Vivian W.

description:
This place is relatively hidden.

What I did like about it, sitting by the chef's counter. It's nice to see all the skewers being bbq'd. Seems like a very nice date spot. When you go here, I would encourage eating more of the skewers. Well cooked, juicy, and lots of variety. Might be expensive though $4/ meat skewer.

I tried the other things like tofu + sashimi + udon. The sashimi was good, but nothing really special (I wouldn't try it here). The tofu might've had really good quality, I just don't think I can appreciate good quality tofu. I got the cold udon as well. I liked the noodles, once again don't think it was that special.
author: Victor D.

description:
Lovely experience at Rintaro. The atmosphere is absolutely beautiful-- can't go wrong with either a wooden booth inside or the outdoor seating with string lighting.

Didn't have a single bad dish here, and we tried a lot! Favorites were any of the sashimis (they come with maybe 8-10 pieces each), the whole grilled fish, marinated tuna over warm rice, and duck skewers.
author: J. A.

description:
Highest hopes. Didn't quite deliver. Very cool if you're hip, young, trendy. Actually, guess it's closer to a 3.7, but I'm not in the best of moods. Waitress was pretty rude. Said it would be an hour wait (Sat night, around 9 pm). But then people in front of us were seated. Took a bit of reminding from my aggressive Asian friend to get us in. Since My memory isn't so great, and I'm reviewing this after the fact, can't remember exactly what we ordered. It was good. Not mind blowing, but very good. We sat in the back room. Would recommend the front area/bar, if you can. Kind of felt we were in the back room, which we were.... 

Very good food, just thrown off by the service and seating.
author: Lisa B.

description: Best Japanese style skewers we had for a long time, the liver is a must have, knee bone is also delicious, highly recommend.
author: Willy L.

description: This place is authentic - and really good even in Japanese standard (am Japanese from Tokyo). Pleased to have found this gem :)
author: Sakura I.

description:
The food is prepared fresh daily using ingredients that are sources from specific farms or local farmer's market. For example, the chicken is from Riverdog Farm and the wasabi is grown in Half Moon Bay. This also means that the menu changes frequently and certain items can sell out more quickly. If you suffer from FOMO, we insist that you go frequently and order as much as possible.

Here's a list of dishes to try:
https://weareallbusypeople.blogspot.com/2017/09/izakya-rintaro.html
author: Eric S.

description:
This was my first izakaya in the states.
It didn't let me down.
It's a refreshing atmosphere that reminds me of Japan. To add the authenticity there are Japanese cooks. And there was even a little Japanese kid walking around and playing. Very homey type feel.
I had made a reservation at 8:15pm on a Thursday. Always do research before you go because sometimes you'll get lost (I always get lost) me and my friend arrived a bit late (8:30) but we were seated still. We sat at the Chef's table(I prefer to watch people cook). I usually get worried about trying to arrive at a certain reservation time as per respect of restaurants I never like being late.
The chefs were friendly and welcoming! Everyone was actually!

Now on to the food.
There are the basics that I stuck with,
Fried chicken
Tuna sashimi
Oyster chicken yakitori
Pork gyoza(off menu)
Had a bottle of Sequoia Genshu Sake
And another glass of sake

All of it was really delicious and I like to observe when chefs are cooking as well. They look like they enjoy their job and they have fun with it too. I suggest you come here for yummy food and really great sake!

^_^
author: Danielle G.

description: You better call first or else gota wait in line .......best Japanese food i had in years .....best service with warm welcome .....if you don't know what to order ,just ask them , we had a deulex sashimi and a bbq liver and meat balls ,perfect ! The tenderness of the liver just right so that means the chef is very experienced ! I give it 5 starts ...
author: Charles W.

description: After eating our way through the city, we stumbled upon Rintaro unnecessarily needing anymore food or alcohol. Boy, are we happy to have found it! Wanting just a snack and night cap, we came with the intention of trying a few yakitori skewers and maybe some sake. Rintaro sits in a quiet neighborhood that can easily be missed. A cute patio with dimmed lights and ample seats awaits. We were lucky to land a seat at the open kitchen bar. The chef and kitchen staff definitely put on a show, working in perfect harmony. Our server was friendly and recommended a sake to us and promptly took our order. We decided on chicken hearts and king trumpet mushrooms yakitori. OMG!! Delicious. The seasoning (Tare) was the best I've had. It was perfectly cooked. Having already overindulged, we watched the chef prepare fresh wasabi. You don't see this often at all! Usually wasabi is mixed in a powder form, but to see that they had fresh wasabi was truly a sight to see in itself. I had to indulge more. We ordered the half moon bay spot prawns sashimi. Best I've ever had!! And they were huge. Chef carefully extracted the roe and fried the heads to perfection. I'd definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for great food.
author: Paul N.

description: The cutest venue with outdoor seating under gas warmers also available. Nice selection of tasty beers and sake. The menu has several fresh cuts of fish, fried chicken, lots of delicious udon and rice options. The pork appetizer was especially  delicious. Their fried chicken wings are popular and though fried well the seasoning was akin to but less appealing than the Korean sweet sauce version. A very diverse kitchen with few Asians, which is unique from most Japanese restaurants, and reflected in the dishes with delicious combinations of fusion cuisine.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Whaaat - sweet outdoor seating, perfectly balanced decor, great service, housemade udon, plum wine & everything in between - all (very unexpectedly) in the middle of 14th Street. Totally exceeded my expectations, and one of the only places worth the price IMO. Its high walls and relaxed but upscale ambiance also made you feel like you were elsewhere (aka not in the middle of janky Mission/SF), which is awesome.

We made a reservation for a table of 8, seated outside on an unusually warm SF evening and started off with some light and refreshing yuzu chuhai (perfect for the summer) and yakitori. Highlights included:
-- gyoza - off the menu, crispy, meaty, and flawlessly seasoned, no skimping on stuffing here
-- plum wine - housemade once a year, limited in quantity but exquisitely tart and fresh
-- kama tama udon - hand made carbonara udon with fresh raw egg, butter, ginger and katsuobushi flakes

To top off, the service was delightful (yes, actually delightful). Will have to come back for the sashimi options and am super excited to have finally found a place perfect for visitors/parents.
author: Anna H.

description: The homemade tofu and chicken thigh/ spring onion skewers were really great! It was worth the one hour wait :)
author: Susan P.

description: Came here the 2nd time, yakitori is good as always. The green tea panna cotta is sooooo good! It absolutely delighted the whole meal! The green tea flavor is perfect after the heavy yakitori. Highly recommended!
author: Xi L.

description:
Rintaro is amazing!! We got a couple different kinds of skewers. The thigh, meatballs, liver, and duck. They were all so good. The duck was and thigh were super tender and juicy. The liver comes with a garlic paste which goes together so well. The meatball is perfect with the dried red pepper powder they provide. We also got the gyoza which was juicy and crispy. The udon cabonara was so good as well. It has a great bonito dried fish and creamy egg yolk taste.

Lastly the panna cotta was so delicious. It was smooth, silky and creamy. They give a roasted tea flavored syrup to pour on top which goes amazing with it.

5/5 would come again! Staff also recommended a lot of those dishes to us and they were spot on!
author: Christopher S.

description: While definitely on the expensive end, the experience is truly satisfying. The Katsu is so incredibly crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. The chicken skewers are properly cooked: very juicy and flavorful. The tuna rice bowl with raw egg yolk is also memorable.
author: Yuan W.

description: Every dish we ordered was excellent.  The Chiizu Tori Katsu (fried chicken with cheese) was the most unexpected dish. The cheese was rich and creamy, and the fried outside was crisp and light.  It is served tapas style, so the bill really adds up if you eat a lot.
author: Ben E.

description:
It's hard to believe that beyond this outstanding restaurant's front doors are sidewalks littered with human turds (as of last Saturday). However, this didn't make us lose our appetite. In fact, we were ravenous and ordered a shitload:

-Kani no sunomono - My favorite crab sunomono to date!
-Dashimaki tamago - Egg omelette in dashi broth that was pretty special for my first visit. 
-Three types of yakitori: Liberty duck, chicken oyster and gizzard - The chicken oyster was my favorite dish of the night.
-Chiizu tori katsu - Stuffing chicken katsu with cheese is genius, and Cowgirl Creamery, no less.
-Karee raisu - I typically don't care for Japanese curry, but this was really good. I just wish it came with more than just two measly pieces of beef.
-Hojicha panna cotta - I scraped the glass and licked it clean. Enough said.

Our server was super cute and helpful - she gave some great recommendations and we ended up loving every single thing we tried. The menu changes often, so I'm definitely planning on returning to stuff my face again. If this means having to dodge through a BM obstacle course, so be it.
author: Suany W.

description:
This is currently my most favorite Kaiseki style dining in America, beating out the contenders in Manhattan. Disguised as an izakaya place, it actually has the dishes laid out in Kaiseki sequence, but you have the option to pair it however you like, which makes it more flexible because I know what I do and do not care for in a Kaiseki set menu: no to the veggies and soup, double up on sashimi and grilled goods. 

There has never been a place that made me miss Japan as much as this restaurant. The court yard waiting area looked like a small zen garden. Once inside, it has a very solid wood feel to the decor and table settings, the grills are right within eyesight.

Exceptional sashimi, grilled odd pieces, the last dishes (aka the rice and noodles) should be consumed up front because it's super delicious to save it to the end. But the best thing to get is the whole fish. Totally blew my mind. Gyoza is better than most Chinese dumplings but not as good as some of the best ones I've had in Asia, but definitely close to being at the top tier. 

There are practically nothing bad there, just that you should not miss the dessert as it's lovely. I had so much to say about this place but I didn't want to say too much. I prefer to have everyone else think this is just okay, a mediocre place, so that it does not get mobbed like the rest of the crowd pleasers. 

This is legit. I learned it from my Japanese friend who learned it from her Japanese friend. I have a few of those establishments under my belt to compare with, some are Michelin star restaurants in New York. I can say with a straight face that this is no ordinary craft.

I know a good one when I see one. This is a keeper, a serious eatery that deserves more than five stars if I could reassign the rating system.

I already have three friends I've promised to take here. Not so much about showing off my favorite spot, but because there are a few more (not many, mind you, we ordered 20 different things the last time we were here) dishes that I've not tried. Plus I intend to share with my friends all about Kaiseki dining through this izakaya menu, which by the way, is how every kaiseki restaurant should consider doing.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Dropped in late on a Thursday night and got seated right away. Absolutely enjoyed the fact that the hostess and majority of the staff were Japanese and spoke Japanese. It adds to the authenticity of the restaurant. 

I think we ordered every Yakitori and Odd Bits off the menu two times over (I ate nearly all of it). My favorites were the Gizzards, Rintaro Tsukune, Chicken Oyster, and Chicken Hearts. All of them were so good and so flavorful. We also enjoyed Udon (I forget which one) but it was really good. The Chiizu Tori Katsu was good as well. If I were visiting here again I could eat all the Yakitori and Odd Bits alone. Everything else would be extra, that's how good they are.
author: John M.

description: Rintato is a great date spot and for smaller groups. Larger groups are more expensive and the food isn't that great to share for larger parties.  One of my favorite izakayas in the fatty bay.
author: Fatty A.

description: A group of us ordered one of every type of skewer they had left that day to share, including some menu items they had that day such as chicken neck and tail. It was all amazingly delicious! The chicken liver w garlic skewers were my favorite; a very rich and unique flavor, potentially not for everyone but I loved it! The udon "carbonara" was also very good!
author: Chuck H.

description:
Oh how I adore Rintaro! I've been here twice for dinner so far, and I predict more visits are in my future because of the delicious food, delightful service, and beautiful atmosphere. And great sake.

I've been to Japan several times, and one of the things I love most about Rintaro is how it transports me back there. Walk into their courtyard and you feel like you've stepped into Japan. The interior is gorgeous, and I love watching the activity in their open kitchen.

In terms of the food, the handmade udon is a particular highlight. I'd never tried udon before because I thought it would be bland (e.g., compared to soba), but the server on our first visit recommended it highly. I'm so glad I took her advice because it was absolutely beautiful. So tender and flavorful! The broth is outstanding as well, and I really appreciate it being fish-based instead of pork-based. Out of our two visits, the only thing we didn't care for was a salad that was overpowered by a miso dressing (hence 4 stars instead of 5). 

The service here is kind and thoughtful, which I really appreciate. For example, I love sake, so on our first visit I asked for a recommendation from the sake menu. Our server proceeded to double-check all her notes on our order first, then gave me a couple choices based on what we had picked - and the recommendation was just perfect!

I strongly recommend Rintaro for a special night out - especially if you miss Japan like I do!
author: Julie C.

description: Always treated with the warmest welcome, fresh seasonal ingredients & impeccable cooking techniques to enhance its natural purest flavor to bring harmony to your tastebuds! Highly recommend their whole fish, it'll take some time to be served at the table but well worth the forgotten wait.
author: Elle K.

description:
If you don't care for udon, there's not much here to get you full... Got the house tofu, halibut sashimi, thigh yakatori, extra thighs (because the duck was out), meatball yakatori, wings, and katsu.

The thigh yakatori was flavorful and great; only item worth ordering. Everything else was a 3 star-- edible but would not order again. 

-Overpriced like most japanese restaurants. 
-Our waitress's English wasn't great, but the real problem was that she had such a soft voice that you could never hear what she was saying. 
-Food comes out one a time... Not good for hungry people. If we had known before hand, we would have just told them to bring it out as it was ready. 
-Drinks came out really slow too.
author: Phi N.

description: Good thing we made reservations, as the place was packed for dinner.  Everything we ordered was delicious and very fresh. The skewers were juicy and the Katsu was on par with what you would expect from authentic Japanese food.
author: Thomas C.

description: Food was good.  The service was ok. They allow dogs which is ok but on a few occasions I have had issues with regulars with barking dogs.  It wasn't a calm serene experience.
author: Sharam G.

description:
izakaya rintaro is a total gem! im so glad to have finally tried this spot. im not usually a fan of izakaya style dining because i always want to have a huge bowl of ramen but it's unfeasible to eat all the small plates and end with ramen in one evening. however rintaro doesnt actually offer ramen, but udon in small servings, so i thought this might be the perfect solution.  came here with my girlfriend around 8 pm on a rainy monday and the place was PACKED. there is a courtyard outside that is super cute and good for waiting (when its not raining) - they bring out cocktails as you order them outside, which is always a plus.  we waited about 40 minutes for a table for 2 in the back room. the restaurant is pretty small, and people definitely like to take their time, so best come armed with a reservation.

we got seated and dived into ordered - skewers: chicken thigh and trumpet mushrooms, fried pork cutlet, the gyozas, and one serving of udon carbonara. i thought the skewers were very well done - i would definitely order more next time to try the various meat and veggie offerings. the cutlet was very nicely done - crispy and hot and crunchy and just the right amount of salty. gyozas were probably my favorite part of the meal - not only was the presentation awesome, the flavor was great and dumplings were super juicy. the udon is made in house and cooked to order, so it took a while longer to arrive and i wish things were timed better.

overall - really solid spot with good, tasty foods!  i docked a star for the relative lack of enthusiasm the host to greet us and seat us as soon as possible, and the service we received - there was a lot of confusion with food orders (delivered a few things that werent ours) and confused my cocktail order because the waiter didnt let me finish and assumed he knew what i wanted. so a bit disappointing there. but glad i tried it - would come back and try to sit at the bar to watch the kitchen magic go down!
author: Christina L.

description: Beautiful place but the food not tasty at all. The server was kind of rude when she answered my question about the Manu.
author: Cindy X.

description: Came here for brunch with a friend, thought it was decent.  The brunch menu is really limited, so we couldn't try the majority of the food that everyone raves about.  But it was a cute place and servers were nice as well.  I'd come back to try their dinner options, but not the brunch.
author: Kevin M.

description: Just so great. I got the kobocha karage and it was out of this world. The attention to detail in the side plates is also perfect
author: Erica B.

description:
They open at 6PM and won't seat you till then. There is indoor and outdoor seating. If they offer you chef counter do not sit there. These are the most uncomfortable stools ever. No backing and the seat itself is super small. I can't imagine anyone bigger sitting on this. At least they have purse hooks underneath the counter. The nice thing about sitting at the chef counter is that you can see all the action happening. The service was good and I liked that when I asked our waitress for suggestions, she really gave her input. Every dish she suggested was really good. 

SHISHITO PEPPERSs-a must when I see this on a menu

MISO CODE-cooked perfectly

HOKKAIDO KOMBU-CURED MARIN COAST HALIBUT SASHIMI WITH HALF MOON BAY WASABI-good amount and it was fresh. 

HOUSE-MADE SILKEN TOFU WITH MEIJI SOY MILK SCALLION, GINGER AND UME SHOYU-super silky tofu. This dish is cold. I like how we can mix the toppings and sauce ourselves. 

CHICKEN OYSTER RINTARO AND TSUKUNE Y A K I T O R I-Their tsukune is delicious. The chicken oyster is tender and flavorful

PORK KATSU WITH CHEESE-Moist, flavorful, and crispy. The cheese goes well with the pork. 

Final dish-tofu and minced pork-basically a "mapo tofu"-least favorite dish of the night. I can make it way better. Too sour for my liking.
author: Karen H.

description:
One of my favorite Japanese places in the city. It has a unique menu and always something new. I've never eaten anything I didn't like! Try the Yakitori skewers, the "Odd Bits" with hearts, gizzards or liver are my particular favorite. Udon is amazing, and the gyoza are impressive. Highly recommend!

I've always had an easy time getting a reservation here if I call one day ahead but I feel like that's eventually going to change!
author: Amanda L.

description:
Have heard about this place from friends for a while but never attempted to visit because I don't want to wait in line. Stopped by yesterday when it was raining and scored seats right away (thank you, rain!)

It was great!

The vibe made feels like I was in Tokyo, and so is the food. We tried the whole grilled rainbow trout. It was good but not amazing. I was more impressed by their yakitori skewers. They also have oden, which I'd like to try next time. 

Lastly, their hojicha panna cotta might sound gimmicky but it was surprisingly delicious!
author: Joseph L.

description: Just had a great seafood lunch platter from Izakaya Rintaro.  The best part was the dessert - the green tea panna cotta was just amazing.
author: Andrew S.

description:
All of our food was great, and I got several 5-star dishes out my dinner. I highly recommend this spot if you like Izakaya! Definitely come with a group so you can try a lot of things on the menu!

RESERVATIONS: Made online about a month in advance. 

SERVICE: Very professional and accommodating. We needed to be in and out in an hour to catch a show, and they made it happen!

MUST-HAVES: Libery Duck, Teba No Karaage (Japanese fried chicken wings), Kabocha Korokke (potato croquettes), Hojicha Panna Cotta! See my pics for additional info.

CHU-HAI COCKTAIL
* Shoga Chu-Hai (ginger syrup w/ shochu & lemon. $11) - 4 stars
Light & refreshing, with a slight sharpness from the ginger.

FRESH TOFU
* Yosedofu (rintaro silken tofu w/ meiji soy milk, scallion, katsuobushi & new ginger. $9) - 4 stars
Dense yet light texture, wonderfully unique. Interesting interplay of flavors. The crisp fresh scallion was the cherry on top.

HOUSE DISH
* Dashimaki Tamago (fancy folded omelet w/ riverdog farm eggs & freshly shaved katsuobushi dashi. $9) - 3 stars
Lackluster for this restaurant. Texture was soft but very one-dimensional flavor-wise. 

SIMMERED
* Gyu Suji Nikomi (Marin sun beef shank & tendon simmered w/ daikon, ginger & black yamaki miso. $14) - 4 stars
A heavier dish for izakaya, but the meat is so soft. The flavor is really intense. 

YAKITORI
* Tsukune Meatballs ($7) - 3.5 stars
Good, not super memorable though. 

* Liberty Duck ($8 for two skewers) - 5 stars
Amazingly fatty, full of rich delicious flavor. Everyone at the table was crazy about this. 

FRIED
* Teba No Karaage (Japanese fried chicken wings w/ smokey tare & sansho pepper. $9 small) - 4.5 stars
Incredibly moist meat. We all loved this too - a thick yet light breading. 

* Kabocha Korokke (curry kabocha & potato croquettes w/ acme panko & snowy cabbage. $11) - 4.5 stars
Such a unique dish! The breading has layers upon layers of thin crisp. The potato inside has a soft contrast. I love the way it feels to take a bite.

FINAL DISH
* Teuchi Udon (Rintaro hand-rolled udon w/ two fishes broth, green onion & nori. $9, add kaki farm hot spring egg $2) - 4.5 stars
Delicious. A light but flavorful broth, perfect texture to the noodles, and a silky soft egg.

* Ikura Don (rice w/ Quinault River steelhead salmon roe, freshly grated wasabi & toasted nori. $12) - 3.5 stars
The roe was amazing, but this was an otherwise rather plain dish - a little too much rice. 

DESSERT
* Hojicha Panna Cotta (Japanese roasted green tea panna cotta w/ hojicha syrup & almond cookies. $9) - 4 stars
Texture was on the dense side, not as light & jiggly as other panna cottas I've had. It was still good, and the green tea flavor really unique. The crackers were dry, too crunchy, and didn't have a good complementing flavor (slightly savory).
author: Ziyan C.

description:
My favorites:

Chicken Oyster
Udon Carbonara
Perfectly seasoned Sashimi that had cucumber and fried garlic on top. I can't remember the type of fish thanks to being almost a bottle of sake in by the time I ate this dish

Ambience was comfortable with great music, and a spot at the Chef's counter will keep you entertained with watching the line. I will definitely be back to further explore their menu and hopefully pop in for lunch one day this summer on their lovely patio :)
author: Britt M.

description:
Really fun izakaya! I think some izakaya in the country has a more serious vibe to it, where chefs/owners are trying to make it more fancy than what an izakaya needs to be. But Rintaro definitely tones the seriousness down a bit while delivering delicious Japanese bar food.

Menu seems to change frequently!

Lemon Chu-Hai cocktail $10

Liberty Duck yakitori $8 - juicy and flavorful, less fatty than I expected (and hoped for)
King Trumpet yakitori $5 - yakitori chef gave us these for free, for waiting too long. I was surprised at how flavorful these were. They were so good - totally order these if you can.

Kare No Karaage $22 - crispy fried fish. I loved the crispiness and flavors of the fish with sauce. The dipping sauce (mori-tsuyu) was a great pairing with the fish, I literally ate most of it by myself...
Teba No Karaage $9 - Japanese fried chicken wings. Super delicious as well, highly recommended. I could have probably eaten ten wings by myself too. Me and fried foods :(

Rintaro Kare Raisu $10 - serving for one person. Rice and Niman Ranch beef curry with apple, potato, carrot, and hot spring egg. I don't think I got the egg :( Or maybe it was cleverly hidden in the dish. This was underwhelming and really simple. So simple that I can (and have) made it at home. The beef was good, but two little pieces? I don't think I'll order it again.

Kama Tama Udon $8 - serving for one person. Boyfriend's favorite of the night. Simple take on the carbonara with hand-rolled udon, raw farm egg, butter, ginger, daikon, and spicy cod roe. Crack the egg into the udon, and swirl it around. The simplified version of this dish is a common Japanese breakfast item with raw egg, rice, and soy sauce - one of the boyfriend's favorite. He thought the carbonara version lacked a little more seasoning so he asked one of the chefs for shoyu and was given a similar mixture. It was so much better after that! And the chef thanked us for the feedback :) 

Everything left us super full and happy :) thanks for a great dinner!
author: Lucy Z.

description:
With their popularity as high as ever, izakayas of nearly every ilk are spread across the Bay Area.  There are the traditional (Izakaya Mai), the newer generation (Izakaya Sozai), and the posers (the now-defunct Izakaya Ju-Ku).  As for Izakaya Rintaro?  More of the trendier, hipster-ish variety, but no less delicious.  Even if they are a little pricier than most izakayas I've been to...

Although their location leaves a bit to be desired (the block isn't sketchy, but it's pretty dark/dead), the restaurant itself is a real gem - a well-lit, open patio that gives way to a dark, cozy restaurant space.  While sitting outside would've bee fine, I was stoked that we snagged the last two seats at the counter/bar (there are some tables/booths inside as well).  

As for the menu, it changes fairly regularly, though there are a handful of staples (like the Teba No Karaage) that consistently appear.  The range of offerings is similar to that of other izakayas, but the ingredients/products used are of better quality than most.  More importantly, everything tasted great!

-- INGEN NO KURUMI AE - Dirty Girl French Beans with Rich Walnutty Sauce...$8 (small)
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/izakaya-rintaro-san-francisco?select=JQqoU-v0ki0KfVTLaq3mYw)
For what it's worth - I thought this was "good but not great", yet this was one of my friend's favorites.  The taste of it wasn't bad at all, I just wasn't super high on the nuttiness of the sauce.  While it added a sort of creaminess, it also felt like it was covering up the beans.

-- LIBERTY DUCK SKEWER...$8
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/izakaya-rintaro-san-francisco?select=oSEZzFjp7P_VKOS8uFGjTg)
Tasty, but definitely pricey.  Although the coloring was a little dark, the meat was juicy (the bit of fat and skin on it helped) and full of that luscious, duck flavor.  The only thing missing?  More of the crisped up duck skin.  A great skewer choice, otherwise.

-- CHICKEN BREAST + WASABI SKEWER...$7
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/izakaya-rintaro-san-francisco?select=J13S4YQOVGT7rPtUn-IzZg)
The least interesting part of our meal, though it wasn't bad.  The breast was decently moist, and I liked the kick from the wasabi.  However, it's very basic - lightly seasoned chicken and wasabi.  Given that, despite the dish's lack of flaws, $7 is a bit hefty for just two skewers.

-- GINDARA SUNOMONO - Cucumber and Miso-cured Bolinas Black Cod in Sweet Vinegar with New Ginger...$13
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/izakaya-rintaro-san-francisco?select=E0KGpWNxifOjHA7JorIowA)
Black cod is one of my favorite foods and this one was done really well.  The fish had that wonderful silkiness to it and tasted so good.  What's more, the cucumbers and vinegar added a sweet acidity that complemented the fish quite nicely.  I just wish we had a bigger piece!

-- TEBA NO KARAAGE - Japanese Fried Chicken Wings with Smokey Tare, Sanshio Pepper and Curly Cress...$9 (small)
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/izakaya-rintaro-san-francisco?select=650cn3z4uAwfXRVW6nCSSg)
The one dish we knew we had to get and it didn't disappoint...mostly.  The wings (piping hot and moist) were coated with a light batter that had a terrific crispiness to it.  However, while the overall taste was great, it could have used more of the sauce to enhance the sweet/salty contrast.

-- TEUCHI UDON - Hand-Rolled Udon with Two Fishes Broth, Scallions and Nori (with Hot Spring Egg added)...$9 (+$2)
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/izakaya-rintaro-san-francisco?select=6tV1tb-WaN_ZID4dTDD0bQ)
Simple, but really good.  The noodles had the perfect bite to them and, while not necessary, the egg added a wonderful richness.  Still, the broth was the star - a lot of delicious, subtle flavors yet not a lot of fishiness.  The best udon I've had in SF, though I wouldn't have objected to some tempura.

-- HOJICHA PANNA COTTA - Japanese Roasted Green Tea Panna Cotta with Hojicha Syrup and Sesame Almond Cookies...$9
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/izakaya-rintaro-san-francisco?select=YGnfpb3Dhvh1XGSDRY_s2A)
What a way to end our meal!  As with several of our dishes, the flavors were delicate, but no less robust.  The panna cotta had a strong taste of green tea and the syrup added the perfect amount of sweetness.  Plus, I loved the taste and crunchiness of the cookie.  GET THIS.

While I can see why some would say Izakaya Rintaro's prices are a bit high, only the skewers felt "pricey" to me, as the rest felt somewhat justified.  If you're still concerned though, I might suggest avoiding the skewers and sticking with their specialty dishes.  And the dessert.  Whatever you do, get the dessert!  That alone would be reason enough for me to come back.
author: Mike L.

description: Great foods, very authentic and made with great care and craft!   I enjoyed every dish here....chicken wings are so crispy and delicious with a dark gooey sauce.  Chicken yakitori was flavorful and smokey from grilling. Udon was home made, such a simple fish broth but has layers of mild flavors (they use 3 different types of fish to make the broth). Their home made fresh tofu is delicious and mild, so fresh, it made me think of a place my family used to go to, to get freshly steamed tofu in the morning. This place is a five star dining experience for Japanese cuisine.
author: Issy M.

description: Decent izakaya location in the mission. Fairly pricey for the actually skewers. Nice entrance that was cutesy and allowed for photogenic moments. Overall it was a decent experience, I liked their house tofu and cheese Katsu but the udon was disappointing. We tried ~ten dishes and opted out of dessert because we were so full. Take a look at the pics!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Great ambiance, service, and food! The interior is very warm and welcoming, but at the same time looks pretty sleek. There is a bar where people can sit facing the chefs as well as booths. There's an outdoors courtyard with lights strung across which is pretty and contrasts with the slightly ghetto surroundings haha.

We sat at the bar so we were able to watch one of the chefs prepare dishes. The chef gave us a complimentary sashimi (the one that we didn't order) which was very much appreciated! When he gave us our dishes, he also told us which dip/sauce was which.

We tried the silken tofu, both types of sashimi that they offered that day, the salmon roe rice, chicken karaage, liberty duck skewer, another chicken/onion skewer, and the green tea panna cotta. Honestly, everything tasted amazing, but the standout dishes to me were the silken tofu and the green tea panna cotta. The silken tofu tasted very refreshing and you add sauce to your tasting. I also really enjoyed eating the green tea panna cotta - the sauce that they give you is honey like but not too sweet. Since it's on the side, you can also add however much you want for those who don't like their desserts too sweet! The green tea flavouring was delicious. Definitely will get that dessert again on my next visit.

We also had the sake flight. The waitress told us the order in which we were to drink it, and I really enjoyed the first one. It had some floral overtones and was really smooth. The other two were also quite smooth but definitely didn't have the floral tones like the first one did.

This is a very nice place kind of hidden in a more ghetto area of SF, but definitely worth checking out.
author: Theresa L.

description: Potentially to be my fav restaurant in SF. I love yakitori a lot! Although they don't have that many options for yakitori, but all items are super delicious!! We sat in the courtyard outside of the restaurant, and ordered their seasonal sake, which was rich and fruity. I will definitely visit again but next time, I want to get the bar seats. It feels like a more authentic yakitori experience!!
author: T G.

description:
Rintaro was pretty good.

We went there with a party of five and were seated in the rear section. It was hotter than the Sahara back there and extremely loud. 

We ordered the sashimi platter, a bunch of appetizers, some yakitori, udon, and the beef curry. The sashimi was very good, but they give you a very small portion of wasabi. We ordered another but never received it. The wasabi was awesome. Everything else was pretty good, but nothing stood out. And the portions are quite small.

Dessert was a roasted green tea panna cotta. I normally love panna cotta, but this just wasn't for me. They added a sugar syrup on top, but it was not enough to balance the roasted green tea. 

It looks like the menu rotates, so I'd prolly try it again with just my girlfriend. As long as we didn't get seated in the back section.
author: Michael B.

description:
Cute little gem located on the 14th Street, close to Wag Hotel and Nihon Whiskey Lounge.

My fav dish...

1. Hotate No Sashimi - so fresh so buttery
2. Yakitori - inner thigh
3. Special house dish - Hanetsuki Goyza (off menu)
4. Unique brand of Sake (Hakkaisan was the only one I remembered)

Least fav dish...

1. Yakit0ri - Liv3r and Sh0ulder - bit dry and gamey
2. Ud0n - tasted like the instant one

Note: the online menu is outdated.

They also have a small patio in the front for seating. 

I will definitely come back for more.
author: anita s.

description: Amazing, fresh, and artistic food blending traditional Japanese decor in a modern Bay Area vibe. Definitely repeat business worthy!! Get the teba no karaage, kanpachi collar (like butter!), & kama tama udon. Fresh tofu made in house is also a must.
author: Ed O.

description: This is simply the best Izakaya in the Bay Area... nuf said...
author: David G.

description:
As soon as you walk into this spot feels like you've been transported somewhere in Japan where they turn out primo quality Japanese izakaya.
Everything we tried here was delicious. Fresh house made silky tofu, cheese stuffed chicken katsu, charred albacore tuna sashimi, king trumpet and ribeye skewers, and udon. 
Go and try all the deliciousness they provide.
author: Hyuk L.

description:
What a delightful surprise. Stumbled in here after a yoga class last night, most likely drawn in the the exclusive, intimate feel from the exterior and the welcoming strings of light hanging above the outdoor patio. As a walk-in single diner, I was happy to be seated right away (even at 7pm) at the counter overlooking the open kitchen. Even without the food, it was entertaining enough just to sit there and watch the chefs work - grilling meat skewers over the yakitori flames, breading and dousing whole fishes at the fry station, preparing majestic mounds of duck salad, etc. Additionally, as noted by other Yelpers, all of the design in the restaurant is very visually appealing and modern smart, staying true to its Japanese theme from everything from the wall fixtures to the wooden archway over the bar to the lovely ceramic wares and dishes.

Okay, now onto the food - I had the:

 Hitokuchi Oden - delicious fried fish cakes (ling cod & other)  with daikon and egg in dashi broth

 Yakitori (skewers) of breast & Ume (plum) jam - served with lemons ~ very plump & juicy meat

 Natto donburi - traditional Japanese fermented soybeans (stinky! Try it if you dare :P) over sticky rice with nori papers and with ume and wasabi mustard on the side

 amazing finish with roasted green tea panna cotta (hojicha) served with green tea syrup and two thin almond rice cookies 

Also, service was plentiful and extremely friendly. I can't wait to come back - this is definitely in my top five favorite restaurants in SF!
author: Andy L.

description: First, I will say the food was good. The service on the other hand was poor.  Very poor.  From the outset, our server made us feel very uncomfortable.  She was trying to up sell bottles of sake. She was not listening to us and what WE wanted.  She acted annoyed when we asked for more time. Then she came back with water and spilled a glass on a female member of our party. She acted unconcerned. She offered no advice on our ordering.  She was just unpleasant.  She was downright unfriendly and unprofessional.  It's a darn shame I gave her a 15 percent gratuity.  The right amount would have been 0.  Good food is key to a restaurant's success.  But bad service is a killer.
author: Barbara E.

description: Do not come here without a reservation. I've tried few times and they are always fully booked up and they don't seem to want us to wait. I put down my number and never get a call back. That happened twice.
author: Patty P.

description: Foods are ok but price is a bit too high. Environment is super nice, good for date night or friends get together. Service was good
author: Han-Chyi P.

description:
This is about as authentic a Japanese Izakaya as you will find in America.  My wife is Japanese and we both spent a year living in Japan.  From the understated bamboo fenced entry courtyard to the enka music and greetings of "irrashai", Izakaya Rintaro does not disappoint.

The house made tofu is silken and amazing, shishito peppers sweet with just a hint of heat, the Suzuki (striped bass) sashimi was as good as any I've had at Tsukiji, trumpet mushroom kushiyaki totemo oishii, kani chawanmushi (Dungeness crab egg custard) exquisite, and karaage chicken wings to die for.

My wife had a sake flight (not on the menu but will bring if you ask) and I had the sake "kuzuryu" which was perfect, smooth and elegant.  

Our waitress was attentive, knowledgeable and paced our dishes perfectly.  At an  Izakaya you don't want to be too slow or too fast.

My only suggestion would be to offer the yakitori with spring onions which is how they make it in Japan.  Otherwise, perfect!
author: Michael K.

description:
Zensai sanshu - pretty good, spicy

Yakitori:
Knees:  thigh meat, with bone
Thigh and sansho - kind of a meat. All, it was ok
Breat with seasame - this was alright, kinda bland
Rintaro kisune - spicy and good
Chicken oyster - pretty good
Trumpet mushroom - good

Pork don with mushroom dish - pretty good, different


Overall-  food was good, pacing of dishes on the slow side, would go again
author: Michael E.

description:
Provisional rating after 1 visit. Solid izakaya / yakitori joint, but lack of a killer item keeps it from must-go status for now.

Ordered:

4.5 *
-Iwashi no nanbanzuke - best dish of the night; surprisingly large anchovies, nicely battered and marinated in slightly spicy vinegar marinade.
-Hirame no kobujime - nice gelatinous texture and mild flavor.

4 *
-Bincho maguro no tataki - decently fresh with shiso and vinegar. A bit light on the flavor and I couldn't really taste any effect of the searing.
-King trumpet mushroom skewer - mirin-based sauce, well-grilled

3.5 *
Thigh + sansho skewer - nicely charred, but lacking in charcoal odor relative to other yakitori joints; meat is quite soft, but a little on the bland side, and sansho flavor a bit weak
Natto don - nice, large beans with a bit more fermented flavor (akin to aka-miso); overall, it tastes like nattou you can get in the store, and not sure if it was mixed well enough.
Kama tama udon - nice to see japanese-style pasta with raw egg, but fails in comparison to Momotaro's chili mentaiko spaghetti

3 *
Hanetsuki gyoza - large, meaty fried dumplings with extra fried batter. Almost Chinese-style with strong ginger flavor. I don't think it's worth the money, though.

Miscellaneous notes:
-The shichimi that comes with the skewers is pretty nice; sake list is small but I had a good glass.
-They may have meat that's not on the menu, so if you want a particular cut, you can try asking the server.
-Pretty new joint, so I think they are working out some kinks with the coursing.
-Overall nice ambience, somewhat reminiscent of Ippuku (though perhaps not at that level). We sat at the bar, which is nice, but not the most comfortable (weirdly, most seats were wooden, except a couple which have cushioned seats).
-Easy reservation online a few days in advance (wide open for Thursday night)
-If you're there early, go around the corner to Rainbow to pick up some tea.
author: M N.

description:
I was sad when Chez Spencer closed their door but Izakaya Rintaro is a nice addition to the neighborhood.

Ambiance is warm and inviting but I highly recommend making reservations since seating is rather limited inside.  We came on a Saturday night and it was fairly easy to make reservations just hours ahead of time.

Food wise - everything was tasty and nicely plated but don't be like me and order w/ your eyes.  Like any other Izakaya restaurants, prices adds up quick since you tend to think that you won't get full off of "small" dishes but surprisingly, although portion looks small, you get full pretty easily.

My favorite of the night was their karaage, very moist and tender and the large was a great size to share.  Unfortunately, we were too full to try any of their desserts but we will definitely be back soon!
author: Janetto L.

description:
One of the worst restaurants for service I've ever been too. I can get better service at a dive Chinese restaurant in the sunset. Our server Yuko was forgetful, rude, and slow! 

First Incident: we sat down and order some drinks and potstickers while we waited for our guest to arrive. She wrote down the order, but forgot to put it in. 20 minutes goes by and we asked if our beers were coming and she rudely says "yea yea yea"... beers came 5 minutes later.

Second incident... so our guest arrived few minutes after the beers arrive and we were ready to order. We were ready to order after 10 minutes of going over the menu. Remember this is our first time here. As first time customers at your restaurant, of course we will have questions about your menu and sometimes we will want to change up what we ordered. Yuko was being impatient and gave me this nasty "uhhhhh" noise like she was annoyed. Excuse me, you don't ever do that to a customer. 

Third incident... Yuko came to give our table a pitcher of water. While she dropped off the pitcher to us, she said... "it'll be really busy so I won't be able to fill up your pitcher, but there's a sink right behind your table, you can fill it up yourself there." Really lady? 

Fourth incident... so remember those potstickers I ordered as an appetizer before my guest came: yeah you got it... she forgot those too. I asked another server if they were otw, she said we didn't order any. Yuko comes by while I was talking to the other server and I asked if she put the potstickers in. Again she was rude about it and said "no I forgot" wtf lady. Get your priorities right.

Fifth incident... I asked Yuko for paper napkins, she said rudely "we don't have paper napkins, we only have Japanese napkin." (She points at the moist towel that was given to us while everyone sat down). I point at the paper napkin that was given to me while with my beer... she walks away and grabs a stack of the beverage napkins and just drops it at the table.

Sixth incident... we grab the check from another server bc Yuko was not giving us any attention. We got the check about to pay, Yuko comes running tell us she forgot to add gratuity to the bill. In my mind you don't deserve that 18% percent. But I said fuck it... because we will never come back to this establishment ever again. Some of the shittiest service I've ever received. 

Wait there's more... I ordered a spring mountain egg on my udon... she forgot to put that in my udon too. 

Other than Yuko... the food was good, the other servers were great. But this one star is for you Yuko.
author: Brian P.

description: Such a cool spot. Unpretentious but beautiful space and food. Such a hidden gem. I've been every week since discovering it!
author: Sarah K.

description:
We were invited here by friends and were extremely impressed. The attention to detail and perfection extends to everything here, from the food, to the service staff, to the architecture and craftsmanship of the woodworking in the interior. 

Everything is painstakingly crafted locally and the menu adjusted daily to represent what is in season. I can't imagine anybody not giving this place a full 5 stars. Also, don't miss their house made plum wine.
author: Josh R.

description:
Exceptional little izakaya for a special occasion. Each dish was delicate and precisely executed, from the fresh tofu to the skewers to the to the rich pot of noodles.

A great place to come with a small group where you can sample many things on the menu.

The weather wasn't suitable for eating outside when we were there, but the patio looked like a lovely spot for a sunny early summer evening.
author: Mark R.

description: I came for new years eve dinner and they had a special menu with a lot of different choices from the menu before. So instead I went with their sashimi, chicken truffle katsu (new years eve special), chicken yakitori and the famous gyoza. They were all amazing! I couldn't really taste the truffle in the chicken katsu but other than that, it was an amazing special addition. The service was amazing as well.
author: Omkar K.

description:
Oh was I supposed to grab a protein shake after bootcamp? Too bad. See #HiromiN taught me "recreational goals get recreational gains", so I went #killbillstatus and refueled with fish heads instead, beezys.

You can have deece food here IF you're not too hangry to wait. (My one-person meal ran just under 2 1/2 hours, after which I wasn't full. *see below*) Bring #cardsagainsthumanity and go a few rounds with your friends; it'll help pass the time.

(^_^) Ika (Squid) Tomato Mayo $10 (http://bit.ly/1fm8ddb)
I've been in a torrid affair with early girl tomatoes since forever.

(^_^) Liver $6 (http://bit.ly/1JnF2o8)
Smooth criminal.

(^_^) Dashimaki Tamago (Omelette) $9 (http://bit.ly/1Mzp4rE)
Surprising subtle flavor. #twss Not "just" eggs.

(^_^) Okashira No Shioyaki (Salmon Head) $9 (http://bit.ly/1DZO0Ga)
Fun dinner piece.

(^_^) Heart $6 (http://bit.ly/1gSWfZE)
I heart hearts.

(^_^) Gizzard $6 (http://bit.ly/1Nfz9dm)
Not rubbery.

(^_^) Sokosuica (Watermelon) Granita $7 (http://bit.ly/1TR8Ez9)
By the grill for hours; I needed to chill out.

(^_^) Thigh + Scallion $7 (http://bit.ly/1JdL9Fm)
Tender thighs get the guys. And girls.

(^_^) Straws $0 (http://bit.ly/1NpH0Eq)
Paper red x white striped. #hyeah

(-_^) Liberty Duck $8 (http://bit.ly/1TPzIto)
Standard duck.

Why not more stars? Because I'm not the world's biggest fan of sporadic 20-30 min waits between courses. I've been to izakayas of comparable quality that were just as packed and had just as many (or fewer) kitchen staff but churned out the dishes. I'd intended to try a few more items but decided to stop ordering since I started at opening time, dined for nearly 2 1/2 hours, and didn't feel like staying till / past closing.

P.S. Please bring boiled peanuts back to the menu.
author: Dan B.

description:
Ok I hate to say it, this is my favorite spot for Japanese food in SF right now.  And there's a lot of other folks who agree because it's now gotten harder to get a table here! 

If you want sushi, ramen, or teriyaki chicken, this isn't the place for you.  But if you want an interesting experience with delicately prepared flavorful Japanese food, this is heaven.

My favorite is the curry but I might be alone on that because it isn't on the menu all the time.  It's just a really robust flavor and they serve it with a raita. I originally thought, how strange, but now I'm in love.  I order two bowls when I come.  No sharing.  When it's on the menu I'm there.  When it's not on the menu...well, I still am there.

Tamago sounds like it's oh just some ho hum egg.  Well sure you can think that because that's what I thought, but no.  It's silky and rich but yet light.  I don't know what they do but it's great.  But honestly, it's the neatest thing watching them cook it.  You should sit at the counter and watch him make it.

Other notables.  Hmmm.

Yakitori sticks - okra and duck are my fav. but other ones I think are good: chicken oysters, meatballs, thigh and onion.  They do all sorts of parts of the chicken.   But the duck....they serve it with yuzukosho.  I went out and bought a bottle of that stuff (spicy yuzu paste). So good.

Tonkatsu - man they make it good.  They do it layered style.  The tonkatsu sauce is a little dark, but it'll work.

Chicken and cheese katsu - not as good for me, but mostly cuz i like my katsu without cheese!

Wings - they are enjoyable.  Small portion but it's good. It's not out of the world wings but it's good (and I don't like wings, so that does mean something)

Fried shrimp croquette - I don't like shrimp but have been told it's quite good.

Fish - I don't like fish but i have gone with many folks who say the fish is out of this world.  it's simple preparation but get the whole fish apparently.  And it looks like they cook it in a little toaster.  But whatever they do, it's supposedly really good.  Even I'm tempted to try it sometimes, but then i remember I don't care for fish.

Udon - they seem to really like making the udon but honestly it's good.  Just good.  Soup is great, flavor is awesome, noodles are nice but for me, Udon is udon is udon.  Their zaru (cold) udon was really good though.  I felt that the freshness of the noodles came out more there than in the hot udon.

Matsutake rice bowl - so simple. Sounds so boring.  But it was delicate and flavorful all at the same time. I could have eaten the whole thing by myself.

Mochi dessert - they run out but the one time I caught it in time it was great. It was a mochi ice cream dessert and looked nothing like I thought - it was a flat layer of mochi and a cube sized ice cream.  Really good.

Or you could head a few doors down to Nihon Whiskey lounge for liquid dessert.

Reservations online - they added a credit card for reservations now. I think the counter is first come first served.  Best spots in the house because you get to see how things are made!

All major credit cards are cool. Bathroom in the back.  Parking blows. Uber. Or you can park towards Best Buy on Harrison sometimes.
author: Traci H.

description: Very disappointed about the poke bowl. The tuna was not fresh. Everything was either too salty or has no flavor.
author: Emma Z.

description: The place is private and good for couples. Nice decor and ambience, but the food, in my opinion, is mediocre. I would only recommend the grilled knee cap and the tofu. Do not even try the rice. The chef put the Ikura on top of a bowl of HOT rice, making the fish roe tastes gross. Ew. Nearly throw up after eating it. In a word, I wouldn't come here again.
author: Annabelle L.

description: We were a walk in - and they accommodated my wife, 14 month old and I graciously.  The food and service were both great. Highly recommend both the sashimi and croquettes!
author: Uri L.

description: Yakitori is delish here! Haven't tried their ramen yet, but heard it's really good. Very small place, there's usually a line so recommend to call and make reservations beforehand.
author: Rose T.

description:
Rapture.

Not sure what that means to you, but to this Yelper it's a straightahead glorious meal at Rintaro.

Um, like, Wow.
