It's hard to describe rapture in specifics, now isn't it? It's more an overall impression lingering in the memory and the senses ... perhaps for days. And, no, this is not a reference to some psycho-delic-flashback-euphoria.

So here goes. 

Some kind of drink that involved cucumbers. It was so smooth ... like silk, I think. But a hint of sweet. Savory chicken meatballs. Firm, fresh sashimi, a pinkish delight. Grilled chicken ... and mushrooms ... and I can't tell which is more savory. 

Silken tofu that just can not be tofu - I mean, that stuff comes in a brick floating in ancient industrial water, right? This creamy, rich bowl of lovely can't be from even the same food group.

A. Whole. Fish. Trout. Salted. Absolutely. Perfectly. Cooked.

I always wanted an excuse to write one of those phrases with a period after each word.

Finally ... hand-made udon. We had 2 different styles. Then ordered another bowl.

Ingredients were all fresh, and perfectly cooked and seasoned. The environment is warm, welcoming, and down-to-earth. Wait staff are pleasant, understated, and appear and disappear at just the right time.

Bliss. Culinary delight. Happiness.

Rapture.
author: Jon M.

description: Love the dessert here! The hojicha panna cotta is fantastic! So is the matcha ice cream because it's made with soybean milk! That was a nice surprise! The teishoku (Japanese meal sets) are delicious, especially all the pickled Japanese vegetables that came with it. I had the wagyu curry one. The karaage chicken wings were delicious too and came with an interesting arugula/shiso leaf hybrid. Anywho, they can be hit or miss sometimes with some of the dinner menu items so I can't justifiably give them the 5th star. For example, I was really excited about their hot pot from my second to last visit, but was underwhelmed. Haven't been back for a while until today when we brought a friend from out of town for lunch. Additionally they're pretty pricey for what they serve. I do enjoy the quality of the food nonetheless and the drinks selection. TL;DR - I recommend going here for authentic Japanese food if you're not worried about price.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Service was great, really attentive and everything we ordered was delicious. Perfect date-night spot. Went there for our anniversary and loved it. They even had champagne ready as we got there. Thank you Rintaro team!
author: Fiorella B.

description: If you are visiting San Francisco and have only one meal, make it Rintaro. It's very tucked away, but when you walk through the doors, you feel like you've actually entered a legitimate Izakaya. I tried 10-15 things off the menu and had a TON of regrets because I couldn't fit another 10-15 inside my person. The food was incredible (especially the bukkake udon) and the experience was even better. Go here. What are you doing reading this. You're wasting time. Go there now. Now.
author: Charlie R.

description:
Most amazing Japanese dining experience ever. 

Just imagine being in Japan but you're actually nestled in Mission down the street from the hood. It's such an incredible atmosphere that they have created.

Have dined here twice, both times have been an eye opening experience. Somewhat Jiro-esque but not quite. The amount of care they place on the food, despite large orders and they truly explain the dishes quite well.

NOT a sushi place. This is a far-cry from a 'sushi joint' and embodies what it would be like to dine in rural Japan with flair. The whole set-up from the moment you step foot off the Mission district into this quaint beautifully decorated eccentric little restaurant makes you feel like you are straight up in Japan. The waitress ushered us to the table with the typical Japanese outcry of "hello" and sat us down in the back (I have also had the pleasure of dining at the bar which is quite fun despite the hard and uncomfortable seating on barstools). 

The open-kitchen is inspiring to watch, especially the sushi chef who places care into the food much like Jiro-san would have in that Netflix documentary that now makes me think I am an expert in the field. But honestly though, I saw him place tiny sprigs of some flower-herb that I wish I could remember (it was pink) on top of our pieces of sushi and they were so incredibly flavorful and exciting to have it on top of the sushi. Quite the experience.

I order like it's my last meal here. 

Make reservations. This place gets packed quickly! Or go right when they open and grab a bar seat.
author: David T.

description: Amazing place with nice atmosphere, delicious food, wonderful service, great location! Love it! Scallops sashimi probably too pricy as for me, but the rest of food - no comments: great! We took different stuff and it was great!
author: Alisha M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. It looks like a great spot from the outside. It looks super popular; it was overpriced and service sucked. Service was pretty poor for a place here. 

It was a pretty popular so you'd think they'd have more servers to help out. We didn't get service for 5-10 minutes after we sat down. We didn't get napkins until I stopped a waitress after we GOT food to get them. It should be pretty simple to note that we didn't get napkins (or really towels) when they were getting our order. It's not super complicated. 

The drink we both ended up getting was a delicious cucumber type drink - made with shoju I think. We ordered a few yakitori and an udon to share. We had 3 types (rintaro tsukune, thigh and onion, and chicken oyster). I think the rintaro tsukune and chicken oyster were the most delicious. The thigh was good. I'd suggest getting a few of these to share. We got udon to share - we wanted the special one, but they didn't have anymore. This one had an egg that came with it. It was cooked in the sauce all together. Definitely different and pretty good to share together. 

Overall, the food was good, but honestly, with that kind of service, I'd rather not come back. I can find good yakitori elsewhere with much better service. 

Protip: just go yourself. I don't think I'll be going back.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I came here for the first time tonight and started in their old-style Peko-Peko pop up.  We had a beer, chicken meat balls, and salmon wrapped in a Persimmon (?) leaf.  All that was great - and a good start to our meal.  The courtyard was small and cute, and suitable for this type of event and good for those waiting for a table inside.

The inside of the restaurant is beautiful - simple in some ways, but lots of details in others.  My friend and I sat at the bar, and we had fun eating and watching everyone in the kitchen cooking.

Here's what we had:
- Kumkuat Champagne cocktail
- Sake flight
- Maguro
- Small Dashi Maki Tamago (exceptionally good - one of my favorites. Somehow they made a normal almost-always overlooked item into a hit)
- Yakitori items: Chicken gizzard, liver, kneecap, thigh meat
- Teuchi Udon (another favorite - the udon must be house-made.  I definitely will come back to order this)
- Hojicha Panna Cotta (again, I loved this dish. It has such a nice green tea flavor in both the panna cotta and the syrup that you pour over it. The panna cotta also had a great texture, and this dish is not overly sweet)

Overall this meal for the two of us set us back $120 before tip AND excluding what we ate in the courtyard.  The bill would have been much higher if I brought my husband.  It's not a big meal, but if you want some good izakaya food that is good across the board, make this a special treat.  OR you can grab and drink and snack here, rather than a meal, to bring down the cost - but it's definitely worth a stop.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Great quality of food. After ordering our food everything came out rather quick and well timed. The table didn't get full and we were able to really enjoy each dish before the next one came out. 

The sake that we selected with the help of our server was a perfect compliment to the meal.

The quality of the ingredients really shows up in how the food tastes and feels. It all had great flavors and had plenty to eat but didn't feel like we over ate. 
We ended up sitting in the back which was quieter and the server looked after us- the rest of the place has a lot of ambience and a few different places to try sitting. Indoors and outside, bar and the quite back room. 
Looking forward to coming back.
author: L T.

description: They messaged me after seeing my review, and did what they could to make the situation better. I'm going to increase my star rating, but I'm leaving my original review (since good or bad it was my experience).
author: Thomas F.

description: Every dish is well thought through. Flavorful with balance. Great authentic Japanese place with friendly waitress and delicate food. A little pricy but well worth it.
author: John H.

description:
Impromptu craving for an izakaya and some yakitori - check!

We walked in on a Saturday evening just as they opened. We were offered a table that was available until a reservation 1.5 hours later, which was completely fine.

Our party of four ordered a significant fraction of the menu (I estimate 50-60% of the menu), and we were not disappointed. The yakitori was well done and while I never quite imagined myself being in Japan, despite the excellent ambience, I was more than satisfied with the izakaya vibe. I would really like to come back here and have a rerun in one of the booths with some more time on my hands.

The sake offerings were excellent. Their home-made plum wine also hit the spot. It is served with sparkling wine or by itself on the rocks; we ordered both and preferred the undiluted version.

One of our favourite dishes, despite our intended homage to carnivorism, was actually the salad with apples. The natural flavours and seasonings really worked fantastically well together, and it was an unexpected and truly refreshing counterpoint to the skewers.

The service was excellent throughout, with just the right proportions of attention and lack of interruption.

Even though we (shamefully) overshot our 1.5-hour allowance, by ~15 minutes, we did not feel rushed to leave. Indeed, I hope I can return soon!
author: Seán O.

description: I thought the food was okay. It is not as good as I had hoped it would be. It is definitely not bad and and the place had a nice vibe. Probably will not be back as there are so many other good restaurants to try in SF!
author: Krysten N.

description: the experience here was exquisite. we came here to celebrate a birthday and had such a good time.  the service was super attentive and friendly. we sampled a number of dishes including fish (i.e. scallop), duck salad, pot stickers, udon and tofu. When we were done we had their version of cheese cake. We started the meal with some of their signature drinks.  Add in a vibrant ambiance and some good music and it made for a great dining experience.
author: Steven D.

description: Amazing Izakaya. Great vibe. Great beers, sakes. Chicken thigh skewers and karaage were the best I've had.
author: Eric C.

description:
I went to Izakaya Rintaro last night with a reservation at 7PM. It was more quiet when I first got there, but it soon filled up quickly and people who walked in were told that the next available table would be at 9PM or later, so definitely get a reservation to be on the safe side! 
The restaurant is cozy and dim with an open kitchen, which was very interesting to watch while I ate. I ordered:
Yosedofu: meh
Rintaro Tsukune: amazing
Chicken Kneecap: interesting, but wouldn't order again
King Trumpet: amazing
Karage: good
Korroke: amazing
Kama Tama Udon: good

The service was pretty good, our waitress was very kind and explained some items on the menu. Overall I had a great experience, and would definitely come again!
author: Shirley C.

description:
Fantastic service!

Unfortunately the food does not live up the the hype. Not worth the prices and not all that special.

Decor is really cool and transports you to another country for sure. Even walking into the front courtyard from the street is an experience.

Sad the food doesn't match whatever Bon Appetite said....
author: Taylor S.

description: I really enjoyed my udon lunch set! All of the tasty, pickled vegetables were a refreshing introduction accompaniment to the meal. The udon noodles tasted freshly made onsite, and the broth complimented the meal overall. I was full and satisfied from my meal and service was pleasant and attentive to the right level.
author: Maile N.

description:
TL;DR - What a fun place to be!

-FEELS-
Dark but still fun! If you dine here, definitely sit at the counter!

-FOOD-
ORDER ALL THE SKEWERS! jkjk, but seriously, you can't go wrong with any of the skewers. We ordered one order of each and the only one I found slightly off putting was the liver because it was slightly overcooked.
Also, the curry was really good!

All the drinks are pretty solid but "light" on alcohol (I'm a manhattan or old fashioned type of girl though) but tasty!

Yes, definitely a great gem in the mission for really yummy japanese skewers!
author: Crystal Z.

description:
Food was fine but I couldn't enjoy the experience because they put us in the back room even though we had reservations. A big part of eating and drinking out versus drinking at home is to experience the ambiance and the backroom was definitely not even close to the full experience. No music, no windows, no decor, hard surfaces, lots of echoes, listening to everyone else's conversations in uncomfortable detail. Felt like we were sitting in a garage. Honestly I think it's a little dishonest to even put people back there and charge full price. I would rather wait an hour than to sit there again.

I asked a couple times to move up but the hostess refused. Said free round of drinks on our next visit but there's too many restaurants in SF to visit a place like this twice. Later she said dessert was on the house but they charged us anyway.

But really don't remember anything special about the food or sake. It was just okay.
author: Russel H.

description:
Inexpensive.
Yummy.
Super friendly.
I totally agree it's one of the best Izakaya place in bay area.
Can't wait to go back.
Always packed, so better make reservation first.
Location doesn't feel safe, better Uber or drive there.
author: Rabbitar N.

description: Lovely ambience and lovely food! Only downsides are that it can be hard to get a table. Also, they don't have much selection for vegetarians.
author: Urban S.

description:
Loved this place - food was great, staff was amazing, space was beautiful. Also you can come on Thursday for the pop up venue and enjoy a drink with some Japanese street food-like snacks (we didn't try it in fear of ruining our appetite for the main event)! Can't wait to come back and hope you get to try this exquisite place.

As a note, we ordered a lot of food for two people and easily got to $150-$200 dinner ticket.  So if you're on a budget, you should probably be a bit mindful of what you order ... But if not on a budget, I would go to town and order everything that sounds delicious to you because it most likely will be one of your favorite meals in SF. 

This is a sampling of what we ordered and would highly recommend coming here:

- Yosedofu - mmmm delicious. Homemade silky tofu with delicate toppings

- half quail yakitori - I could have ate more than just one - perfectly grilled and seasoned that will make your mouth and stomach yearn for more

- trumpet mushroom yakitori - yummy mushrooms!

- some sort of vegetable salad with duck and pluqot - very good and you'll just have to see my photo of this because I'm forgetting the name of this dish

- fried chicken (kaarage) - this was Soo good my friend and I could have easily gone through two orders of this
 
- carbonara udon - the noodles were great and we should have probably slurped up the egg afterwards but forgot to (or wasn't sure if we should have) ... Flavor may have been a bit lacking here or needed a little bit of salt

- kake udon with tempura fried onions in fish broth soup - good  balance between crunch and slurp... Delicious and may have preferred this over the carbonara 

SKIP The red eye tuna sashimi - was ok, but probably would not order this again only because the other food is more fun and fantastic to eat ... And why spend $17 on this when you can get it at another restaurant...

Lastly, you really should have beers with your food. It washes down and pairs so well with everything that it heightens the food tasting experience at Izakaya Rintaro! 

Happy eating!
author: Susan L.

description:
Wonderful place!

I came here on a weekend with one of my very god friends, hoping to score some solid Japanese food on the Mission.

And boy, were we in for a treat! My friend and I ordered several dishes and we ended up spending around $45 each after tax and tip.

We began with Yosedofu, which we split into separate bowls. The Yosedofu was very well made, and had the consistency of what I imagine to be one of the sweet tofu dishes I had back when I loved street food in China.

In addition, we had Tamago. It was a good dish, although I kind of thought we would've gotten the tamago as a sashimi (so the egg would be over some rice). Delicious anyway.

We also ordered Chizu Katsu, which translated to fried chicken and cheese. Don't be fooled by this seemingly American-style dish! It was very delicious and completely worth it.

We couldn't leave here without trying the Yakitori. Rintaro makes amazing Yakitori- we ordered Liver, Skin, and Thigh + Onion. My favorite, by far, was the skin. It was decadent, delicious, and amazing. You get two skewers per order to split between you and a friend.

Finally, we left after a bowl of udon in a delicious soup. The visit was very satisfying, and I would recommend this place to anyone who likes (or even doesn't like) Japanese food.
author: Anders Z.

description: Make sure you RSVP! We waited so long to be seated that we lost appetite and we're a little off-set in our experience because we saw free tables. Portion size is relatively small, but the taste on food is well done. Their yakitori and chicken wings is probably my highest recommendation here. Very friendly staffs as well
author: Guy H.

description:
The food is amazing. Especially the desserts. Service was good in the beginning but started to fall apart at the end. 
We ordered a second round of food, but someone brought us our check before the food even arrived. No one asked if we wanted dessert. I had to aggressively tell our server.
Looks like they get lots of reservations, so unless this is an unplanned visit, call ahead or visit as soon as they open to avoid long waiting times.
author: Tracy S.

description:
amazing interior + exterior with decent Japanese food. 
Shochu cocktails were just okay.

8 sold out items on the menu at 8pm. 
I couldn't eat anything I wanted and this happened 2nd time.
I wonder if they were way too busy that night or just didn't prepare enough?  
whichever the reason, I won't be back.
author: Nao N.

description:
Must update my review after my most recent visit!
Since I wasn't very impressed with their yakitori, we didn't order any skewers this time. The service was better and food came out at a good pace (unlike last time). I think that's why our experience is much better this time. Arrived ten min early for our dinner reservation. There were 5-6 people standing by the hostess when we arrived. I guess they didn't have reservations bc we were seated immediately after checking in with the hostess. 

What we had:
Haru no NUTA- refreshing salad of turnips, asparagus, turnip greens, and spring onions with the perfect balance of mustard and wasabi flavors; reminds me of the wasabi potato salad at Delica (which is one of my favorite salads)
Megami MAGURO- good texture sashimi, served with cilantro flowers
Hanatsuki GYOZA- Berkshire pork with chicken foot jelly and 'wings', wow I loved this and could eat so many!! You could taste the freshness of the ingredients and the outside is a little crispy but they were super juicy inside... Almost like xlb soup dumplings. Who would've thought gyoza could be this good?!
Kabocha KAROKKE- curry, kabocha and potato croquettes. Fried perfectly with Acme bread crumbs and not greasy at all. Just the right about of curry flavor in the croquette. It's like eating tonkatsu curry without having to have saucy curry and meat. 
ODEN- we chose simmered daikon, grilled/fried meiji tofu, fish cake with tuna; tasty, cooked in flavorful broth
NATTO DON- natto over rice served with umeboshi and toasted nori; I normally do not like natto, but this one wasn't bad. I even ate a few bites. The natto was less strongly/slimey than others and the toasted nori made it taste even better. The rice I thought could be better tho
Teuchi UDON with spring egg- handpulled udon cooked in two fish broth, green onion and nori; ordered this after seeing chef Sylvan make the udon while we were eating. So glad we tried it. Texture was harder/chewy, similar to tsukemen noodles and the broth is very flavorful, also very good with the remnants of the spring egg
Suiyoubi no neko BEER- light beer in a cute can

Every item we had was delicious. The only thing I'd point out is the 5 piece maguro sashimi was $18 which I would not get again. But I'm not a fan of tuna either sooo.... 

Overall, this is easily my go-to izakaya if I lived closer and I would take out-of-town friends and family to for reliable good food and experience. I recommend anyone to get their CROQUETTES, GYOZAS, and reservations when they dine here. I've had their trout and potato croquettes and they were also amazzzing. Their menu changes so you could come back for different croquettes and maybe even gyozas. I'd just stay away from yakitori and sashimi (over-priced and not their best items IMO).

I saw chef Sylvan work with mochi last time and saw him hand-roll udon this time. Lucky me! He even came by to give us fresh kumquats after and I LOVE kumquats. We had no room for dessert, but the kumquats were perfect, something small, sweet and tart to end our meal.
author: Iris H.

description:
I really really wanted to like Rintaro, and I was really looking forward to dining there, but many of their dishes were a hit or a miss. First of all, the environment is adorable. You walk through a cute outdoor space that's reminiscent of Japan, and they have a cool chef's counter, booths that look like Tokyo and a back room. The waiters are super friendly and the service is overall, very welcoming. 

I tried the tamago, shumai, gyoza, skewers, and the udon. Possibly my favorite dish was the perfect, flavorful tamago. I wasn't crazy about the shumai or the gyoza, while the skewers and the udon were good but not amazing. Considering the fairly high price point, I'm not sure if I could recommend Rintaro when there are so many great places in the city.
author: Kate M.

description: We had a wonderful cozy brunch at this authentic Japanese izakaya with delicious food. We can tell the ingredients were fresh and of high quality. Will return for sure.
author: G C.

description: We had to wait for an hour although we made a reservation. Besides that, it is a cute spot and the food was great. Freshly made udon was pretty good but the sauce was meh. I would defiantly come back for the fried chicken and sashimi patter though.
author: Tiffany O.

description: High-quality food, but really high prices for really small portions. I ordered a sushi platter for the table, for $65, and it literally came with 14 small pieces of sushi, not even enough for one person. If you're not that hungry and don't mind spending lots of money, it's not a bad choice.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Ambiance: 4.5/5
Value: 2.5/5

This place is where Chez Spencer used to be. I like that the venue is not very loud and with the booths, you feel like there's plenty of privacy. We actually chose to sit at the bar so we can watch the cooks do their magic. 

All the grilled skewers here are chicken (but strangely, no chicken skin). We ordered the gizzard, the thigh with scallion, the oysters and meatballs. The skewers were anywhere from $6 to $8 per pair. The gizzards were my favorite and the hubby loved the oysters. Overall, the meat is tender and flavorful.

We also got the fried chicken stuffed with cheese, the pork shumai, and the egg omelette. The chicken katsu was crispy and not greasy tasting. I felt like the cheese was unnecessary because it's a very mild cheese so I couldn't really taste it that much. The egg was great, simple and full of umami. The standout was the shumai -- I love the young ginger and the pork was so tender and studded with just the right amount of fat. I think that's a must order.

The place is pretty pricey and they don't offer any option for "fillers" such as any starch  aside from porridge. Definitely not a place to go if you're really hungry. The quality of the food is good, but still, the ingredient is pretty pedestrian to warrant this type of prices.
author: Alice W.

description: This is for the cooking class held at Rintaro with Chef Cocco from Japan. The team worked hard for the attendees to enjoy a nice lunch after a two hour class. We learned many formal Japanese dishes and the multi course lunch was absolutely fabulous. Dubious that I'd be able to replicate the meal but happy to have been able to watch the chef at work and enjoy the fruits of their labor.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Expensive but tasty. Enjoyed the yakitori here more than some of the places I went to in Tokyo recently. The udon was also fantastic. Highly recommend.
author: Ian W.

description: This might be my favorite Japanese restaurant!!! Everything is so goooooood! Me and my friend just keep wondering how can they make the chick beast and the rib so juicy!!! Also the house make ume lemon juice? I thing that's the name hahahhaha. I like it.
author: Jamie D.

description:
Most things on the menu are nonexistent, especially ones shown on Yelp photos here. 

Food is extremely slow to come. Prepare to spend 2 hours get two skewers..

Food quality is ok - nothing exceptional.

As always, everything is overhyped af in SF - and this place is a prime example for that. Don't risk your cat getting towed just to try this place, not worth it.
author: Derek P.

description: Come here for really small, overpriced portions. The food is decent, especially the yakitori, tamago and udon. But was really put off by how small the plates were.
author: Chelsea W.

description: This place is good.  Yakitori is outstanding.  The katsu wasn't the best I have ever had but still good.  We had the udon carbonara, while it was delicious I still thought it fell flat because of lack of seasoning.  Beautiful restaurant and food.  Highly recommended.  Dont skip the hot green tea, but watch out they serve it nearly boiling.  Delicious. 4 stars.
author: Ducky M.

description: I stopped in for dinner here a little over a month ago looking for some Japanese food inspiration.  My husband and I were immediately impressed with the beautiful decor, certainly something that reminded us of izakaya houses we had been to previously in the US and Japan. We ordered the tsukune and chicken thigh + onion yakitori, kamo no menchi katsu, gyoza, and kake udon.  I was most impressed by the kake udon since finding good udon in San Francisco is like looking for a unicorn.  The best tasting dish we had was the kamo no menchi katsu.  The breaded and fried duck was delicious and almost decadent in taste.  The only drawback to our experience was that service was mediocre.  We were stuffed into the back room corner that was dimly lit and infrequently visited by servers.  The order of our food was also strange and a little disorganized, but also very slow. The front of the restaurant by the yakitori grill seemed to be a much more lively and exciting area to sit.  In any case, I'd come back with a bigger group to try more of the menu.
author: Lisa I.

description: I'm over paying $100 p.p to sit at tiny, lopsided table crammed into an area so small that the waiters can't fit between the tables and I can feel the breath of my neighbor as he coughs. The food is great but tiny dishes so the owners have a real cheek charging this much in what is a cafe experience at best. For $100 bucks I want some linen, some polished glasses and decent sized portion and some space between me and the next dinner. This isn't New York!
author: Sally S.

description:
I feel like I've been starting every review lately with "FINALLY got to try..." but my recent visit to Rintaro was one of my most anticipated meals of the year. If you haven't heard of it or paid a visit, you must, especially if you love Japanese food as much as I do. Rintaro now takes the crown for me for best Japanese restaurant in the city. 

Firstly, I highly recommend making a reservation through Resy (go to their site and you'll see how). They do require a card, and a hefty $25 if you cancel after a certain time before your reservation, but hey - I can appreciate - if you're not committed and considerate, they probably don't want your business :P. In terms of seating options, I also recommend the Chef's counter so that you can watch the cooking and prep. This is always my favorite seat in any restaurant, although, if you're coming with more than 2 people, the tables are a better (and still great) option. 

The food is high quality and delicious. We ordered a bit from every part of the menu - some chicken meatball yakitori, the large cod (not as large as you'd think, it was easily demolished between two people), halibut sashimi, steelhead roe don buri, and the fried chicken wings. What I loved about the food was that as soon as I would claim "THIS" was my favorite dish, the next would come and I would be equally (and happily) torn about it being my new favorite. A tip - if you're sharing any of the don buri's, ask for another small bowl. One of my pet peeves is eating rice from a plate. Our server made great recommendations, and I am already excited about my next visit so I can try more (silken tofu!). 

And the ambiance.... perfection. If you've been to Japan, you'll know and can related to what I'm talking about. It's the kind of place you'll probably pass 10 times and not know it exists but serendipitous-ly, I passed by it on my way home from Rainbow one day and decided to explore. 

Oh, try the fermented plum sparkling wine drink - it's super sweet (get as dessert), but they age those suckers for 8 months!! O.O
author: Corrina S.

description:
They do a good job creating a very cool and elegant Japanese izakaya ambiance.  The menu is interesting, and everything is thoughtfully prepared.   

Unfortunately, nothing we ordered ended up being super special. We ordered some kushiyaki (skewers), udon and mapo tofu.  Everything tasted just decent enough.  The pricing is a tad expensive for what you get.

This is for people who want a Californian twist on izakaya.  If you're looking for authenticity, you should look elsewhere.
author: Judy H.

description: Rintaro was kind enough to send us back here again with a credit. Everything on the menu was available. We enjoyed our Saturday night dinner. Will come back soon and hope to see new things on the menu. Thanks again Rintaro for the classy gesture.
author: Ethan A.

description: One of the Best Love in San Francisco to try fish! :) it's a great place to get and enjoy your dinner. They have a beautiful comfy patio. Deep fried items are the way to go here, yakitori, sashimi and other cooked items are nicely average. Such a lovely place with delicious & fresh fish bowl.
author: Jones B.

description:
Me: "SO, are we going to have date night tonight?"
Mr. NSS: "You're going to make me go out like THIS?!?!" 
(He was all bandaged up from surgery the day before.)

Me: "Yah, why not? You'll probably get more attention than Kim K.'s oily, 'i can fry a dozen eggs on dat' photshopped ass on Paper Magazine."
Mr. NSS: "Ugh, what would we be eating?"

Me: "Izakaya." 
Mr. NSS: "They have yakitori--gizzards?"

Me: "Yup, they do."
Mr. NSS *mumbles*: "The sh*t I have to deal with dating a yelper."

Me: "Excuse me?"
Mr. NSS: "Nothing, dear...when are we leaving?"

I'm such a sneaky bastardette because I knew Japanese food would be an easy sell...especially since yakitori is one of his weaknesses. Muahaaahaaa.

Softly opening on Monday, November 10th, Rintaro took over the Chez Spencer location. Currently, there's no reservations. It's first come, first serve. Even before they opened at 5:30 pm, there was a line so come early. 

Rintaro serves izakaya, Japanese tapas. Compared to other izakaya restaurants I've been to, Rintaro's menu is smaller and more focused: http://bit.ly/1sIfHaQ. Usually, the rule of thumb is to order about 3-4 dishes per a person and then a finisher like a bowl of ramen or don (they only have don, rice bowls on the menu). The alkie menu is pretty limited with just two beers and three sake/shochu options (my beer was $10.50 a bottle!). It's not cheap here; our bill for two including tip was $176. =X

~ * ~ F O O D ~ * ~
*Complimentary Boiled Peanuts: http://bit.ly/1BgJfFN
*Hanetsuki Gyoza: Berkshire Pork Gyoza (6 for $12): http://bit.ly/1u5Oa63
*Yakitori Chef's Choice: Tsukune, Thigh, Thigh w/ onion, Gizzard, Wing & Mushroom ($15.50): http://bit.ly/1sIgtUj
*Yakitori: Skin & Gizzard ($6, $5.50): http://bit.ly/1xBnbSn
*Yakitori: Liberty Duck ($6): http://bit.ly/1xBnooE
*Kare No Karaage: Crispy Fried Sole ($22): http://bit.ly/1EGfkp1
*Keihan: Rice w/ chicken broth, chicken breast, shiso & egg ($6.50): http://bit.ly/1v8cDe4 
*Santa Barbara Uni Donburi (off the menu - $8): http://bit.ly/1yCrWJQ
*Kaki Yonashi Kanten: Persimmon & Wine-Poached Pear Jelly w/ vanilla ice cream & brown sugar reduction ($8.75): http://bit.ly/1sIhA6u

As with any newly opened restaurant, there are bound to be kinks so it was nice that they provided complimentary boiled peanuts (sweet and savory) for us to nosh on while we waited for our order. 

It's rare to find housemade gyoza on the menu, and Rintaro's rendition didn't disappoint. The thick skin had a toothsome chew with a nice, crispy browned bottom, and the pork filling was juicy and flavorful. However, the wrapper broke apart when picking up with chopsticks and the filling fell out of the gyoza.

The highlight of their izakaya menu are their yakitori skewers. Every yakitori we had was uber tender, subtly smoky, and lightly seasoned with tare (soy basting sauce) or shio (salt). Mr. NSS' loved the gizzards so much that we ordered two additional orders. 

The best bang for your buck is the kare no karaage: crispy fried sole which is served whole and you can eat everything including the bones. Forget your chopsticks and use your hands to break apart the crunchy fish with tender flesh. We really enjoyed this dish as it was satisfying and not greasy at all. Great frying technique. 

The dishes we were most excited about were the most disappointing dishes of the night. The uni don (off the menu because it's limited) was basically one slab of uni over a bowl of rice served alongside strips of nori and soy. While the uni was deliciously sweet and briny, the rice was dry and hard, and not palatable. For $8, it would have been nice to elevate the don like with an onsen tamago (Japanese hot spring egg). The keihan didn't fare any better. It was like a bland chicken porridge. 

Dessert did redeem the disappointing finishers. The persimmon and pear jelly were refreshing with concentrated flavors that was prominent yet subtle. Loved the vanilla ice cream which I showered with the brown sugar reduction. 

~ * ~ S E R V I C E ~ * ~
The staff was nice and polite but it was confusing because it didn't seem like they had assigned tables. One staff took our order but then others took our additional orders. If you're in a time crunch, I suggest that you tell them to bring everything as they're ready. Otherwise, they will stagger your order and won't fire up something unless you're done with a particular course.

One thing that left a sour taste in my mouth was as we were leaving, we passed by several of the staff including the hostess and no one bothered to say, "bye" or thank us for coming. 

~ * ~ A M B I A N C E / D E C O R ~ * ~
My gf and I celebrated our birthdays at Chez Spencer and the new space was unrecognizable; clean, zen, and with lots of light natural woods. There's 3 two-tops, five booths, and 12-13 seats at the counter with a front view to the open kitchen. There's also one lonely table in the front courtyard.

~ * ~ P A R K I N G ~ * ~
Semi-difficult street parking.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
We came in on a Thursday night around 7pm, and were able to sit at the counter. It was great to sit at the counter and watch the talent in the kitchen, but they do take reservations if you want to guarantee a table.

The atmosphere...incredible. It starts with the walk in. It's beautiful and calming. Their greeting is authentic, and the service from staff friendly.

The food. Whoa. I went with my friend that is originally from Japan, so I let her order for us. Here's what we had:

Silken Tofu
Yakitori - Meatballs + Thigh and Onion 
Oden
Gyoza
Tamago
Panna Cotta

All 5+ stars!! So good. The Oden was great, but just wasn't my thing. Although, I loved the egg in it. Each dish, flavorful, fresh, and artistically presented. They take a ton of pride in their food. I could see it in each dish being made while we watched them from the counter.
author: Amy O.

description: This place is adorable, loved the interior decor and ambiance of the restaurant, kind of made me feel like I was in Japan. It's right next to Nihon Whiskey Lounge, which great if you want to grab drinks before or after your meal. We sat at the bar and ordered a bunch of skewers and sashimi. Overall the food and service were great, the only negative is that it's pretty pricey and all of the small plates really add up in the end. If you're willing to splurge it's worth a trip over.
author: Angela K.

description:
Foodwise, this is a solid 4 star restaurant. Standouts are their homemade tofu, undon and the chicken skewers. Most other menu items are pretty good. Exceptions are the whole fried fish and donburi. Donburi is just so so and bland. Fish was awful. It was the most expensive item on the menu and when it came out it was fried so crisp, the meat had shriveled away to nothing and you were left with bone and super oily crust. 

Service-wise, this place is neutral to sucky on most nights. Thus the three-star rating. I've been here at least 4-5 times and each time (last 3 times within the last 6 months), the service leaves a little more to be desired. Once we left without sitting because after making a reservation, showing up on time, waiting for 20 more minutes, they offered us a table right by the door where other people waiting were congregated. We would have had people's butts in our face the entire time we're dining. When we pointed to a quieter table in the corner that was also available, they said they were going to squeeze three people into that so, no, not for us (party of 2). During our most recent visit, we showed up on time, hostess tells me it will be a few minutes. I see couple of booths ready and set up. I ask if we can get one of those (as we've always been taken to the back room where it's less pleasant in our prior visits). She looks at me and says it will be 5 minutes (for no good apparent reason). I say ok. We stand around the hostess station and awkwardly avoid eye contact with the hostess until 5 minutes is over and she sits us down. WTF... 

So in conclusion, this is a good enough place to go with good friends. I would never take anyone I need to impress as the service level is not there. I like the food and the ambiance enough that I've gone back multiple times, but with each episode, I question whether it's worth going back. I really hope they improve service. Then I'll be there every week!
author: Liz K.

description: Food is delicious.  The ice cream dessert is divine.  yum.
author: Andi G.

description:
Great meal in a gorgeous space with a nice vibe. 

The service really stood out from the moment we arrived. I was ten minutes early on a Saturday. In my experience this usually implies I will wait until at least 7:15 to be seated. But the hostess kept me posted on the status of the existing diners and we were seated before five past. The servers were attentive and helpful without being intrusive throughout the evening. Even the chefs we were lucky enough to have a front and center view of from the counter were happy to answer our many questions and offer advice on how to choose from the many great menu options. 

The food is available izakaya style and intended for sharing so you are able to enjoy a variety even if there are just two of you. Every dish we had was great. Definitely try at least a couple of skewers. I wish we could have had more but will just have to be back. The shoulder was really outstanding. 

Do be aware it's helpful to have a sense of how to use chopsticks. I assume they will provide a fork if you need to ask, but this type of food is worth learning to use chopsticks for if you don't already know. 

I had the sake flight and highly recommend that as well. Each was delicious but very different. It was a nice way to experience the breadth of the beverage without having to think very hard about my choice. I just wish they had an Omakase menu option so I could have done the same with the food!

Finally, the space is incredible. The architecture is worth taking in and appreciating before you get too absorbed in the food. I also appreciated how lively but casual it was. 

My kind of place. I'll be back.
author: Jessica H.

description: Overpriced mediocrity. Nothing justifies going to Izakaya Rintaro given the great food San Francisco has to offer. Sure, the atmosphere is great, the plates look beautiful, and the staff is nice, but the food will ultimately let you down. Those small quantities of street food wannabe are priced around $18 a plate in average, and you'll need several to get satisfied. Nothing really stood out of the 8 dishes we tried aside from the fried sole and its unpredictable sometimes eatable bones and sometimes not.
author: Ben L.

description: Amazing food clearly cooked with heart and soul. The atmosphere is lovely and authentic. Menu changes seasonally (daily?) and I have been here in both summer and winter and each time the menu choices matched the season. Food is melt in your mouth good and affordable. Small plates meant to be shared, amazing cocktails that compliment the food perfectly. Service is impeccable, both times the staff have been friendly and helpful in menu choices. For a special occasion or just a good meal, go.
author: Amylynn F.

description:
gyoza- 5 medium sizes pieces, decorated on top with a layer of crispy flaky batter, comes with tasty vinegar/chili/sesame sauce. 

egg noodle dish - soft boiled yolk 

iced tea- not too heavy or light. quite good! cute peppermint straw.

nice clean airy space.

bar - in front of the bartender
chefs counter - it's a bar in front of the cooks
dining area - each table seats 4-6 ppl


overall nice experience.

i'm more for spicy food, but if you ask for more of their mirin/soyu/vinegar/chili/sesame/garlic sauce it will go well with the other dishes!
author: Jeff K.

description: Had lunch here (teishoku sets), rather than the dinner. Food was delicious and very authentic, some of the best katsu I've had and comparable to what I've eaten at nice katsu restaurants in Japan. Not cheap but IMO worth the money.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Absolutely love this spot!! 

I've been here twice in the last two weeks. We can't get enough of the food and the vibes and apparently we're not the only ones. This place is always packed! Definitely make reservations ahead of time.

Highlights:
- homemade tofu - we got the yuzu flavor
- tonkatsu w/ cheese - delicious and perfectly breaded
- homemade udon - love the texture, the sonoma duck breast was a little overdone, so don't let it sit in the pot too long!
- yakitori - good and apparently they've already changed from what they use to serve


On Thursday nights there is the cutest okonomiyaki pop-up!! And the okonomiyaki is super legit too. Just as good as the kind you find in Japan ;)
author: Kristen C.

description:
Overpriced, hyped place. The interior is beautiful and the host is nice but food is just ok and extremely overpriced. On the menu "Vegetable" we ordered cucumber & crab salad for $18 and the dish was a tiny palm size. Some cucumbers with about 3 tsp crab meat for $18. We don't mind paying $$$ for good quality food but really? Tiny cucumber salad for $18?

Chicken thigh yakitori was good. Was not a big fan of chicken oyster yakitori which had quite strong meat/iron smell & taste. Chicken katsu was ok. 
Maybe if you don't know much about Asian food, you might like this place but I was very disappointed with the mediocre food being extremely pricey. You are basically overpaying for their nice and zen feel like interior. We drove all the way from Berkeley on Sat. Also, this was my 2nd time here hoping the 2nd time will be better experience but no, I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Arum K.

description:
I went here with my sisters and it was packed!  Thank goodness we had reservations because I overheard them turning people away and suggesting other places to eat nearby!

I loved everything - our meal, the atmosphere, and the service.  Everything about the restaurant is so cute- they have tiny dishes for everything and it's seriously so adorable.  They even provide a separate container for used skewers which is so thoughtful, but that's not a common thing at other places.  Between courses, our table was cleaned and tidied which I appreciated (not that we were dirty, but there were lots of little dishes) :) my favorite items were the yosedofu (tofu), gizzard and thigh skewers, keihan, and teuchi udon.  I would go back for more in an instant!
author: Liz C.

description:
I actually enjoyed my visit quite a bit. We sat at the bar pretty close to opening time, and I had a mini panic attack when they were laying down the charcoal and it got really hot for about 2 minutes. But that went away, and I was really glad to watch them cook. 

We started with the scallop sashimi, which was incredible. The skewers were of course delicious. We got the chicken meatballs, empire duck, and the fish cake. I think next time I would skip the fish cake, and order the duck again! The boyfriend really enjoyed the chicken, and it's their mainstay. 

We also had the cooked whole fish. I would eat that every single day. So light, moist, and the perfect temperature for a dinner serving of fish. I think if I were to go back, I'd just get the fish and 5-6 duck skewers, haha.
author: JoyAh B.

description:
I agree on the pricey-ness of this place. And I believe that the money is spent on the ambience (which is perfect for yakitori) but steals away from the food which isn't unordinary yakitori. 
If the prices were lower, this would be a smash hit, as they got their foods and feel down.
author: Andy L.

description: Went with a party of 4.  I have a soy allergy (the worst kind for this restaurant), but the staff and chefs were super accommodating.  I was able to have a delicious meal and didn't feel I was missing out.  The rest of my party raved about the Udon, the Yudofu and the Teba No Karaage, and several skewers.  Everything was delicious. The location had a great atmosphere as well.  Just added to the deliciousness. Will definitely be going back.
author: Stacey S.

description: Food was good but not great.  However, it was very expensive for the offerings.  The skewers are mediocre for $9-$12 for 2 tiny offerings.  The service was solid but lacked personality.  Felt like a trendy pick and place to be seen but I would like great food for my money.
author: Rachael G.

description: Unusual, adventurous (by American standards) Japanese fare. Not your garden variety Sushi joint (not a sushi bar). My waitress made a few suggestions and all were winners. Constructive criticism: the Robata selection was mostly chicken. How about some beef and fish?
author: Dr. B.

description:
Izakaya Rintaro's a cool place for some izakaya in the mission. Two friends and I came in and immediately started off with some skewers. There was a small assortment of skewer choices and we had fun picking and choosing what to eat. We ended up getting chicken heart, chicken gizzard, liberty duck breast, and thigh+scallion. All were absolutely delicious. 

There were a couple other dishes thrown in including this fish karaage dish. Personally I would have preferred chicken wings as those would have been both cheaper and possibly more delicious, but the fish wasn't bad. I will highly recommend getting dessert here though- we shared the hojicha and it was amazing. It was like a green tea pudding with layers and I really wish I had gotten one for myself instead of sharing it with two friends.
author: Philip W.

description:
Recently named #6 on Bon Appetit's list of hottest new restaurants in the US, Rintaro lives up to the hype. This isn't your standard Japanese restaurant (no California rolls here!); instead, Rintaro offers a small/medium-sized menu with delicious and high-quality food.

I enjoyed my dishes:
- Chicken Karaage: very delicious sauce and crispy skin!
- Udon noodles: they make the noodles in house and you can really tell! They're the perfect consistency...highly recommend getting one of these dishes (there are 2 options, both in broth)
- Green beans: these come in a walnutty sauce that is just delicious! My favorite dish of the evening, I could have just done with a couple bowls of this
- Shumai: made of a mixture of pork, scallops, and shrimp. Tasted average, but I liked how the outer shell was made of rice as opposed to a traditional dumpling-like wanton. Unfortunately, this item was one of the more overpriced on the menu ($15 for 3 teeny tiny dumplings!)
- Silken tofu (one of the house dishes): the tofu was impossibly soft, so much so that the consistency was reminiscent of a soft creamy cheese (like the inside of burrata). I couldn't take more than a few bites but appreciated the dish for its uniqueness
- Green tea: refilled for free without my having to ask, wahoo!

Highly recommend trying this place out with a few friends so you can order family style and try as many unique dishes as possible! One note: the food does take some time to come out, so the length of the meal ends up taking a bit longer than the usual dinner.
author: Neha S.

description: I don't know how this place could get such high rating. Their skewer is so so and pricy. There are so many places in SF you could get better skewer. Other small plates are even worse. We tried vegetable with black cod which is 18 dollars. It is super small and tastes weird and not fresh. Also the udon, over 10 dollars for a tiny bowl. They say it is homemade udon, but who cares if the taste is just the same as those in fast food japanese restaurants. I would say Nijiya's udon is more tasty than here. This restaurant is pretty and service is good. But food quality?
author: Li D.

description:
I usually don't like noodles and such, but Rintaro has the best Udon noodles I've ever had. The atmosphere is very authentic and staff is very attentive and genuine.
We went there for a birthday dinner and all the small plates, to udon are fresh and excellent.
Chef Rintaro came out and was making fresh noodles in front of us. I went up to talk to him and he was very friendly and nice. He found out that it was my brother in law's birthday and sent us some sweet goodies at the end of the meal.
Amazing food, without any air of pretentiousness. 
One of my most favourite places in the city.
author: Valerie T.

description:
Don't believe the hype! Over-priced like whoa. You pay more for atmosphere than anything here - so yeah, the space is cool. Food? Meh. 

Don't even bother with the edamame for a snack. $7 and you get a couple stalks with tiny little soy beans - most were not matured on the order we got. Pass on the skewers too - I felt robbed with how little food you get. Same goes for all of the other dishes we tried.

Despite having great atmosphere, being with great friends, and ordering a bunch of food, this place was a serious let-down for everyone and left us unsatisfied to the point of needing to go get a second dinner afterwards. Fail.
author: Andrew N.

description:
I came across this restaurant on Yelp after my search for somewhere hot and new for a date night. You will first walk into a dimly lit courtyard with picnic benches filled with customers enjoying their meals. In the main dining area, there were booth and table seating, but the best part is the open kitchen where you are able to see all the cooking and prep action going down. My bf and I were seated in another dining area in the back and away from the main kitchen action. It was secluded, had a side decorative kitchen area, but I probably would have preferred to be in the main dining area because the ambience of an izakaya felt so authentic there. 
Five stars for ambience and decor. 
Now on to the food, the menu offers a good variety of items. My bf and I were on somewhat of a paleo diet, so this review on food will be very protein focused. 
We ordered the albacore tuna sashimi. One of my favorites - it was so smooth and delicious. Our second order was Yakitori - chicken thigh and onion. This was also very good. I am one to enjoy a bit of crisp on the edges and this dish hit the spot. Then we had the Teba No Karaage - Japanese Fried Chicken with a smoky Tare. The chicken was prepped and fried very well! 
Finally, we shared the Rainbow Trout Lrg. If you're looking for a no frills, clean dish, this is the one to get. 
We were still a bit hungry, so we ordered more Yakitori - another order of the chicken thigh and onion, and this time also the chicken oyster. We should have gotten the chicken oyster sooner! The best part of the chicken we have had yet! Dark meat, and again, cooked with a nice crisp around the chicken and it was delicious. 
Five stars for food. 
We ordered a flight of sake - Tedorigawa Kinka, Hakkaisan (my favorite, smooth and not too fruity) and the Shichi Yan Hori. A great trio if you're not too familiar with the different sake families and looking to try all. I would say they were generous pours.
author: Jenelle L.

description:
You should go there only if you don't care about the service "at all". 

#Service: 1*
## Experience with reservation and getting seated (-1 star)

- First of all, what's up with that "we only accept reservations if you give us your credit card number on a site that does not even have a secure connection unlike any other website that asks your credit card number"? I had to make reservation so gave it away but seriously, I still regret doing it and probably will until I see a fraud on my card and have to cancel it. If you are going to ask for the credit card, (1) first do it the right way, and (2) make sure that reservation works. This leads me to the next item....

- Like mentioned above, even after giving my credit card number, I went there 15 minutes earlier and the lady at the door politely asked me to come back in 15 minutes (because that's when my reservation was at). Alright that's acceptable. We did come back in 15 minutes and guess what? Still waited 25 minutes to get seated for a party of 2. Oh, and of course, they first asked if the counter is okay. It's NOT okay because that would mean you took my credit card number for no reason. Geez. 

## Experience with ordering and getting the food (- 1 star)

- We waited I guess about another 15 minutes for someone to take our order. He was a super nice guy though. 

- We ordered a bunch of stuff and the first dish that came to our table, was not something we ordered. They apologized and took it away from us. 

- They brought the wrong Udon which we also sent away.

- They forgot our Okra Yakitori that we asked at the end of our meal, and our waiter was surprised to hear that we did not get it yet. He apologized, went back inside. Then came back saying that he is so sorry because they ran out of okras. Geez(*2)

I don't think I can experience more fails than this at one time

#Food: 5*

Boy everything was good and delicious. 
- Yakitoris (inner thigh, oyster chicken, some others): 5*
- Carbonara Udon: 4*
- Gyoza: 5* (could have been 4* but got 1 more star because of the creative presentation)
- Katsu: 5*
- Green Tea Panna Cotta: 5*
- Sake: 5*  

Overall, this is one of the few places that I will be back after giving 3 stars but I will seriously only go if that's an occasion that I don't care about the service.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
Went last night for the first time and had a great experience... the ambiance and food are top-notch. The service was fine (nothing to rave about), but the menu is amazing. Tons of unique items you'd be hard-pressed to find elsewhere. I highly recommend the hand-pulled udon, seafood dumplings, and yellowtail sashimi! 

Just a side-note - the menu on their site was different from the one in the restaurant, so it seems like they may change it up a bit and aren't great about keeping it up-to-date online.

Only con is that this makes for a fairly pricey dinner - with tax & tip it ended up being around $60 per person.
author: Lily N.

description: I've been to Rintaro three times now and it continues to deliver the best Japanese izakaya experience in the city. I'd recommend sitting at the chef's table (aka the bar) if you have two people or a booth for a larger group. All of the dishes are thoughtful and well sourced. My latest experience was with their set lunch menu, which offers one main dish, a miso soup, and four small side dishes. It is a huge portion of food and served in a wonderfully calm environment. Highly recommended!
author: K J.

description: On my second visit to Rintaro, I understand what all the hoopla is about.  The hirame no kobujime was tasty and beautifully presented, and the Half Moon Bay wasabi added a unique local twist.  The house-made silken tofu was velvety, fresh and delicious.   All the yakitori skewers were on-point -- I especially liked the liver and duck, and the hand-rolled udon was the perfect texture.   We were almost too stuffed to get dessert, but we're glad we didn't skip because the hojicha panna cotta was certainly a highlight.  Deceptively simple yet refined, the juxtaposition of the two tea flavors in the roasted green tea panna cotta and the hojicha syrup proved a sublime finish to a memorable meal.
author: Crystal O.

description:
I hate to be the bearer of bad news but Izakaya Rintaro was such a disappointment. I made a reservation two weeks in advance and I was so excited to try it out. The photos on Yelp are stunning and the space is beautiful in person as well.

The problem, unfortunately, is the food. Considering that the restaurant is an izakaya and you must order a lot of dishes to feel full, I really thought the menu should've been larger. We felt like we ran out of things we can order. 

On the yakitori list, we ordered gizzard and thighs with scallions. Both items were good (not great) but neither were worth the $6-$7 price tag. The meal went downhill from there. The natto gohan was extremely bland and unappetizing. The chicken katsu with wagon wheel cheese was nothing special. The cucumbers in the sunomono were under-marinated and the black cod was fishy. The agedashi tofu was average at best.

Don't get me wrong - I can appreciate subtle and delicate flavors. But what Rintaro delivers is a real lack of flavor.
author: Yi Z.

description: Best of the best! I usually don't write reviews, but this one is definitely a must-try! Love the skewer, especially heart and liver.. and chicken karaage too!
author: Zhang Y.

description: Great atmosphere, like Japanese tapas.  A few Japanese beers to choose from, as well.  I had the shungiku and duck salad, which was outstanding!
author: Geno W.

description: We had a great meal at Rintaro last night. A great menu of Japanese soul food. A taste of Japan in the mission. We enjoyed smooth sake and cocktails, excellent yakitori especially the liver, lovely chrysanthemum salad with kumquats and delicious fried chicken wings. Green tea Pannacotta to top it all off. Great place, nice vibe, excellent service. Not cheap, $140 for 2 with tip. But highly recommend. We'll be back.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Wonderful little gem. The izakaya is tucked in behind a cool fence and offers a fun outdoor dining space for good weather use. The inside is beautiful, with exposed wood beams and the feel of being inside the Skelton of an upside down ship. 

The service was great. Staff was super attentive and helpful with all the different menu options, including a well edited sale menu. 

Food was delicious. The sashimi set was beautiful in presentation and delicious. Onion blossoms and fresh shiso leaf were a tasty addition. Ponzu was also fantastic. 

Chicken oysters were perfectly grilled and the anchovies in spicy vinegar sauce should not be missed. Cold udon with umami broth was a great way to finish.

Awesome place.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Hadn't heard of this restaurant or really been in the area before, but saw it on Yelp and decided to try it last night.  The place is tucked in a kinda odd location, but there was a decent amount of street parking around.  The restaurant had a really nice atmosphere inside, and the service was great.

Between the two of us, we had:
- Chicken heart skewers (5/5) - as good as it sounds
- Chicken thigh and scallion skewers (4/5) - the scallions are especially good
- Chicken oyster skewers (4/5) - flavorful dark meat
- Duck skewers (3/5) - really spicy, but not as good as the chicken skewers
- Shrimp and cucumber appetizer (3/5) - not too exciting
- Kurobuta shumai (4/5) - this really isn't a shumai.  Instead, it's a Chinese "lion's head" pork meatball covered with a layer of rice.  Still really tasty.
- Fried oysters (4/5) - big oysters fried with perfectly crispy breading
- Keihan (5/5) - a deep, intense chicken broth with rice.  My girlfriend was absolutely obsessed with this dish.

Unfortunately, they were out of chicken skin and chicken tail already, so we didn't get to try those.  But the food was really good, so we'll definitely be coming back here again
author: Simon L.

description: They have some surprisingly interesting and good food for an Izakaya, especially some delicious and interesting cuts of meat for skewers. And some fun variety options that really make the meal enjoyable. I'm not normally an Izakaya fan but I would definitely go back to Rintaro.
author: Amjad S.

description: Truly one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco. Very cozy and welcoming, every dish perfectly done - the skewers were a favorite.
author: Barry S.

description:
Walking in, you'd never guess that this place has as many accolades as it does.  It's set back from the sidewalk in a part of town that's less than glamorous, but don't let that throw you: it'll be one of the best Japanese dining experiences you'll ever have.  No wonder this place (and its chef) has received "best" awards by numerous critics, media, and average folks like me.  Everything is cooked to perfection, and the sashimi is the freshest and most flavorful around.  The vibe is low-key and cozy, and the service is friendly and fantastic.  We sat at the counter and enjoyed watching the different people do their assigned tasks of grilling, frying, slicing, skewering, and plating so gracefully -- all the while smiling and making conversation and ensuring that we were being attended to.  
Things to try: the skewers (we had meatballs, gizzards, and livers -- amazing), whole fried sole, yellowtail and tuna sashimi, housemade tofu, and housemade udon.  The sake flight was also delicious, thanks to our server's recommendation, as was the green tea panna cotta.  
There are a still a ton of dinner options that we wanted to try but are saving for next time; until then, we can't wait to come back and see what lunch is like.  Either way, I know we won't be disappointed.
author: Carlo A.

description:
Really cute design up front, but what a big difference in the back room... 

I made reservations to check this spot out and was so awed by the front room that has a beautiful bar right in front of the kitchen and booths set up that looks like you stepped into a noodle shop in the Japanese countryside. 

It was a huge disappointment to be seated in the back, where it looked like an afterthought and a rather dingy kind of decor.  It's like night and day.  The service seemed slower too, and we were forgotten several times.  (Missed an order, took several courses before an empty plate was taken away, slow on beverage refills...)  

The food was generally good, but like some other reviewers noted, really hit or miss.  The mizuna duck salad was so overloaded with dressing, that I couldn't finish it, even though it was tasty,  Just very overwhelming saltiness from the tamari base. 

We got a bunch of assorted yakitori, which totally hit the spot and were SO delicious!!! 

The udon was good, but other than a denser noodle, it didn't taste any different from any other casual noodle spot. 

I was really excited to try this place out, but was, unfortunately, underwhelmed.
author: Annie W.

description: Interesting meat bits for the grilled skewers. The tofu was kinda bland, didn't really taste the flavour in it and chicken karaage was decent. The cocktails were great and well balanced. The sakura sour was quite tasty, refreshing, and strong enough. Seating is great for conversations but wouldn't come here with a group larger than four and will definitely need a reservation, otherwise I could imagine you waiting for quite a bit. We nabbed one the same day and on a friday but your luck could vary.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I love love love this place! The interior was beautiful with lots of wood and a big open kitchen where you can see the chefs hard at work. Friendly and super attentive staff. But omg the food. I have been wanting to try rintaro for months now but it's definitely hard to get a reservation here. Anyways the food. My group of three had ordered almost the whole menu and I gotta say everything was presented beautifully, rustic japanese. And taste wise almost everything I had was amazing. Definitely get the bukkake udon!!!
I love halu and sozai. And now rintaro is joining their ranks! Arigato very much to the rintaro staff! I had a blast!
author: Kelly T.

description:
Rintaro has the potential to be a 4 star, but on this particular occasion, it just didn't get there. 

I had a friend visiting from LA so naturally I thought "Ah a willing guinea pig to try out a new restaurant. Excellent!"

Every place I called either didn't have space or didn't take reservations, but Rintaro said they always reserve some space at the bar for walk ins. Since we were eating dinner on the early side (6:30pm) on a weeknight, I figured this was fine. 

On the night of, my friend arrived early, seated himself at the bar, and ordered a cocktail while he waited for me. Apparently, the hostess made it a point to come over several times to let him know that he wouldn't get a table since he didn't make a reservation. That, understandably, made him a little uncomfortable. 

When I arrived, the space next to him opened up at the bar, so I sat down and voila - we were seated. No drama at all!  I immediately noticed that the decor was very cute and well done, as others have mentioned. Other than the hostess shaming us for not having a reservation, the rest of the service was actually excellent. We asked our server for recommendations and generally went with them. Dishes were:

Duck Yakitori - The two pieces were on the smaller side, but they were tender and tasty. 
Whole trout - Good sized portion of fish. Fresh and tasty, but we both wished the skin had been cooked a little longer.
Chicken Karaage - Very crispy as karaage should be. Lots of flavor, but I actually found it to be oversalted. The lime slices were cut too thin that we couldn't actually squeeze them without getting juice everywhere. 
Roe over rice with shiso - This dish was like making your own roe handroll. Very tasty if you like roe and handrolls. 

Overall we enjoyed the meal (the bottle of sake might've helped). The reasons for not receiving a higher rating are:
1) There were ants coming from the flowers on the table. The ants were crawling onto the plates with our dishes! I had to watch the plates like a hawk and flick the ants off. This made the whole situation less appetizing. I'm pretty sure this is a health code violation. 
2) The price was a bit on the expensive side for the experience that we got.
author: Janet Z.

description:
I rarely write 1 star review, but the service here was beyond atrocious. We were a little hungry and craving skewers. When we arrived the greeter ignored us and upon asking to be put down on the wait list, she said something about how she doesn't know if she can put us on the list because there might not be enough time. This was 8pm on a Saturday. They close at 11pm. The couple in front of us arrived only minutes before and has their names put down and were seated while we were waiting to hear back about even putting our names down.

I've never had any restaurant refuse to take down names 3 hours before closing, if they turn out to be that busy and we won't be called, that's fine, that's normal behavior. But refusing to even let us put our names down when other people are allowed to is obviously discriminatory.
author: Emma T.

description: Food was good - the gyozas were presented well, and the skewers were generally pretty tasty. However, the service was a bit slow, and the atmosphere was a bit too loud. Reminds me of Ipukku at Berkeley which I think is better.
author: Sean G.

description: Love the wings and good customer service. There are less choices in this restaurant but it totally worth coming just to have some good wings
author: Polly T.

description:
I haven't been to many izakaya joints but wanted to check out a few spots before my trip to Japan; preparing my palette for the real deal :)  

We came here for my wife's birthday dinner. I found this place on Yelp and thought it was fairly new since it only had 175 reviews. Come to find out, it opened over a year ago, which means - some of the pictures on here are of dishes that are no longer available. We were sad! ... but I digress. 

This place definitely deserves more reviews! All the dishes we ordered were phenomenal. Here's the list-

- Dunguness crab and cucumber 
- Homemade silken tofu 
- Big eyed tuna sashimi
- Yakitori chicken thigh and onion
- Pork gyoza
- Housemade udon noodles

If we weren't so full, we probably would have ordered a few more dishes and end the night with their green tea panna cotta. Unfortunately, we were near unconsciousness from over-devouring so we will be back!
author: Patricia T.

description:
Overall a disappointing experience. Rintaro has potential, but has a ways to go. 

I must preface by saying this review is strictly based off my experience on Valentine's Day's prix fixe menu. I included each course in my review, but skip to the bottom for the gist. 

I was excited when Mr. Rintaro posted a special V-Day menu on Instagram just a few days before. 8 courses for $75/person, not bad. 

Upon arrival, the place looks great. From the wooden gateway with their Rintaro stamp logo signage, to the dim lit outdoor rock garden seating area, into the open and bustling kitchen space with bar seating, high ceilings, and traditional style booths in the main room. Of course, my 7:15 reservation landed me in the back room, what looks like a converted storage space that they've decorated with some flower branches, so we didn't get to enjoy the beautiful space and its ambiance, but that's fine, I'm looking forward to the food.

:: The Menu :: 

Drinks: Sake flight ($26): 3 beautiful glass cups: 1) Hakkaisan (junmai). 2) Izumo Fuji (junmai). 3) Kinka (daiginjo). The Kinka was my favorite. Also got a cup of hot tea, served in a small tea cup, no teapot included. (Note: not one time did any server come by to refill my tea). 

1st course: Radishes with miso & nut paste. The 2 pieces of sliced radish (long leafy stems in tact) was served with 3 sliced carrots (one slice w/ its carrot top in tact) and 2 pieces of endive. The carrots were roughly chopped, and with the stems and carrot tops in tact, it looked sloppy together on the long rectangular plate. Didn't eat the long radish stems or carrot tops. 

2nd: Dashimaki tamago. 1 piece per person. Decent job with the rolled egg, a fluffy bite and a classic Japanese menu item. 

3rd: Night smelt and nori tempura w/ matcha salt. 3 pieces of smelt tempura each, and 1 nori piece of tempura each. Fried decently, with a dab of matcha salt on the side. (Note: the tempura came out of order on the menu, and when we said to the server we haven't had our sashimi yet, the server seemed a little annoyed, took it back, only to have another lady bring the tempura back to us saying, "the sashimi takes a little bit longer". Ok? And we didn't ask to send it back, just an observation that it came out of order. Next.)

4th: California bluefin tuna w/ Half Moon Bay Wasabi & Kushi oysters w/ dashi gelee. 2 pieces of tuna sashimi each, 1 oyster each. The quality of the tuna was there, but it doesn't come with enough wasabi, definitely not enough to taste on all 4 slices of tuna. The oyster with dashi gelee were just ok, it tasted like they could have been sitting out for a while. Kushis are small and we only got 1 each. 

5th: BN Ranch New York steak, Liberty duck breast and king trumpets. This dish wasn't what they originally posted on the menu. The duck breast was supposed to be served with hand-rolled udon. I guess the udon wasn't ready, and so they combined the duck with the steak and served it side by side dressed with some baby greens in between. The best part of the dish were the seasoned king trumpet mushrooms sitting under the duck breasts. The steak was medium-to-well, on the chewy side, and pretty hacked up slices. 3 small slices of steak each with some minced daikon to go with it. Duck was also a bit chewy, 1 slice each. Probably the most underwhelming dish of the night since it was the main course, wasn't what they advertised, and it didn't really make sense put together. 

6th: Quinalt Nation Steelhead roe over rice w/ shiso. So this was the last course before dessert and it's a lot of white rice and a lot of roe, and a shiso leaf.  The roe was good, and the white rice did fill me up for the time being. Still couldn't help but feel underwhelmed again at this point. 

7th: Chocolate almond cake w/ candied rose petals. Baked in the shape of a madeline, 2 pieces each, and 1 rose petal each, served with powdered sugar. Technically a cake, but not the kind you eat with a fork. 2 chocolate madelines for dessert. A disappointing finale. 

Wrap up:

I came in a follower of Rintaro and Peko Peko. Their presentation & aesthetics are so well done and it gives you the impression that they've got it down. Leaving the dinner, I gotta say I was really disappointed and unimpressed. A lot of the food was just ok, and not one course stood out. The menu was a mish-mash of uninspired dishes. Definitely not the caliber of food to justify the price. The service was friendly, although a bit slow and still learning as they go. 

To be fair, Rintaro is still new to the game, and this was a one-off menu. On the flipside, this was supposed to be a special prix fixe menu for an eventful evening. Don't advertise a special menu if you're going to serve us mediocre, uninspired food, for a higher price no less (w/tip around $250). It only raises more questions about the caliber of Rintaro's food in general. If only they'd shine with their cooking, as they do with their appearance. Step it up, Rintaro!
author: Dave H.

description:
Amazing Izakaya experience. This place is tucked away and hard to find but it is a well kept secret worth seeking.

As you're walking in, you can tell this place is already special from its elegant landscape outside. The inside feels warm and intimate. 

Food wise, all the items came out well. I recommend the smelt, tamago, and the yakitori (oyster and the chicken+scallions were great). The croquette were nice too. 

Drinks wise, the blood orange sochu came out beautifully.
author: Victor W.

description: Super authentic izakaya! Make sure you get seats at the bar. Food recommendations: skip the tomago (it's just a plain egg omelet), definitely get the duck skewer and chicken wings. Mushroom skewer and udon were good, chicken hearts were ehh. The couple next to us got the grilled salmon head and they told us it was great, will definitely get one of their grilled fish entrees next time. House sake was also a big winner!!
author: Shabnam E.

description: Fresh food from scratch, cooked the minute you order. Rintaro is in a league of its own. If you haven't tried it yet, you're missing out.
author: Gilbey G.

description: After I left my previous poor review harping on bad service, I was contacted by the manager who apologized and insisted that I return. I recently went back and enjoyed my time. Atmosphere is great, nice variety of food (liver skewers = yum), service was improved, and Coedo beer is tasty. Only complaint is that by 8pm on a Friday, their skewer selection was somewhat depleted. Will definitely be back though.
author: Robyn B.

description:
The day after my birthday, I made plans to meet my cousin for some wings at Dr. Teeth. Instead, he mentioned about going somewhere that he had bookmarked on Yelp, which led us here. I didn't know much about this place and when walking to Izakaya Rintaro, we tried to figure out exactly where it was. Going through what seemed like a mystery door, we walked into a small Japanese garden and saw the lights coming from Izakaya. I already knew I was going to like it.

We walked in and was greeted by all the staff. I literally felt like I stepped in a restaurant off a side street on the outskirts of Tokyo. There were a good amount of people there and were able to sit at the bar. I ordered some sake and we ordered a bunch of items:

Yosedofu (freshly made silken tofu) - Good, but I'm not use to this type of tofu and thought it was a bit much.
Hanetsuki Gyoza - Pretty good and made fresh.
Tenders with Wasabi and Chicken Skin (on the house) Skewers - I really liked the tenders. The chicken skin was surprisingly good and I can't say no to free. Some other customers ordered this and for whatever reason, didn't want it so the chef asked us if we wanted it.
Halibut Shashimi - This was probably my favorite. 

I really enjoyed sitting at the bar and watching everyone in the kitchen making food. I wouldn't come on an empty stomach unless you plan on spending a lot of money. After all, these are mainly tapa style plates. Great service and good, fresh food.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Of the similar styled places we've been to in SF, this is the best one we've found so far.
