They organize their menu into what are essentially courses, with a few selections for each course, and they are served per the course order too, e.g. sashimi, gyoza, yakitori, fried, noodles. So hint of the day is: if you're ordering, say one tonkatsu and one noodle, for a party of two who want to eat the "main course" (i.e. tonkatsu/noodles) at the same time, you need to tell the wait staff, otherwise, they'll come out one after the other.

We really liked the chicken yakitori -- cooked just right, not too salty, like many places, and good flavor, and the gyoza are a must-have; really delicious. Aforementioned tonkatsu and udon were good too.
author: Bruce C.

description: Izakaya Rintaro is more than amazing Japanese food served in the same vein as tapas. It is from beginning to end a complete dining experience.
author: Jon R.

description:
I saw a spider and I'm so scared :(

Twice in school I forget which I was in class and I also saw a spider during learning.

Take a lesson from this review. I'm very proud.
author: Nik S.

description: Good food, if they haven't run out of things. Bad service.  I really wanted to like this place, BUT they were out of the sashimi dish that I wanted and the ice cream.  They forgot the appetizer we ordered and we had to ask for it twice before it came.  Were never asked if we wanted anything to drink and was hard to get a waiters attention for anything.  Bummer.  Might be worth going once just to try the food, but it's not up to par with other restaurants in the area that have good food and good service.
author: Manal Y.

description:
Love:
- Lovely setting - both inside and outside
- Chicken oyster skewer
- Knee cap skewer
- Fried chicken wings
- Liberty duck skewer

Like:
- Hand pulled udon

OK:
- Tofu hotpot
- Whole rock cod braised in ginger soy sauce
author: Michelle W.

description:
Went for the first (and last) time for lunch with a colleague today, mainly because it's around the corner from the job and Japanese food is pretty rare around here at noontime. The lunch menu is very small but the dish descriptions made it sound varied and delicious. I don't remember the name of the dish I ordered but it was basically a sashimi bowl over rice for $25 and a $4 glass of ice tea. What arrived was about a buck and a half worth of sashimi that was impossibly flavorless with the fish cut so tiny it should have been called tartar, not sashimi. Even the cucumber and crab salad lacked seasoning and tasted as watered down as... water. There were these little dishes with a few slices of radish and scallions, presumably to season the bowl with but after adding them all to my bowl, while improved, the tiny pieces of fish still lacked texture or anything memorable or even flavorful.

My colleague is vegetarian and came to try one of the two vegetarian options on the day's lunch menu. The problem was option 1 had chicken (which they would hold), crab (also hold) and fish sauce. Had she ordered it with no actual animals in it, the waitress said she'd end up with a small bit of rice and a few veggies. She opted for option 2, which had less meat for the restaurant to hold. (In reality, there really wasn't any vegetarian options despite the day's menu using the V word to describe two menu choices) Anyway, what she got looked like one of those fried onion blossoms found at cheap quasi-Mexican restaurant chains only this one looked like it was squished and oozing more grease than a veg head or meat head could or should enjoy. And that only set her back $18. Yes, for lunch! I didn't taste it (nor did I want to) so I can't comment on its quality but we both agreed neither of us would be back. Maybe dinner is much better here but I doubt I'll be trying it based on how poorly, and expensively, they do lunch.

UPDATE:
Shortly after my initial review above, management at Rintaro messaged me with a sincere apology for our lunch experience and explained that as a result of the problems I described, their chef/owner has been addressing the issues and evaluating the lunch menu for improvements. They added that he is providing additional training to their kitchen staff and is revising some of the items. And lastly, they offered and provided a full refund for our lunch.

This effort by the restaurant and the courtesy and professionalism they showed in trying to make things right makes me feel like they deserve another chance. I have added a star to this review and in light of their unsolicited yet welcome response, I believe I will try another lunch at Rintaro sometime in the coming weeks. They recently began their lunch offerings and maybe just need a little time to become a great lunch choice in San Francisco's Mission district.
author: Peter S.

description:
Loved everything about this spot. Ambiance was Japanese Noah's Ark and the food was warm comfort. 

Highly recommend the chicken thigh skewer above all others. Tofu in broth was subtle and smooth. Standout was the cheese panko chicken. Not a super strong flavor profile, but just fluffy, juicy wonderment. Accompanied by cabbage and radish salad that really put this dish over the top. 

Udon was sub-par and not flavorful enough, especially when compared to the other dishes. 

Had dessert: Panna Cotta with green tea and almond cookie. Slurped it up. Nuff said. Yum yum.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Hmm...  Since Mr. J and I love Japanese food so much, we thought we would swing by the new Izakaya Rintaro for a second dinner because we just can't wait.

We ordered the following:

Hanetsuki Gyoza - the presentation might look pretty, but the skin of the gyoza is too thick and doughy.  The top part where it folds wasn't even fully cooked in the middle because it was too thick.

Dashimaki Tamago - nothing special and a tad bland.

Gizzard and Meji Fried Tofu - these skewers are lacking flavors!  I doubt they use binchotan.  Because if they do, it's a total waste.  Don't know how to explain it but something is missing.

Uni Donburi - ugh, the rice was a bit on the harder side.  Would really appreciate if the person who drop it off would give us a little instruction.  I mean, I know it's not rocket science, but what are we supposed to do with the Yuzu chunks and do we just pour the soy sauce over and mix?

Kaki Yonashi Kanten - really weird combo and nothing special.  I normally like the brown sugar syrup, but it wasn't complimenting the vanilla ice cream at all.

Overall, a rather disappointing experience.  So many Japanese restaurants opening left and right in the city.  Yet, hardly any are worth going.  Hopefully they will improve over time.  As for Yakitori, I think San Mateo has better choices.

And, if you pay attention with my photos, Melon Soda was clearly $3.50 on the menu and not $4.50 as charged on our bill.  Not a big deal but just saying...
author: Kay Y.

description: I have mixed feelings about this place. We came and sat at the bar and asked our waiter to order for us, stating that we were very hungry and not worried about the total cost (it was a special occasion). I would say that overall the skewers are good, but most of them taste very, very similar. The udon is the star (both carbonara and regular are great) and I would come back just for that, but sadly I didn't enjoy much of the other small plates we got.
author: Amy Y.

description:
This place doesn't look like much from the outside - it's actually kind of hard to find. At first, I thought it was closed. The food was pretty good, but I think it was pretty pricey for what you get. The silken tofu appetizer was really refreshing and ...the duck skewers! Loved them! 

The place was cute inside, but the service was only so-so. We made a few orders, but we also had the remind them and ask about our orders a few times. 

I don't know if it's worth coming back again - I think I'd rather find a better Izakaya place in the city.
author: Susie C.

description:
Nice service and atmosphere. Great Japanese Tapas. Prawn was to die for!




Will come back
author: Ed B.

description:
I was very pleased with my experience here. The decor is simple and earthy, with exposed beams and persimmon hanging branches. 

I really love Japanese food and I have been to Japan many times, so I was very excited to try RINTARO. I'm always on the search for yummy J food! 

I enjoyed this place bc it was simple good food. Clean and tasty! The gyoza was especially wonderful and very traditional with its unclosed edges. (It's his family recipe)

So very glad they take reservations now!!!!
author: rebecca c.

description:
I grew up on Japanese food and izakyas, and went on a first date here with someone from Japan because his boss reccomended it. Neither of us really got the hype.

The service here was prompt and courteous, but the food wasn't mindblowing. We were dissapointed by the limited choices to order from, but still got a good deal of things to try. We really wanted agedashi tofu and chicken karaage, BUT THEY WEREN'T ON TONIGHT'S MENU! Some things are just staples of an izakya--those are not meant to be revolving items.

The came out in a timely fashion--we started with the silken tofu and were a little confused by the arrangement of accompaniments. The soy sauce was separated in a tiny bowl, rather than with it, and fish flakes and other things were separate. I guess this is great if you are really picky about how much soy sauce you want? This was just okay. That was followed by very salty tamago that should have been sliced thinner. The fried smelt that came next was delicious and had a great sauce. We also ordered thigh and onion, potato, asparagus, and softbone skewers. Soft bone was not soft enough and could have been prepared better as it was on the tough side, and the rest were what'd you expect normally.

The place is close to home so that's nice, but I'm not walking back through tent city for a just okay izakaya. I'm sticking with Kiraku in Berkeley!!!!
author: Michelle N.

description:
This interior of this place was so freakin "Japanese chic" that I have to give it 4 stars even though I didn't find any home runs among the food. We ordered most of the Yelp-famous and staff-famous dishes, of which the simple yet flavorful Dashimaki Tamago was the most successful.  The also-famous Yosedofu (silken tofu) was so mild that we desperately tried to scrape up all of the minced ginger and sauce they provided with it in the hope of adding some flavor.  (It didn't help that they served this dish first; when you're hungry this isn't the best way to start.)  The chicken skewers were reasonably tasty.  We had the Tsukune which is meatball, and wings; these were made better by squeezing 100% of the provided lemon on them.    They also cut us a free taste of the chicken thighs which were probably the best of the bunch.  We finished the mild-taste-parade with their (again famous) Sobacha Panna Cotta Naru.  The sugar sauce was delightful, but something about the panna cotta tasted artificial to me - kind of like how soy milk doesn't taste quite like milk.

We also took down a KSA kolsch style ale, which was very good, and an excellent cup of traditional Japanese houjicha.

Next time, we will order whatever the F we please - and skip the famous things!
author: Aaron M.

description: Rintaro is a true hidden gem. It's a bit off the beaten path, but it's my favorite authentic Japanese dining experience to date. All of the food is prepared thoughtfully and it seems like everything has a purpose on the menu. Not to mention it's delicious. Everything we tried was outstanding, but the hamachi and the chicken wings were the shining stars. As with pretty much any place in San Francisco, it's best to show up with a reservation because of it's size and popularity it would be difficult to get a table otherwise.
author: Allie E.

description: Great date spot.  My wife and I had a really fun three hour dinner here.  If you can, sit at the bar so you can see all the action in the kitchen.
author: Troy J.

description: Izakaya Rintaro is not a traditional izakaya: don't expect to drop in with a group of friends, order a pitcher of beer, and have a few laughs with the table next to you. Naming aside, it is my favorite Japanese place in SF.
author: Brad B.

description: I had a great first dining experience at Rintaro. The service was professional that time with a really thoughtful and helpful waitress. That first time would have been a 4 stars.  However, our second experience was subpar.  We were seated at our 8:45pm reservation and majority of the yakitori items on the menu were already sold out.  The only thing left was chicken meatball.  It is called izakaya for a reason and that was our purpose dining there.  Our waitress, Jennifer,  was unapologetic and indifferent.  Basically we asked for one thing and her response was sold out and that continued down the list.  It would have been helpful if she offered to tell us what was left being available.  And to top this off, she spilled soup and soy sauce on us because she said "I didn't know there was soup."  We ordered udon, of course, there was soup. She displayed no emotion and was not very sorry.   The manager and other staffs seem nice and  friendly.
author: Kat K.

description:
It is so rare to dine in a restaurant that has just opened, and feel as satisfied as I did after eating at the recently-opened Rintaro. 

I usually shy away from trying new restaurants the first month or so after opening. There are inevitably too many kinks, in both the front and back of the house, to work out. I'd rather try a new place after they have figured everything out. However, when we received an invitation to join friends at Rintaro the week the restaurant opened, I accepted the invitation. We dined on night five of Rintaro being open. 

The wait and kitchen staff are clearly seasoned professionals. I guess I should have expected that from former Chez Panisse folks. The owner also operated a bento catering business and pop up restaurant in the East Bay, and clearly his experience has transferred well to the restaurant.

Between our party of four, we ordered almost the entire menu. This was by design, and because we love to eat. The dishes are meant for sharing, which worked for our "eat the entire menu" plan. 

We started our meal with the Peko Peko Ume-Shu drink. It's a plum (ume) liquor that's great for sipping and tastes just like a Japanese plum. An unusual treat, and the perfect way to start our meal. 

We ate everything from house made soft tofu, yakitori skewers and tamago to pork katsu and kombu-cured halibut. 

Everything we tried was beautifully presented and tasted as good as it looked. 

We ended our meal with both of the dessert options: persimmon and wine-poached pear jelly with vanilla ice cream and a ginger chiffon cake. Both were a beautiful ending to a fantastic meal. 

I'm not ready to give up my waiting period to try new restaurants rule, but I will say that my experience at Rintaro far exceeded any past dining at a newly opened restaurant. If they were that good on night five, I can't wait to see what they're going to be like in a month or two.
author: Lee H.

description:
Great selection of varying types of Japanese dishes including sashimi, noodles, yakitori, grilled whole fish, fresh salads. Not a single dish was like the other. We ordered about 8 dishes for the table of four which were served continuously over two hours. 

Their inventive take on drinks is refreshing.
author: Alina T.

description:
Food - 3
Service - 4
Ambiance - 4

Rintaro did not quite live up to the hype for us, but it was still a satisfying meal.

Dishes we got:
INGEN NO KURUMI AE - French bans with rich walnutty sauce (standout)
YAKITORI - Tsakune meatball and liberty duck breast
CHIIZU TORI KATSU - Riverdog farm chicken and cowgirl wagon wheel cheese katsu with acme panko, snow cabbage and shiso
MATSUTAKE GOHAN (FOR 2) - Rice cooked in a clay pot with California matsutake, dashi, fresh yuzu peel and mitsuba

Everything was unique and the flavors were interesting, but nothing blew our socks off.  The service was pleasant but a little slow.  The ambiance is quiet and intimate.

Overall, a good meal.  However, there is nothing rushing us to return here as I would likely want to try other Izakaya joints.
author: Carrie C.

description: Finally a good izakaya place in SF. The menu is small but selections are great. This place has a cute cozy Japanese vibe, good for dates. Food was delicious especially the fishes! Make sure you make the reservation or the wait could be more than an hour.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Ok, so this might have been the priciest meal I had in San Francisco. It was damned tasty, but I'm not sure if it was as good value for money as I'd like.

We did try a plethora of different things including the chicken wings (SO GOOD), the dirty girl wax beans (good, but over creamy for me), udon (not bad), the omelette (slightly overcooked for my taste), silken tofu (I only had a bite but it was very smooth), chicken meatball skewer (YUM), chicken liver skewer (glad I tried it), shiitake mushroom skewer (good but I wanted more shiitakes!), sweet peppers (meh, they tasted like peppers), chicken thigh skewer (tasty, tasty thighs) and likely a few other things I don't remember.

The cocktail was good, but not mindblowing - certainly enjoyable though. I loved the experience of the izakaya style, getting to try so many different dishes is always fun, but I find they add up very quickly and I'm not usually as full as I'd like from how much I've spent.
author: Ayla C.

description:
Now... where do I start.

I made a reservation 3 weeks in advance, to make sure we got a nice spot.
We got a "table" at the bar (which is OK if you just walk-in into a restaurant, but not for a 3 week in advance reservation!!)
We ordered 2 drinks (the pomegranate, and the tea based) Pomegranate: OK, nothing special. Tea based: I couldn't finish it, what am I saying? I couldn't even start it!
Then for food we ordered 1 snack (eggplant), 2 skewers, the damsaki tamago and one of the udon to share.
I must say the food was again OK, nothing special. It took us 1.5 hours to get all our order! Even the eggplant (which was supposed to be a snack took about 25 minutes to come out)
I understand that they cook everything from fresh (I could see that from my seat), but 1.5 hours!?! Really?? 4 small orders? 
Service wasn't great either, she never came back to see how were doing.

The ambiance is great, and if you go there in a group of 4 you get a Japanese box, which is pretty cool.

I just came back from a trip in Japan, and food over there is delicious, so maybe my expectations were set too high for a Japanese restaurant.
author: Maggie J.

description:
I'm new to the world of Izakaya and thankful to my friends for bringing me here, even if some of us were dragged (Bryant M. ;-).

Izakaya helped open my eyes to the realization that not all Japanese food is sashimi. Ignorant, I know, but my immediate reaction to this was one of disappointment: I LOVE sashimi. What I learned during my Izakaya experience is that it's a wonderful meal when I'm craving Japanese food, but also want fried chicken!

They have a delicious take on chicken wings and the chicken katsu is worth ordering for a meal that is nice and filling. Some classic Japanese flavours with big, bold and classically American (as far as I know) fried chicken. Marriage works!

That said, you'll want to bring a whole bunch more dishes to your table to play. The individual dishes are small and ideal for sharing. For the best experience, bring a bunch of friends and have everybody order a few of their favourites. Make sure to get some of the skewers - I would have over looked them but some of my friends were smart enough to order. These wounds up being my favourite part of the meal.

They have a more open front area that has a lively yet private atmosphere to it. You'll feel part of something but still be able to have conversations.

For larger groups, they have a semi-private back room, separated by a low hanging cloth, that will fit a few larger tables or would also be a great space for a private party.

If you're feeling social they even have bar seating along the kitchen. The combination of all of this makes for an excellent and delicious time.
author: Dale E.

description:
In all honesty, I got dragged here against my will -- and I'm so glad I was. Even though Japanese fare is not my go-to, I loved this place. Here's why:

+It's a bit off the beaten path. When our uber driver dropped us off, I was totally confused because it looked like we were in a residential neighborhood. Izakaya Rintaro is beautifully nestled on a quiet street, and the exterior is warm and cozy with lights strung above the simple patio. 

+They take reservations! (Okay, it's going to be about a 2-hour wait, but still... they take reservations!) They were also incredibly gracious to accommodate an additional 5 people that added to our party at the last minute. 

+The service is stellar. Every single person was kind and helpful, and our lovely server was pure perfection. I have this wheat thing, and she helped me navigate the menu without hesitation. So if you need to eat gluten-free for whatever reason, Izakaya Rintaro knows what's up. 

+The food is creative, yet comfortable at the same time. Although the dishes had several ingredients I wasn't familiar with, nothing seemed out of reach or too fussy to eat. I decided on a couple different types of chicken skewers (with gf soy sauce, of course), and they were simple and delicious. I also split the dessert -- a green tea panna cotta -- with a friend, and it was weird and wonderful. And from the looks of it, everyone loved their meals. One thing to note: the food here really is tapas style, so be prepared to order several plates and share them.

+The interior is minimalistic and beautiful. Think: lots of light wood, dark, soft lighting, and modern. 

The price tag is a bit hefty, but for such a perfect experience -- it was worth it for me.
author: Bryant M.

description:
In the former Chez Spencer space, Izakaya Rintaro serves some interesting, but expensive Japanese "tapas."

The menu is rather limited, offering yakitori and only 12 other dishes. The chicken thigh and scallion yakitori ($7 for 2 skewers) was perfectly cooked. The breast and lime yakitori ($7 for 2) was tender and juicy. Served with grated daikon, the dashimaki tamago ($9.25) was wonderfully fluffy. Freshly made of organic soybeans, the yosedofu (silken tofu, $7.75) was brightened by crispy scallion and freshly grated ginger. Served in a clay pot, the delicious tori meshi ($12.75) sported Riverdog chicken, egg, and fresh yuzu kosho.

There is a good selection of sake and beer. The flight of three sakes ($25) is a good way to kick off your meal. Service was a bit slow and confused with dishes coming out irregularly. Used plates were not removed promptly and drinks took a long time to arrive.

Overall, Izakaya Rintaro is good, but on the pricey side, even for The City.
author: CJ G.

description:
Nice atmosphere and interior that reminded me of Japan. Food-wise some dishes were really good. The duck sallad, the chilled tofu, the korokke, and the nankotsu yakitori were all really really good. However, the chicken breast and tender yakitori were quite dry and bland (disappointing). The soba special was quite disappointing as well. I love soba, but the soba just didn't taste like it does in Japan.

I would definitely go back and try more dishes. Hopefully next time more of the dishes will be available (quite a few items weren't available when we were there).
author: Philip B.

description:
Service was pretty horrible, forgot about us multiple times and asked for things that were ignored. As I write this I'm still waiting for the check to arrive.

Trout was bland and tasteless. 

Chicken wings tasted like something I could have grilled at home in crisco and Safeway brand bread crumbs. 

Tofu was not bad so +1 for that.
author: David Z.

description:
So won't lie, definitely came to this place because it was rated as one of the top 10 new restaurants of the year. Did it live up to the hype...? A resounding yes.

Food was awesome, with some of the standouts being the spot prawn sashimi, chicken "oyster" skewers, karagge chicken wings, the whole fried fish, and the house made tofu. Their green tea was also super legit. The ok list included the tartare, some cold veggie dish with a miso-yuzu mix, and the fish cakes. Dessert was some awesome tea creme brulee that will never be matched again in my life! Service was solid, as they kept refilling our tea on the cold night, but I have to admit having five people shoved into a booth for four was a let down. Do try this place if you're in the area or hankering for some delicious izakaya style food, but make reservations and be ready to be squeezed into a small space!
author: David H.

description: Hands down one of the best Japanese restaurant I've been in SF Bay area.  Yakitori is a must and their salad menu is very fresh and while light still flavorful.  The only drawback is the bill at the end..  price is a bit steep for the menu portion, for example a very small bowl of salad is north of $10, all the yakitori menus are pretty much between $10 and $15.  Would recommend it overall.  Kampai!
author: Luk S.

description: Good tasty authentic and fresh food, well thought out and nicely presented. Very good thoughtful and attentive service. Felt a bit rushed out the door at the end, but service was great otherwise. Tended to be a bit loud... but it may have just been the booth behind us. Smokey at times due to open kitchen.  Energy occas, frenetic with 'trendy'  ' millennial ' crowd and attitude. The Pannacotta was superb
author: C J.

description: Love yakitori Restos and this one is a little gem hidden on 14th, not the best neighborhood in town but the food is killer. Wish they had some Tako Wasa! Everything else is amazing! Service is excellent! Their house Sake (served cold or more like room temp) just a bit chilled is to die for. It's like drinking water with this lovely aromatic smell! Would definitely come back again.
author: Miguel Y.

description:
Such amazing dinner! I'm very glad we got a reservation here for our date night. The place is very nice, cozy and unpretentious - replacing the great Chez Spencer - designed and built by the chef's father. We ordered:
- odd bits yakatori: liver and kneecaps - yum!
- fried chicken wings - great flavor
- chicken katsu - aaaaamazing
- shu-mai - I could eat 15 of these!!! (no, not really, but they are amazing)
- mochi and panna cotta - both of these were very good, the panna cotta was the lightest I ever had
And to top this off, our servers were so nice and attentive. They told us about the place, the chef and his father, what materials were used in building the restaurant, etc.
Can't wait to go back! Great job Rintaro and chef Brackett.
author: Timea B.

description:
I almost never write yelp reviews, basically limited to when I truly believe it may help a favorite spot of mine receive a little extra attention or possibly serve as a small help to their business. Rintaro certainly doesn't need my help, but rather has just consistently surpassed our expectations every visit, enough so that this is the least I could do.
 
I truly believe Rintaro is one of the most special, unique places in San Francisco. While Al's Place, Lazy Bear, etc. pop up in the news regularly, somehow Rintaro remains a relatively under-the-radar gem. Having eaten at many of the top spots in the city, I believe they care as much or more about their food than any other top restaurant in SF. Whether it's painstakingly made Udon, the greatest Tamago I've had always (at least every time I've been) prepared by Chef Brackett himself (and not frequently enough on the menu), some of the most consistently fantastic Yakitori I've seen including my time in Japan (and maybe the best variety of chicken bits in SF, make sure you ask if anything isn't on the menu), even to the home made tofu and plum wine in their cocktails, there is a level of detail and love not always shared by Rintaro's peers.
 
But even beyond the food, the experience is unparalleled. Where you may wait in the crowded front room at Al's, at Rintaro you are welcomed by a beautiful garden scene somehow hidden from the unsightly streets just outside. As you arrive and leave, you will often be thanked by both the wait staff and the cooks behind the counter for your patronage. And if you go for a special occasion (we just did our anniversary), you may be able to slip a special request (ours was having Tamago on the menu - and it wasn't, but rather a special order was prepared and served to us as a first course), you may even luck out with a complimentary drink or two before your meal, and if you're fortunate enough, maybe even a quick hello from Chef Brackett. And it is this, the complete experience, that sets Rintaro apart.
 
When you go, in case it wasn't obvious, order at least one piece of chicken you wouldn't normally (kanzuri or hearts perhaps?). If you can, ask for a seat at the counter where you can see the chefs' attention to detail in action. Don't just get a beer (although I usually do), inquire about which cocktail is your host's favorite or would pair best with your meal. And again, get the Tamago.
 
And thank you Chef Brackett and all of Rintaro for another special night (the best one yet). This is exactly why we come at least once every season: to see what new magic you've cooked up and once again ask ourselves why we waited 3 months to come back.
author: Mitch S.

description:
My friends and I (4 of us) were sitting outside in the courtyard because they did not have space; understand bc it is a busy restaurant.

We ordered drinks and a dessert and were enjoying our drinks. After 30 min, the hostess asked us to give up our chairs because they apparently ran out of chairs inside. We now have to stand, and they didn't even over to comp a drink for the inconvenience.

Pretty messed up and disappointing. I don't know how they can consider themselves to be a legitimate or professional restaurant if this is how they treat a paying customer.

Never coming back, strongly do not recommend.
author: Matt P.

description: This review is seriously long overdue. I've been to Izakaya Rintaro five times and every single meal is just as memorable, if not better, than my first, which is why I keep going back. Unlike typical Japanese restaurants where they serve mostly sushi, Rintaro offers a variety of other Japanese items (think yakitori, yaki onigiri, korokke, etc.) and I really appreciate that. I believe their menu changes seasonally, so I'm always excited to see what they are offering, but like that they keep some of their staples, too. Inside Rintaro is aesthetically pleasing - very simple yet modern - and love that they have an open kitchen where you can watch the chefs work their magic. Really friendly and helpful staff also. Can't wait to go back!
author: Kalani K.

description: My husband and I just went there 2 months ago. Fishes taste so fresh and we were so blown away how tasty all of their food were!!!!! We definitely visit the place again soon!!
author: Jang R.

description: Great food. My recommendation: make sure you share with others from your party, instead of ordering individual entrees. That way, you'll get a taste of a broader range of their food. The service is also very good.
author: Antonio B.

description:
Really tasty, good quality, little hidden spot. A Japanese friend recommended it and I really love it! I never order a dish that I didn't like, and i'm a bit picky. 
4 stars instead of 5 because they are always late (i've been there 3 or 4 times), bit pricy (but quality come with a price right? ), and some of their waitress not super friendly. Still, a place to try :)
author: Morgane M.

description:
This was my second time here. Just as delicious as my first time! The servers were friendly and attentive. They came by to fill our tea many times. The decor is part of the charm. The outside courtyard is super cute and all the interior woodwork details are gorgeous. 

There were 4 of us and we had the torikawa age (deep fried chicken skin), yosedofu (soft tofu made on sight with choose your own condiments), dashimaki tamago (Japanese rolled omelette), millefeuille tonkatsu (layered fried pork cutlet with shiso and more), an order of chicken thighs with green onions skewer, an order of chicken liver skewer, and the nabeyaki udon (pot cooked udon). For dessert we had the houjicha panna cotta (roasted green tea panna cotta), and the fruit mitsumame. The panna cotta is so smooth and creamy (a must!) and the fruit is so ripe and fresh in the mitsumame (best bite of apricot I've had in years). Everything was flavorful and delicious, ingredients are fresh and in season. Can't wait to come back!
author: Sarabeth L.

description: The best udon I have eaten in the US! I was really impressed by how good their handmade udon was. I often go to Japan, and I have been to many udon places there, but this restaurant had udon just as good, if not better, than most of the places I have been to in Japan. We also ordered some of the yakitori, which was good, but not impressive compared to the udon. Also all the food is really expensive, but if you are looking for some high quality Japanese food in a place with a nice atmosphere, I definitely recommend this place
author: Hannah G.

description:
Chicken. Chicken chicken chicken. 

Yes, I know Rintaro does so much more than chicken, but it's the veritable exaltation of this common fowl that keeps me coming back again and again. I thought I knew chicken, but I'm seriously appreciating chicken in a whole other light. 

There are two standout dishes that make me so sad if they're not there; the liver skewers and the chicken/rice (for one). The first time I had the chicken/rice I almost wish that I had a cold coming on so I could credit it for curing me. 

If pressed to consider Rintaro beyond chicken (but seriously. chicken), of course, the decor is stand-out amazing. It's like dining in the hull of a Japanese cedar canoe, and I mean this in only the most complimentary way. The wood makes the place warm and smell amazing, even after months of being open. The other dishes I've tried have also been supremely tasty and well-executed. If there's a whole fish on the menu, don't miss it. 

The only thing that ever gives me pause is the dessert. It's probably just my western-leaning mentality, but I always want something with a little chocolate. Again, I can't fault them for my habits. 

Also, little-known fact, there's a killer back room that would be awesome for a private event. In fact, with a birthday coming up, I might just have some friends over. As long as they don't order up all the chicken!
author: margo s.

description: This place is worth 2 stars due to their unannounced time limit. There were 4 of us, and our reservation was for 6:30pm. We were having a great time, loving the food and drinks, until the hostess comes over at 8pm to inform us that we have another 30 minutes to finish our meal. It's not like we were hogging their table and not ordering food or drinks; in the allocated time limit we managed to rake up a bill of $500 for the 4 of us, and it would've been a lot more had we not been kicked out. They should've told us of the 2hr limit when we made the reservation, but informing us during our meal is just rude and unprofessional.
author: Pegs C.

description: Japanese Tapas spot! Everything was so good. I didn't even care which part of the chicken I was eating! All the skewers were bomb.Com
author: Abigail E.

description:
i had been wanting to try this place for a long time, and my friend bought me a gift certificate years ago when it first opened.  i finally used it yesterday for dinner w/ friends, and it was tasty.  we tried the fresh tofu, turnips, shumai, kabocha korokke, whole grilled rainbow trout, some skewers and the nabeyaki udon to finish.  everything was really yummy, and my faves were the fresh tofu, grilled fish, kabocha, and the chicken tsukene skewers.  

this place feels super japanese, and the ambience was great.
author: Helen T.

description: Had heard the buzz about this place and went to check it out.  We were not disappointed. The restaurant itself is super interesting, with a long bar as you enter with booths on the other side, exposed beams overhead, and traditional Japanese curtain partitions placed here and there. Feels a little close quartered, intimate and rustic.  Especially with all the smoke from the open grill swirling around.  When you step in from the street, through the courtyard and into the restaurant you feel like you've stepped into an old timey Japanese izakaya joint. From the street, you would never guess that behind the wooden gate was this sweet little Japanese eatery. The service was very attentive, our waiter helped us pick out the initial cocktail, and then parse through the sake list to chose a very yummy bottle. As an izakaya place it was many many small plates of food. We have been to many and this one definitely stacks up with the best. Menu was varied, veggis and proteins fresh, and preparation spot on.  There were four of us and one was a vegetarian, so we tried the sashimi, the housemade tofu (YUM!), various yakitory skewers, the croquettes, dumplings, chicken karaage and finished things off with beef curry (SO good!). I will say it was a pricey meal, but very memorable and special. Definitely one to add to this list of places to go for a unique, delicious and enjoyable meal.
author: Lori H.

description: Fresh and carefully picked ingredients plus a talented staff make for one of the best izakayas in San Francisco. The yakitori were all perfectly grilled and the carbonara udon was outstanding. Don't skip out on the desserts either because they are cap off the meal with surprisingly creative and tasty feelings.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Great ambiance, delicious food! 

Had a few of the skewers -- all were perfectly cooked and completely delicious. The beef curry was also great, down to the rice that came with it. 

My favorite though, was the chicken katsu with the cowgirl creamery cheese. Truly excellent!
author: Rita K.

description: Have been to Rintaro several times and it keeps getting worse. Had 9pm reservation last night, waitress rushed us through out the evening. The kitchen was breaking down before 10pm, check was delivered before we were done.  Overall bad vibe last night.
author: Sandra P.

description:
Beautiful venue with a wonderful warmth to the space.  The hidden entrance, excellent service, and menu brought me walking down memory lane of my Japan trip.  

The booths have a cozy feel.  I sat at the front corner table for two and it was perfect. 

They could turn down the music a bit as it got pretty loud later in the night.

Would definitely return here.
author: Jackie D.

description:
This place is overpriced and overrated in my opinion.

The menu is different than most Japanese restaurants, mainly because it's not a sushi restaurant. This place specializes in skewers and other small dishes, though they do have some sashimi on their menu. The atmosphere is pretty chill here and the decor is modernized. 

My friend and I ordered the chicken oyster and chicken rib skewer. The chicken oyster is meat closer to the butt of the chicken, so it's more tender and had the skin on it. Both skewers were pretty good, but it tasted like something I could make myself at home. 

For the "finishing dish," we shared a bowl of udon for 2. It had an egg, vegetables, and duck. The dish itself was pretty good. The broth was flavorful while the udon noodles did taste freshly made. But for $25, it was pretty small. It was more for one person rather than two like it said on the menu.

The service here was decent. The server was friendly but a little too attentive.

I probably wouldn't come back here because I feel like the food was just average for the price.
author: Derek T.

description: This place was amazing great ambiance, great food, excellent cocktails. We were there with another couple. We asked the chef to make us whatever, and he did not disappoint.
author: Sam S.

description:
I hate to be the dissenter here, but I was sadly disappointed by my meal here.  Perhaps my expectations were too high after the Bon Appetit fanfare, but honestly, I think I would have been underwhelmed by my meal regardless.  The best thing about Rintaro was the interior decor - it's a beautiful space that was clearly crafted with much thought and love.  But unfortunately, the same wow factor does not translate to the food.

We ordered a variety of items on the menu, and nothing was terrible, but nothing was great either.  There wasn't anything particularly new or exciting on the menu, nor was there anything that was executed particularly well.  Overpriced for what you get in both quality and quantity.  I think it's wonderful that a local restaurant got such great press recently, but I think Rintaro really needs to step up its game to live up to the hype.  Yelp puts it best with it's 2 stars "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Cindy W.

description:
Just came back from a delicious Kaiseki style dinner at Rintaro and was very impressed. The atmosphere was cozy, space is beautiful and good on low noise level although the place was packed. 

Ok so what to order:

-Marin coast halibut sashimi, half moon bay wasabi, like butter- melts in your mouth- super fresh.

-The house dish is the Goyza- basically dumplings- but the presentation is fantastic and they burst delight in each bite.

-Tori Katsu- chicken with cheese was satisfying and light but savory.

- Yakitori- savory and great to try a few

-Ending with the Kakiage Udon- delicious broth and incredible hand rolled thick tasty noodles.

_ Dessert- you have to try one- we tried the parfait- homemade ice-cream- I usually don't like desserts- but it was so savory and not too sweet.

They have a lot of fabulous non-alcoholic drinks- try the fresh orange drink !

Oh I will absolutely go back! Be sure to reserve in advance, as this place is popular- I recommend sitting at the bar if there are 2 of you- as you can watch the chefs!
author: Jill S.

description: Service was excellent, but the food was extremely disappointing. I liked the environment and the layout of the place as well. I see many people on here compare this to a real Izakaya in Japan. However, if this place opened in Japan, it would probably be on the bottom of the list because it certainly does not taste Izakaya worthy. It could be that the flavor is bland and dull to tailor to the "Healthy SF" taste buds, but you can cook the same thing yourself at home with the ingredients and cooking style they use.
author: Ken T.

description: Credit card required to make a reservation? No thank you. I'll take my business elsewhere.
author: Keau K.

description:
The best Japanese food I've eaten since being in Japan! Incredible decor with a huge amount of attention to detail. Nice friendly staff and atmosphere. Each dish was presented beautifully.

Standout dishes for me were the pork gyoza, the fresh udon noodles and the katsu miso pork. It's always nice to be able to get some good tamago egg as well, yummy.
author: Hannah H.

description:
After dining here, I wonder if the Bon Appetit staff had never been to an izakaya.  The Bay Area has so many great ones, and while Rintaro is good, it's not amazing.  It's more of 3.5 stars -- the price point was a little high and the menu small, but service was very friendly.

We ordered:
- Green beans with walnut sauce:  It sounds weird and I don't even like walnuts, but this was one of the best dishes of the night.  The walnut sauce gave a rich creaminess to the beans which made them quite unique.  4/5
- Yakitori of the vein between the chicken heart & liver:  Okay this was a new experience as I've never tried this before.  I wouldn't say I liked it as the texture is like eating slightly rubbery thick veins, but it's worth a one time try.  2/5
- Cartilage yakitori:  Normally I love knuckle cartilage yakitori and don't like the long thin cartilage, but here they keep some of the meat on which made this pretty tasty.  4/5
- Chicken shoulder yakitori, chicken gizzard yakitori, chicken thigh with scallion yakitori and chicken meatball yakitori:  Good but not memorable.  4/5
- Chicken oyster yakitori:  Sadly dry.  2/5
- Fried chicken wings (large size):  Good sized plate of tasty chicken wings covered in a sweet soy-based sauce.  4/5
- Chicken rice in broth (keihan):  Really nothing special  3/5

While we saw plates of the house-made udon pass by, we weren't allowed to order it -- may be sold out?
author: Alice C.

description:
We were introduced to this amazing isakaya by the restaurant's architects.

I could go broke just ordering the chicken wings.

Don't miss the japanese carpentry elements--Sylvan's father--trained in Japan--built it out.

can't wait to try it again.
author: Ted H.

description: Lovely authentic setting with family-run feeling, sophisticated but subtle takes on classics: udon, yakitori, dumplings, wonderful combinations and truly exquisite desserts, including tea panna cotta.
author: Red R.

description: Fun laid back atmosphere with amazingly great food. The sashimi's were fresh and delicious. The Chicken oyters very tender, the dumplings interesting and different (excellent) and the cold noodles topped off a great meal. The booth the three of us sat in allowed for great conversation while being part of the restautrant.
author: Gijs V.

description: By far one of the best restaurants I have been to. Not only is it surrounded by a wonderful staff, amazing cooks and awesome decor... But they execute their food every time! Shout outs to Koko, Tenshu, and Kan who never seize to amaze me with their kindness and dedication to preparing delicious food. Rintaro is a must if you're a native to SF or just strolling by.
author: Carina D.

description:
I generally never have Shime-saba since I hate the sour taste that spreads in your mouth. Shime-saba at Rintaro, however, was actually very nice and marinated to a level where you can actually taste the mackerel and enjoy.
Also, I love nankotsu yakitori, although it was harder to chew compare to the ones you have in Japan.
author: Asa N.

description: The ambiance is great. Cozy inside, great architectural details, but the smell inside was very strong of meat cooking. Fortunately they gave us a table outside in the courtyard. Very nice, My husband had the skewers of chicken hearts and chicken liver. The hearts were better. We split the Kobocha Korroke and they were underwhelming. I expected that rich, sweet squash that I'm accustomed to and it wasn't there. The best dish (it isn't currently on the online menu so I forget what it is called; thought it was Matto Don) was the julienned-tempura maitake, carrot and onions over rice with a hot spring egg.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: I was just really unimpressed by the food. Nothing was bad but nothing jumped out at me either. I know we're in San Francisco but I thought it was pricey for what was being served.
author: Eli L.

description:
A high quality authentic Japanese Izakaya. Tasty, fresh and good ambiance.
Limited menu selections, all pretty good. Will go again.
author: Jun S.

description:
We had a great dining experience here. I came with 4 other guests and shared about 15 small plates. The ambiance was bright and sunny because of the large skylights in the ceiling. The menu is small and seasonal. 

I really enjoyed my sochu cocktail- it was made with very fresh ingredients. We also shared a bottle of sake, of which there was a respectable selection. 

There were several booths so I'd say this restaurant is ideal for small parties (3-4 guests).
author: Sarah M.

description:
While the space is beautiful and the food was good, the service needs some work. Who doesn't love an izakaya? Part of animals grilled and other small bites meant to be drunk with sake and eaten at leisure with friends.

While food was all good but not great it was 1-2 dollars more than it should be and the menu is rather small for an Izakaya. This is not a place for a vegetarian or a pescatarian. They also forgot one of our dishes. The gizzards were over-cooked. The yosedofu (silken tofu, $7.75) was brightened by crispy scallion and freshly grated ginger and quite good. The uni don was small and poor priced for the amount of uni.

The service was poor. We made a reservation and then when we went there were no tables free and only very narrow seat at the bar. I made a reservation so we would have a table. They were able to clear one table in the back after we refused to sit at the bar. Then they seem to forget about us. We had to get someone's attention to order and then things came out randomly sometimes 3 dishes at a time then a 15 minute wait for more food.

The inside space is mostly not wheelchair accessible with booths raised off the floor, narrow walkways, and high stools at the bar. It looks beautiful especially contrasted with the burnt beams above but the food and service do not live up to the decor.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
I saw this restaurant in an article and grew curious when it was named as "one of the best restaurants in America" and I was also so pleased to see that it was an izakaya style restaurant. It's tucked away in the Mission and could be hard to miss if you aren't looking for it.

The first thing I noticed right off of the bat was the decor and the ambiance. There is some truly amazing carpentry / wood working details that went into the build of this place. My sister said it smelled just like the hot onsens (hot springs) in Japan, and she didn't mean it in a bad way! The wood gives off such a nice warm, musky smell and it totally compliments the added aroma of grilled meat. 

We ordered quite a few items: shishito peppers, gindara sunomono (black cod with cucumber salad), teba no karaage (japanese fried chicken wings) chiizu tori katsu (chicken katsu with cheese and cabbage), and some standard robata items such as meatball, thighand scallion. For dessert we had the hojicha panna cotta (green tea panna cotta). 

Oddly enough the items that stood out to me the most were the items that I figured would be the most disappointing: shishito peppers; incredibly fresh, grilled and smokey perfection with great crunch. the karaage was OUT of this WORLD! Such a great flavor to the skin and just fried in the best sort of way. The meatball was also surprisingly full of flavor and totally surprised me.. but probably the best thing of all was DESSERT. And trust me, I am not a dessert person and I usually pass on it. But this came out in such a strange presentation that I had to try it. You pour a sort of hojicha syrup (which I suppose was suppose to be like maple syrup but infused with TEA!?) on top of the panna cotta and it just tastes divine... 

I would literally return just for the karaage and the dessert. I am eager to see if they will change their menu depending on the seasons. Although the meal was thoroughly enjoyable, I thought they were lacking some more interesting items on the menu so it would be nice if they did change it up a bit.
author: Mariko M.

description:
This place was beautiful to look at and dine in.  Like a cross between Muji and your Japanese Grandma's house out in the Kansai countryside.  Love the exposed wood, the indigo-chic uniforms the staff have to wear and the simplistic but very rich attention to details, colors, light and textures.  Also love that they used real Yatai yakitori grills, or at least seemed to.  Really beautiful décor.  Not at all like an izakaya, but spot on in terms of "wafu" aesthetic.  Too many beards, curled staches and tattoo sleeves for my liking, but hey, you can't turn away customers...not Rintaro's fault.

Unfortunately we were disappointed with the food.  Only because we really wanted to eat real, non-fusion, un-doctored izakaya food.  We felt this menu tried too hard to be innovative when the innovation could have been to simply provide damn good classic izakaya food which, quite frankly, doesn't exist in San Francisco.  But that's no fault of Rintaro.  Just our personal preference.  For people that don't know Japanese food or only have basic knowledge of it, this place's food would've probably been amazing for them. And it was delicious, just not what we like :-) Oh, and there was no shochu.  What? Why?

Only thing that left us thinking "hm..." was we were there for our wedding night dinner for just my husband and I.  We had our first date in an izakaya in Tokyo, where we met, and we were hoping to pay homage to that fact. When I called to make the reservation I mentioned that it was our wedding night and the waitress was pretty emotionless about it.  I wasn't expecting freebies or special treatment at all.  I was just so excited to be booking our wedding dinner so I blurted it out, but there was no "congratulations" or any hint of friendliness, really - just monotonous confirmation that our reservation was for 2.  And when we arrived I mentioned it again - again, out of excitement and it was like the waitress didn't hear us.  Again, no special treatment needed, it just would have been good customer service to have acknowledged that she at least heard me.  Just thought that was a bit crap.  But our actual waitress was so lovely so that made up for that.  

Of course I can't rate the restaurant on the poor actions of 1 or 2 people, especially as the place is so darn nice to look at. That's why I'm still giving it 4 stars.  I'm not giving it 5 stars because I think the menu could have been a bit more authentic.  The karaage could have been real karaage- not wings- and there should always be shochu on the menu at an izakaya.  Full stop. Still, so pretty....
author: Adrian C.

description:
How anyone could give Rintaro less than five stars makes me doubt the value of Yelp. 

The setting, food and service were all spectacular.  Stepping through the front gate transports you to another world. The restaurant is a traditional Japanese house built by the chef's father. It is truly a magical space. 

Visiting with a large group allowed us to order nearly everything off the menu. Each dish was fantastic.  Some standouts were the salt baked mountain trout, the handmade gyoza and the crunchy salad with crispy shrimp.  I'm still thinking about them!

Yakitori prepared over bincho charcoal is a rarity in Japan let alone in the US. This was done extremely well.  Chicken oysters are a rarity anywhere, and they have them here!  

Come give this place an honest try.  You'll be happy you did!
author: Secret Asian M.

description:
This Izakaya restaurant has a lot of potential, but just isn't up to the standard of its peers in SF. 

Came here for Valentines Day and was initially very surprised to see their beautiful interior/ambience... Only to be seated in the backroom which was essentially kitchen/storage space which had obviously been converted into extra seating space.

Food came out incredibly slow - we had been seated at 7 and were only two dishes in the prefixed menu by 8. We glanced around the backroom at one point and saw that EVERY table was waiting for food.. If you don't have the kitchen capacity to serve an additional backroom.... Then don't have a backroom.  We told our hostess/waitress (we did not have a consistent wait person) that we had an evening engagement at 9, however, and they did speed up the courses for us.

The food itself was average. Nothing on the prefixed menu stood out, although I will concede that the ahi was fresh.  Prior to dessert, my date and I were considering coming back to give their regular menu a chance on a less busy night... But they had to bring out the "Chocolate Financier", boasted as almond and chocolate cake with candied rose petals.  This in theory could have been amazing... But in reality, it was bland, spongy, madelines on a plate of powdered sugar.  Just give me a scoop of green tea ice-cream next time.... Seriously.

Wait staff was super nice, but it seemed they were unaccustomed to serving the extended space as we were asked for drink orders twice and our courses were brought out in the wrong order.

Price came out to be about $260 for the two of us including tip... Which could have been a far better (and tastier) experience elsewhere.

Izakaya Rintaro - Lose the backroom.   It is a complete let down for your customers to see the beautiful front area only to have them seated in a dark backroom next to a sink.  You guys also don't seem to yet have the kitchen capacity for it.  The competition is fierce in SF..
author: Eric H.

description: Love this place! Small portions, but very tasty. Not overpriced for how delicious it is. The KABOCHA KOROKKE is my favorite of everything. Udon was yummy too. The drinks were fabulous! Can't wait to come back.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Delicious! Pro tip: sit at the chef's counter. The stools are not terribly comfortable but you'll be able to watch all the dishes prepared and put on the pass, so you can see what you want to order before you actually order it.  (I don't really care if stools have/don't have a back rest, but the foot rail was so low  for a shortie like me it was barely reachable). 

The scallion and chicken skewers were wonderful (also note they do cook chicken Japanese style so it's a little pink), as was the asparagus with sesame dressing, curried kabocha croquettes, and chicken wings that'll give San Tung a run for sticky/spicy/sweet dominance. Service was wonderful-- bartender at the counter even gave us an extra splash as we had a good ol' time. Capped it off with a green tea panna cotta that was light and came with candied walnuts and a honey sauce to add at will. Well done, Rintaro.
author: Emily L.

description: I've returned twice since my birthday...for the pop up okonomiyaki in the courtyard and for lunch on Thursday... Both delights.
author: Geri S.

description:
I loved this place! The food was excellent. I especially appreciate the care and thoughtfulness that went into their sourcing. And the atmosphere, design, and materials used were incredible. A brilliant adaptation of traditional Japanese design with American restaurant design, which is also an analogy for their food. And, they played a great soundtrack. The service, also, was friendly and fast and attentive, though a bit amateur. 

The only complaint I have is that it took me so long to try this place!
author: Eater S.

description:
A cool Mission restaurant that serves high quality izakaya style food.

Loved the book "Building the Japanese House Today" and the photos in it. The ambience met our expectations. Seated in the back room. Towards the end of the meal, we were left alone to enjoy the design and the decor.

The music was too loud.

Ordered 13 items (no sashimi) and house sake. Yosedofu had a mild graininess and the nutty note of soybeans. They could be a little more generous with the accompaniments. Shumai was a pleasant surprise. Kake Udon only with the hot spring egg would be a better choice or have the Satsuma-age served as a side. Yakitori items were delicious, especially chicken oysters and hearts. The deluxe Kanzuri was a chicken inner part between the heart and the liver. We probably had tasted that part before. It had a mundane name.

Service was minimal. 

The recent review of the restaurant by a food critic is too flattering to be convincing. We have been to some izakayas in the Bay Area that do better in authenticity, originality or variety. To be a standout, Rintaro needs personality.
author: D.V. A.

description: I wasn't sure what this place was... I'm still not really sure. It's kind of a small plates japanese tapas place I guess? It's like an Izakaya without the focus on alcohol. The space is super pretty it's a great place to meet with a friend. The food gets an A+++ even though it's very expensive for the size of the plates.
author: Geoff G.

description:
Great meal here tonight. Sort of unique and interesting atmosphere with creative and super tasty tapas-style food that came out at a fair pace for it being packed at 7:30 on a Saturday night.

We had:
Fresh Monterey Bay halibut sashimi with fresh wasabi which was top notch.
The chicken cheddar katsu. The hand rolled fresh udon noodles with tofu. The chicken meatball skewers, chicken thigh & scallion skewers. A salad with persimmon vinaigrette and chilled duck breast. All of it was really great food.

Service was good for us. No complaints other than a missing egg in one of the udon orders. No big deal.

Show up early and hit the whisky bar next door. Amazing selection.
author: Zak S.

description: More authentic than your typical SF Izakaya, so that's good! We had the katsu, the tofu, the hard boiled eggs, the tsukune, and the genmaicha panna cotta. The tofu was delicious but needed more ginger and sauce.  The Katsu was interesting... it was huge slabs of pork with onions sandwiched inside, and the whole thing is fried.  The taste and texture were good, but the onion really threw me off.  The Tsukune and panna cotta were excellent. I'd go back for more yakitori.
author: Terry K.

description: Very cool ambiance. Good staff. Fun to sit at bar and watch the chefs at work. The Udon soup was delicious as was the Gyozo. Would definitely come back.
author: Kelly R.

description: Looks like there's a seasonal menu since some of the items that were on yelp weren't on the menu.  We had the cheesey tonkatsu - which was not amazing, but yummy if you like chicken with cheese (good cheese!).  I still prefer aina's katsu, none other is very moist in the bay area that I've found at least.  The fresh tofu, as everyone says, is pretty awesome.  The non-soupy udon was my fave dish, the udon is hand pulled and has a different texture than the usual stuff you're used to.  That and the fizzy sour plum drink is what I'd come back for.  That fizzy plum drink, soooo good.
author: starrynight c.

description: So much fun! And everything was so yummy! We focused on the yakitori, next time we'll do the rest!
author: Pri S.

description:
Came to eat here after reading the Bon appetit article.. I saw a few people came in with their magazines.. A bit tacky :)

Reservations were hard so we requested a chef table.. Which i think is first come first serve.. And we lined up around 5:45 (15 minutes before opening) on a Thursday night.. We were able to hear seated by :6:15 or so..

We ordered:

hamachi sushi that was decent
Fried chicken- pass.. Not impressive
Miso Cod- really good and was in the article
Various Chicken yakitori - all were good.. Except the meatball.. I would skip that one
Homemade udon- this is a must order.. Handmade udon.. Yummy
Some patato croquette thing-good
Sake

All in the bill was 140 bucks for two people.. A bit pricy.. But the food was good to great..
author: John K.

description:
I was just unlucky because I know they must be good.
I reserved and put a note that we were celebrating a birthday. We still waited quite a while to be seated. Much of the menu, which is very small, was sold out. The "Shime" which are the rice or Udon which comes at the end of the meal, we were told we could order in advance but would be put on HOLD until the end, but it came right after the appetizers. I ordered the natto with rice and the rice was not cooked. It took a very very long time for the yakitori to get served. They were extremely apologetic and said we did not have to pay for the meal. I felt sorry for them, as they were embarrassed. Of course I paid but it was not a great experience.
author: Mariko T.

description:
Wow! we had great fun in this place. The food is amazing and you MUST try their homemade 
plum wine
author: Uriel C.

description:
I don't really see how this could be any better.

Beautiful restaurant, excellent service, and the best meal I've had in a very long time. Everything had so much flavor, was presented so beautifully, and the servers did an excellent job of explaining everything and making sure our large party had enough food.

seriously, you need to go here.
author: Ashley M.

description:
I was hoping to return to Rintaro for a five-star experience after they settled in, but sadly, went the other direction... I was excited to have an authentic Japanese izakaya with yakitori, but found on this second visit that they've dumbed it down to appeal to the masses. I don't blame them, they have to stay in business, and I remember my original review being at odds with other diners who penalized Rintaro for their authenticity.

Menu changes - no more chef's choice parts for yakitori. Straight list on the menu for two skewers each. Also got rid of the mentaiko dashimaki (think plain now, cod roe can be a bit much for a lot of folks) and no more yaki onigiri (grilled rice balls, totally awesome).

Thought it was odd that they ran out of tsukune (chicken meatballs) which I would have thought was the most common item to source and make.

They also forgot one of our order items, the age-tofu, a fairly light dish. We asked for the check because we were going to the symphony and they brought out the green peas croquette - it was actually quite good but the opposite style, full on fried heavy dish compared to the age-tofu... and odd dish as a complementary item.

Food is still good and I think it'd be a fun place for dinner, just comes off of my list of real Japanese places
author: Aki N.

description:
Eat something from each section of the menu! For my first time here we had: 

Swordfish sashimi - like the steak of sashimi!
Sunomono crab salad - super refreshing 
Hamachi sashimi - wowwwww 
Gyoza - oily but mouthwatering 
Pork Katsu - life changing 
Shrimp croquette - heavenly perfection 
4-5 yakitori (hearts and tsukune stood out) 

For my final dish i chose the Udon Carbonara and it was incredible because they hand roll their noodles! The chewiness of the noodle was technically perfect and it went well with the creaminess of the egg yolk. 

I can't wait to return!
author: Ryan B.

description: Best Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. Really.
author: Charlotte R.

description: Had both lunch and dinner here. The food is great but the dinner service is hit and miss. They really need to improve on that. The lunch food and service was great. Really enjoyed the outdoor seating on a warm day.
author: K. G.

description: This new spot is awesome. The special plum drinks are tart and delicious. We loved the halibut sashimi so much we ordered a second serving to pair with the steak and sashito peppers, green Beens two ways and omelette. Normally I don't like blocks of Japanese rolled egg but this was warm and hit the spot. For being the 5th night open then ambiance was perfect for a Friday date night and the serving staff was very accommodating. Can't wait to go back and bring friends!
author: Lozzy W.

description: Amazing izakaya spot and friendly chef! Recommend to sit by chef table so u can see how they master cooking the whole fish! Delicious!
author: Caroline T.

description:
A beautiful, sincere, heartful Yakitori joint that is so hidden in the middle of the city you have to know it's there, and even so you may have trouble finding it.

Rintaro takes over the former and burned down Chez Spencer, and before that, Citizen Cake -- both famous on the national dining and food TV scene, so big shoes to fill.

The vibe is modern wood frame industrial Japanese romantic chic, with pulsing music, little details everywhere, a completely open kitchen full of pots and casks and things familiar and not. It's designed to foster an immediacy and communication between customers, kitchen, manager, service staff: like a serious sushi restaurant but with chicken skewers and lots of fried things, not sushi. The design is very, very nice.

I only tried one thing, the tsukune (grilled chicken meatballs on a little wooden skewer) served on a nice plate with a little pile of unusually tasty shichimi. The chicken is from Riverdog Farm (http://www.yelp.com/biz/riverdog-farm-guinda), the Binchōtan (white charcoal, steamed at over 2000 degrees, invented several hundred years ago) is imported from Japan, there is no flour or egg or any other binding in the meatballs, they are made 50/50 of an especially coarse grind plus a second finer grind almost like eating little chicken nibblets. Most all ingredients here are organic, sourced from specific farms or bought at the local farmers markets. Let's just say, a lot of thought went into everything on the menu.

The boiled peanut table condiment is the best I've ever had. Edamame begone, I could make a meal of that.

Prices are reasonable for this style of restaurant: $5.50-$6.50 for each chicken skewer, other apps at $5-10 a few larger plates at $15-20. This is food to go with beer, sake, soju, and good company.

A special shout out to the men's room, one of the nicest in town, thanks to a classic Japanese design and a lighting fixture that shoots little shadows out across two pi radians, it's a place of meditation and comfort.

It was only the second day of service (after a soft opening the week before) and I want to try more before giving it five stars. It could go either way, but there is a lot of promise here.
author: Gil S.

description:
俳句 居酒屋 

individual dishes so carefully composed

locally sourced organic seasonal mantra sonic pitch

loud pop music hurts ears
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Loved the ambiance and the traditional wooden decor. Sadly, the food was good but not exceptional. Maybe it was just the menu that day, as I know it changes frequently. 
They also don't have too many non-meat options outside of the salads, and I was left hungry.
author: Nancy Z.

description: This is such a special restaurant. You can see the amount of care and attention to detail that went into the design of the space and that goes into the crafting of each dish. I imagine everything here tastes amazing, but don't skip the yakitori.
author: Casey P.

description:
Agreed with previous reviewer - this is my favorite izakaya in sf right now.

The skewers are all excellent. Nice char outside, smoky and smell of meat fat, juicy inside. Favorites are: kanzuri (only seen on the menu recently, so delicious!), chicken breast, thigh with negi, shoulder blade, duck (no other izakaya in sf does duck this well), heart. They used to have grilled chicken skin, but now only fried chicken skin- please bring back the grilled skin!

All other dishes are also excellent except for the tofu that has come last during our meal. Would be better as a starter.

Food comes in beautiful dishware. Especially the light dishes and sauces. 

Space is cozy and cute. Great place for a date.
author: Sarah L.

description: Always on the hunt for yakitori, izakaya, charcoal smoked meats...all that good stuff!! Surprisingly not that many in SF.  A few good ones sprinkled around the Bay Area though.  Found this place on Yelp and went for a walk in at opening.  They were fully booked but accommodated us at the bar if we were finished in an hour.  Turned out perfect.  Sat in front of the grill master and got our food and drinks quick!  They didn't have any beef but I loved most everything we got.  The good stuff was all off the grill.  Duck Breast, gizzard, thigh+scallion, mushrooms...I could've sat there for bit eating sticks drinking sake and Japanese wheat beer.  It was pit stop eating though...which is just as well.  Feeling pretty good on exit.  The two items that were good but kinda average was the Ebi and Katsu.  Can't wait to go back
author: Ramon L.

description: The skewers were decent.  The fried yam made me really queasy!  Blech.  The udon was really great though.  It also felt overpriced in that I paid $30 for these little tapas.
author: Niniane W.

description:
We decided to go with small plates. This may have been a fatal mistake, as the small plates felt more like "amuse-bouche", interesting but relatively insubstantial. The crudités with miso paste were fine and the tofu was fine. The chicken skewers were relatively flavorless, and not so fine. The tuna sashimi was fantastic. Our "dinner", amounting to three amuse-bouches and maybe 4 bites of one yummy sashimi added up to $50.  

Ok. The rant. I really, really, really wish Yelp diners would routinely reveal if someone else paid for their dinner. I could rave about this place if I was dining on an expense account, but seeing how I paid for it personally, three stars. The overall value proposition was poor. After spending $50 here, we both ate a second dinner later in the evening.
author: T S.

description: Made reservations and came here with two friends to split some dishes; we got a lovely booth. I love the decor and service was decent. I would highly recommend it as a date place if you're looking to impress. However, I find the prices a bit unnecessarily high, because the portions are tiny. The menu is very fish-heavy (duh, Japanese). I left satisfied-full (but not overly so), with $40 less in my pocket but nothing I had was life changing. I'd recommend it to friends to try but am not dying to come back again.
author: Melissa T.

description: Excellent food. Polite and efficient service. A lot of the staff is Japanese, so don't expect them to engage in a lot of banter. It's not typical in Japan to do that, so they're not going to flirt and crack jokes with you. The interior is really nice. A bit expensive but not crazy. Overall, a pretty authentic Japanese experience.
author: El G.

description: One of the best meals I have had in San Francisco, and an exquisite take on izakaya. I lived in Japan for 7 years and this is where I go when I am homesick for the delicious food in Tokyo.
author: Caroline G.

description: Chef Brakett has created an homage to all good things Japanese with his own inventive narrative.  This is much more than an izakaya.  We've visited three times, each time a unique and satisfying experience.  Inquire about any specials...their yakitori are just hands down great.  Shingiku sarada was ethereal.  If you're lucky enough, try the hand pulled udon to close your meal.
author: Mike O.

description: I think I found my new favorite Izakaya restaurant. Everything we had was excellent. I've seen some reviews about this place indicating the long time it took to get their food. They obviously don't understand the concept of a good Izakaya type restaurant. It's not really a place to go alone. It's a place to go with friends or a date. You drink, and you order food.....plain and simple. It's not a place to rush, it's a place to take your time, enjoy your friends or in my case, my date, and most importantly, it's a place to enjoy excellent plates of food. I would recommend this this place for anyone wanting to try new experiences......excellent food!!!
author: Troy H.

description: Service could be better. The food, however could not. Wow. You want the dashi maki tamago, any of the vegetable dishes and some iteration of whole fish.  The chicken hearts were bomb as well.
author: Michael L.

description: Third time here.  I had big hopes for this place.  They had everything they need to be the best izakaya in SF. Authentic decor and food but with a cali twist. Super friendly and attentive staff, many of which Japanese speaking. Lively open kitchen thats a joy to watch. First time was phenomenal, second time was just good, third time was just disappointing.  The Ika salad was the only great dish we had, although very small. Delicate and refreshing with an awesome sweet wasabi inspired dressing. 3rd time having the Chizu Tori Katsu. Such a unique dish and loved it the first time. This time around the panko crust was basically the main attraction.  The chicken breast was almost non-existent and completely separated from the crust. 3 of the pieces were literally only panko crust. The salad seemed to be a bland shredded diakon instead of the dressed and flavorful cabbage and shiso it came with the first time. The yakitori skewers- Thighs too tightly packed, great flavor on outside, but when you separate the pieces and bite in, bland chicken. Breast pieces were too small, thus dried out and a bit chewy (the yuzo kosho on the side was very nice though). This was the first time we tried the UDON, great presentation but definitely lacking any real depth of flavors. Everything needed more love, care, and then some consistency. I really liked you guys! I hope this was just a fluke.
author: S M.

description:
I want to like this place. I really do. But I don't. 

The decor is gorgeous. The entryway and outdoor patio is a dark and mysterious space, quite conducive to conversation while you wait for your table. 

Inside, the white, joined wood makes for a gorgeous view. You'll enjoy it while you're eating.

Sadly, the carpet doesn't match the drapes, if you catch my drift. 

The meat of the matter. Mediocre. Benign. Not bad. Not good either. Carefully and artfully presented. Some nice tastes, but damned expensive for blah. Don't settle. 

You'll want to go early as I've noticed on both times I've been that they tend to run out of many things on the menu. 

Come for a drink and pre-dinner snack, but eat elsewhere.
author: Mickey D.

description:
Service could be better. we were a party of 3 at 5:30pm and came in with a line, but they wanted to seat us at the bar b/c they wanted to save the tables for 4-tops. Luckily my 2 colleagues were aggressive and insisted on a table. There was at least 1 empty table after we ate (so they could've spared the table)

Then they were SLOW to take our order. (if they wanted to turn the table over, they should take our order ASAP). Then they served our food in the wrong order (they served the rice dish first)... In an Izakaya, (they usually serve the rice dish last, b/c it is filling, and they want to sell more food) and there was a LARGE delay between most of our dishes and the egg dish (they forgot we had it, we forgot we had it) We had ordered dessert and then they said "oh, you still have the egg dish" Delays in filling tea and water.

the food - yummy! Everything was good. 
the chicken on a stick - yummy - with green onion, with plum
the duck on a stick - a little spicy, 
the egg dish - yummy, we ordered the LARGE, too much egg for 3 people
the rice dish - yummy, thick broth, very satisfying "home food"
kabocha croquettes - yummy! great way to get me to eat a veggie.

the decor - VERY nice for an izakaya. reminiscent of a great place I know in NYC. Nice bathroom!

neighborhood sketchy. parking difficult.
author: Sophia Y.

description: This place is amazing. Absolutely beautiful, traditional ambiance. Excellent service and incredibly delicious Yakitori. I recommend this hidden gem to anyone seeking a true Izakaya experience. Don't sleep, this place is going to blow up.
author: D V.

description:
Such a pretty atmosphere. Everyone was incredibly attentive. Food was excellent. The thigh and scallions was delicious.

Definitely going back.
author: Galen C.

description:
my wife and i cautiously reserved a spot for tonight's donabe dinner as we had a not-so-pleasant experience during our first visit to rintaro. as a backdrop, our first time here was wrought with service that was lacking (no napkins, little to no explanation of dishes, rushed pacing of courses) just to name a few of the missteps. nonetheless, we reserved for 2 at 6:45pm.
