upon entering, we were warmly greeted and sat at the bar. the gentleman behind the bar area promptly served our sake orders. and then the barrage began. we were served the first four courses within 20 minutes. churn much? we had a deja vu moment from the first time we came here. for us, dining out is a relaxed experience where one savors the kitchen's creations, enjoys conversation and melts into the ambience. these experiences are not conducive to rintaro. we felt rushed, could not even enjoy the food and wanted to get out as quickly as possible.

there were some aspects of the evening that were positive; the knowledgeable and friendly guy behind the bar, the rice course and sake selection were high points. but these could not redeem the lack of service and pacing attention that we experienced.
author: Rob D.

description: The food was equally beautiful and delicious, the venue warm and cosy and the staff was helpful and friendly. Totally deserves 5 stars
author: Olivia M.

description: That's it Rintaro, you got me. You pushed me over the edge with your deliciousness and now I finally have to write about it. This place is frikken awesome. I have eaten at Rintaro three times now and have yet to order something that I didn't like. The menu from top to bottom is rock solid, particularly the udon noodles (which I could eat every day), and having Asahi on tap never hurts. I don't consider myself a dessert guy but if you go there it is a must, I repeat, A MUST that you order one (or all).
author: Kyle P.

description: Unique intimate Japanese restaurant with nice outdoor eating space - nothing fancy but high quality food and attentive service - we particularly loved the soft tofu dish, the miso cod sunomono, as well as the variety of skewers (trumpet mushrooms, okra, duck as well as the more classic chicken/meatballs.
author: Jeff H.

description:
We love this place. We have been eating there regularly since it opened.

The decor is very Japanese. It really reminds me of some of the dives under the railway tracks in Hibiya (except for the lack of smoking). The handmade wooden pieces add a touch of authenticity.

The food is varied, and delicate. Even something as simple as Tamago (egg) becomes a gourmet delicacy. There are many items you won't find on the menu in a typical Japanese restaurant in the US, only in Izakayas such as Rintaro: sardines "Southern Barbarian" style (sorry, Portuguese); whole fried or roast fish. The yakitori chef really knows his business.

You can sit in a booth, or on stools in front of the kitchen counter and watch the chefs at their work. There is also a back room, if you have a large party. Heck, even going to the bathroom is an aesthetic experience!

Finish off your meal with one (or more) of the three desserts on the menu. The pastry chef is amazing, and sometimes you can watch her at work. Panna Cotta, mochi, fruit, whatever, she knows how to turn it into a delicious dessert.

Now, the restaurant is not cheap. If you want some low-cost sushi, look elsewhere. This is a completely different experience, and Sylvan, the owner is a master at his craft. What you pay for is what you get.

My only complaint is ... the background music. I'm probably just showing my age. Fortunately, it's not so loud that it's overwhelming, as it is in some restaurants.

Highly recommended.
author: Jeremy E.

description:
came here on a Thurs night without a reservation and they managed to squeeze us into the bar with no wait at all!  Highly recommend the bar seating so you can watch the chefs.  One of them even showed me how they shaved (homemade) bonito. 

The food was excellent.  We got: 

liver yakitori (SO GOOD, must get)
homemade tofu (very smooth and creamy, texture of greek yogurt)
grilled trout for 2 (huge portion) 
grilled salmon head (should not have gotten two grilled dishes because they tasted pretty similar) 
karaage- crispy but a little sweet for my taste
uni rice bowl- pretty normal dish 

Looks like their menu changes a lot because some dishes friends had recommended were not available.  

 At about $95, this was more than enough food for 2.  I am definitely coming back to try everything else.
author: T Y.

description: My partner and I ate here over the weekend. Not bad. Extremely slow service, but all of the employees were super friendly. Note to owner: Get some heat in that place!
author: Anthony B.

description: Went back to Rintaro last night with my girlfriend for their Peko Peko popup in the courtyard.  Had chicken meatballs on skewers and two refreshing Asahis.  The staff came by and adjusted the radiant heaters so we'd be warm.  Excellent food and service.   I really like the unadorned simplicity of this place, and in a town of overly rich food items, it refreshing to eat treats from here that are simple, refined and fresh.
author: Jonathan b.

description: Amazing!!! Delicious with the best service. Could return again and again for the silken tofu and rock cod.   Went with a party of 4 and I think we tried everything in the menu.  Nothing disappointed.  Expensive but highly recommended!
author: Daniela S.

description: It was good for a one-time experience, but not the type of restaurant I would find myself coming back to often. Everything seemed fresh and was well prepared. Service was good besides waiting at the door for 10 minutes to actually sit down (we had a reservation, but their systems were down ... really?). The cocktails here were a highlight! The matcha one and passion fruit one were just delicious. We got an assortment of dishes, including sashimi, seafood, chicken, tofu, and udon. Everything was good. My BF particularly enjoyed the skewers and sashimi. Since I am a picky eater, I had a hard time finding things on the menu, but if you are more open, it's definitely enjoyable. The only dish I definitely would have skipped was the tofu ... it was good, but it's just a hunk of homemade tofu so you reeeeally need to like plain tofu. Damage was around $100 for two (pre-tip). Definitely a solid bet for the Mission.
author: Cara R.

description: This restaurant was named for Michelin picks 2016 cheap eats in SF.  No doubt they used the highest ingredients possible but it just didn't do it for me.  We had a big party of 11(including 2 toddlers) so we tried a variety of items on the menu.  Must haves: persimmon salad & tofu? Can't really think of anything else. All skewers were on the salty side.  Had to ask them to tone down on the salt. Hand rolled noodles were lacking flavor. After spending $50/person, we all had to go n get burgers since we were still hungry.  I think I will stick with Sumika in Los Altos.
author: Chloe H.

description:
I feel like w/ izakayas you never have one "hella" good experience.  This type of dining is all about the drinking and small bar bites.  We took our newlywed friends visiting from NY since we thought it'd be a fun experience.  First of all it's totally hidden so unless you have the address handy you could totally miss it.  

We shared a bunch of things - 
- crispy fried sole - wasn't easy taking it apart and it was just ok.  lacking some flavor
- yakitori - skin, thigh & breast w/ wasabi.  They ran out of the thigh and that was the best of the 3
- gyoza sounded delicious but it wasn't spectacularly different from any other one you've had

I'm pretty sure we ordered other things but I can't remember.  Unfortunately maybe not that memorable.  I was bummed they didn't offer the uni donburi and tamago on the menu.  And they were also out of the yaki onigiri :(

For dessert we shared the yuzu cheesecake and some other thing - both were unique and tasty.
author: Meredith K.

description: I was disappointed by our experience at Rintaro given the hype.  The food and service were both just okay.  The service was fast, and pleasant - but not very helpful in interpreting the menu (which is not straightforward) or how we should order.  We received our food very fast, but with no explanation of how to eat it - multiple bowls and extras but no idea how they should go together.  The food itself we found bland, but cooked nicely.  The silken tofu was a bland, grainy chunk of tofu with a fishy soy sauce on the side.  We had two Yakitori - the meatballs were flavorless and gristly, but the lamb was nice.  The Oden was very nice, a flavorful broth with perfect fish cakes.  The highlight was the green tea panne cotta, this had interesting earthy slightly sweet flavor and a silky texture.
author: Rachel P.

description: One of the best chicken wings I've ever had - the pepper makes your mouth a bit tingly and it's awesome. The whole fish is fun to eat but my favorites were the fish cake and the cocktails.
author: Nancy J.

description: This place is amazing. The decor and woodwork is beautiful. The pottery is unique. Everyone was super friendly. The food is realllllly good. Yakitori was flavorful and juicy. Soup was hot ,spicy and delicious. Corn croquettes were golden crispy and had a perfect balance of savory and sweet. I didn't find it over priced at all. Take time to enjoy each bite. Lots of love in the food and restaurant. Thanks for a great experience!
author: Francisco V.

description: Authentic atmosphere! Almost feels like a trip to Japan. Everything was delicious and it was great to have the opportunity to eat liver skewers (not everywhere). Last but not least, the chiffon cake for desert was amazingly fluffy, almost like eating a sweet cloud. I recommend!
author: Melanie P.

description: San Francisco needed a restaurant like this.  I could see why the menu would be intimidating/unusual for people that don't know authentic Japanese food.  But I have many great things to say about the space, staff, and menu.
author: Benjamin M.

description: Really enjoy this place, they have the freshest ingredients, you just know you are getting quality food and service. I recommend this place.
author: Steven D.

description:
I love this place. Have been there several times now and it's become my favorite secret little spot in the Mission/SOMA area. It's a little off the beaten path (same block as Rainbow Grocery). The entry is a gated area with a lovely little courtyard in the front and you almost wouldn't know the place existed unless, well, you do. 

Rintaro itself is one of the loveliest spaces in the city, warm and intimate but not at all pretentious. It also smells fantastic because of all the wood elements. I love taking people there because most of them don't know about it and they're always surprised that such an amazing little place exists. 

The menu itself is always fantastic. They change things up somewhat every day so there are always new things to try out on each visit. Also, I've been going there since they opened in Fall 2014 and it just keeps getting better. Today was my favorite meal to date. BTW, I've been hesitant to write a review because I don't want Rintaro to become impossible to get into. But, that's kind of a selfish reason. 

We ordered:

1. Japanese fried chicken. Phenomenal and I hope that becomes a mainstay on the menu if it isn't already. I would have ordered more if I didn't need to save room for other things. I'm not very good at eating chicken or other meat items that involve bones (textural phobia), but I ate the heck out of these things. I do not ordinarily manage to leave behind clean bones; I did with these. A dubious accomplishment, but nevertheless, one that I'm proud of.

2. Cucumbers with a miso type of sauce/dressing for dipping. Probably the weakest dish of the night but still damn tasty and refreshing, plus, needed to eat some some kind of veggie in an effort to pretend to eat healthily. 

3. Croquettes with chicken and wagon wheel cheese and tonkatsu sauce on the side. Perfectly fried and super tasty. They also sometimes have curry potato croquettes and I love those equally as much. 

3. Udon noodle soup with duck and egg. This is a new item on the menu (or at least one that wasn't on the menu on previous visits). The noodles are made by hand and while I'm not normally a noodle person (more into the broth, usually), they were delicious and chewy. Broth was amazing. 

4. Tamago. More flavorful and savory than most tamago (and I say that as someone who almost always orders tamago when I go to a Japanese restaurant). Sylvan, the chef, has been making them for decades and has basically mastered the shit out of them. 

5. DESSERTS! You wouldn't expect an izakaya to have amazing desserts but RIntaro does. A must order, even if you're not normally into sweets/desserts. Their dessert chef used to work at State Bird Provisions and received a Michelin Star when she was there. Today we had a spicy strawberry sorbet (hard to describe, but evoked strawberry pop rocks in the best possible way) and the green tea (matcha?) panna cotta, which was one of the silkiest panna cottas I've ever had. 

I went with just one other person today so that was all we had room for on this visit. Will absolutely be going back.
author: Maya B.

description: My friend is friend of owner so they recommend me to visit. Today was my birthday. I was very upset. I took reservation but waited for 30 mins to be ready. The table they reserved for us was counter. I was assuming to have regular table because this was first time to visit. When I explained the situation to waitress, she said I should have wrote table preference in note section of online reservation system. Again, this was first time and did not know. Instead of apologizing, they are telling me what I should have done. Unprofessional  attitude. I do not recommend if you are looking for great services. Food was great but they need to train hostess and waitress how to speak to customers.
author: Shinya M.

description:
Ambiance is great. Service is OK although they can be a little slow. None of the dishes blew us away, but everything was good and flavorful. The whole fried fish was a little greasier than we'd wanted it, in contrast to what we'd heard from some other reports. Prices are reasonable but portions are small so you'll rack up a substantial bill if you come with an appetite.

No reservations for parties smaller than 4, and there are often moderate waits even at off times.
author: David C.

description:
I came with high expectations after seeing this place on the Bon Appetite top 50 new restaurants. Decor is straight out of Shabuya and looks authentic. Menu is full of all the favorites from a neighborhood izakaya for a reasonable price. Waitstaff is friendly and seated us immediately (with a prior reservation booked 3 weeks ago). Waitress quickly placed the order and brought out cold drafts. 

Everything is great until the food was served. We ordered 5 assorted yakitori servings which took about 20 minutes to arrive (not a problem) but alarmingly all arrived together. The fatal flaw here is each skewer takes a different amount of time to cook so there is almost no way for a busy restaurant to prepare and plate 5 different items at exactly the same time. Every other yakitori place I've visited brings out each order individually as they are ready. At Rintaro, the first cooked orders sit for an extended amount of time waiting for the remainder of the order to be ready. As a result the breast came out dry, the thigh meat was rubbery, and the chicken meatball had mushed together. Four of the five orders came out only slightly warm as the dagger in the disappointing meal. 

The concept of yakitori is highlighting the unique characteristics of each part of the chicken as individual pieces through meticulous preparation. Rintaro spoiled that with very flawed execution. 

Following the yakitori disaster we placed an order for katsu which was so delicious that we ordered a second. This does not boost the rating because a KFC can also make great fried chicken. 

I'm truly disappointed. I was looking forward to loving this place and having yakitori that was elevated to the next level.
author: D R.

description:
Beautiful restaurant interior. Got the croquettes -- which were amazing, the gyoza, which were pretty good, the livers on a stick (also brilliant) and the special that night, which turned out to be a real stinker -- fresh tuna served over rice in a way that made the tuna mushy, diced, and unremarkable. 
Not much in the way of food for vegetarians here, FYI.
author: Hawley S.

description: I never have had device deserving so much of a five star review view. I have been to plenty of Micheline rated restaurants and they could take a page from the book from here. The food is fantastic, we were almost convinced we walked into a small restaurant in Japan. I will definitely come here again and recommend to all of my friends.
author: Philippe H.

description:
My takeaways in two points:

1) this is not really authentic Japanese food although it seems to try to be.

2) I am not going to trust any top 10 list now, after I never really trust Michelin rating.  


The carpentry is definitely amazing.  Even in the dim night light,  the architectural plainness and subtlety still intertwine and shine nicely.   It is definitely different from a usual hipster place.  

We sat at the chefs counter just to appreciate the art of the chefs.   The owner, the head chef,  was in the center of the open kitchen, carefully and artistically displaying his skills as a chef.  I saw him peel a daikon (one of the godly existences in Japanese cuisine) with a probably a Japanese chef's knife smoothly and beautifully.   He also used the same knife on a bonito fish, and sliced it into different chunks.   He looks serene, focused, and comfortable - I am sure that this ease with the eaters' observations came after practice or the self-consciousness to overcome self-consciousness itself.  
 

When you see "izakaya" in the name of a restaurant, which means an informal drinking and dining place after work for Japanese, you certainly expect more informality and more authenticity in the food.  Unfortunately, this is not the case with what we ordered.   We ordered fried chicken wings, a Yoshoku dish (Yoshoku means "western/foreign food" in Japanese and has Japanese variations of the western fried food and Indian curry, etc.).     We ordered yakitori, a Japanese culinary gem that is definitely undervalued in the American restaurant scene.      The last order was Teuchi Udon  - it is a statement made by the restaurant since they want to present handmade udon instead of already popular and haphazardly ramen.   

Ironically, what turned out to be the most impressive is the fried chicken wings, the Yoshoku/western food, since, well, obviously, it is made here by the western chefs.   The udon's soup base tastes pretty much just like soy sauce and lacks the flavor of fish broth.     The yakitori, which was so highly looked forward to, turned out to be quite ordinary -- the duck meat tastes like western steak meat.  It is between reasonably tender and reasonably chewy - but nothing special or Japanese about it besides being skewed.   The chicken breast skewer is pretty much tasteless and a little bit overcooked to our standard.   We do like the ume sauce (plum sauce) on it but wish it could have been more delicately spread on instead of being a drop.  

We did not order any sashimi or other things based on our sampling of these three orders, which did not turn out to be amazing.    It is a young restaurant and you could see that the menu is very carefully set up and seems to have a limited variety at this point.  We expected very authentic Japanese food, which is especially presented by its (fish) broth and unique handling with meat, and it did not turn out that way.   I would also suggest that the light be brighter so as to reflect better the carpentry as a great asset of the restaurant.    The front yard is very cute -  some shallots and chestnuts still in their spiky shells in two separate bamboo baskets are placed separately.   Little details like this are important.  However, while the food was served in wooden bowls and other Japanese-style ceramic containers, the chopsticks we have got are the typical dispensable chopsticks, which do not match the aesthetics or intention of this restaurant at all.   It could be a cost-saving issue, but then it certainly makes this restaurant seem overly priced then,  which serves 2 cubes of chicken breast on a skewer for $7.

I could be a bit harsh on this restaurant.  Yet since I am a passionate cook and passionate about Japanology,  I could not help thinking that right now it is not the right time to try too much food there.   However, this opinion could be biased, since I did not order some of the Japanese favorites and bests listed on the menu, such as sashimi, a salad with persimmon vinegar (they have a typo on their online menu which says "vinega"),   daikon, japanese mushrooms ... 

It is a nice bustling vibe, yet not nice enough to make me feel completely un-self-conscious.  :)  If you know what I mean.
author: Shuting Z.

description: Torn between 3 and 4 stars for this place. Based on the quality of food and the high price gonna have to give it 3 stars. Everything we ate bordered on good/OK but nothing was amazing or had flavors I hadn't tasted before. We got both sashimi dishes and those were decent. The fried chicken wings were crispy but lacked flavor/seasoning. We tried the meatball, duck, chicken thigh skewers and again not a lot of flavor. The persimmon salad was really good. Maybe we just didn't order the right things??? The ambiance of the place was cool and service was fine. I was just expecting more....
author: Brittney E.

description:
Incredible dining experience! The interior is so gorgeous and inviting, which makes for the most lovely dining experience. 

More importantly the food is superb. Surprising, fresh, tasty, and so satisfying... an overall delight. It is the kind of restaurant you leave feeling perfectly content and in awe of the artful meal you've just consumed.

Truthfully everything we ate was amazing. Absolutely FAVORITES were: Kabocha Korokke (curry kabocha croquettes with snowy cabbage) and Keihan (rice with chicken broth, poached breast, shiso and ribbon egg) which I would not have expected to be as outstanding as it was, but our whole table absolutely LOVED it. 

I cannot recommend Rintaro enough! Order everything on the menu if you can. 
Oh, and be sure to get the plum wine!
author: Erin L.

description:
When Vincent K. asked the BF and I if we wanted to eat dinner, we jumped at the chance. Knowing that we wanted Japanese food, our options were limited -- that is, unless we were willing to wait. Orenchi Beyond came up as an idea, but please see aforementioned regarding wait time.

Then, the BF reminded me of Chef Val Cantu's suggestion from our dinner at Californios the weekend prior and we decided to check our Izakaya Rintaro. We were a bit disappointed upon arrival to find we would have to wait 40 minutes for a table; thinking on our feet, we quickly drove over to Ken Ken Ramen to see if their seating was any better but no such luck. Having killed 15-20 minutes by this time, we drove back to Rintaro and luckily, some space cleared up in the front by the bar for the 3 of us. I was seated in a slightly awkward position, being in the middle of 2 differently leveled bar tops, but I managed to get by.

Unlike other restaurants that call themselves Izakaya and don't actually serve tapa style bites, Rintaro hits the nail on the head. Chungah behind the bar ended up serving us as they were quite busy and likely wanted to reserve table tops for larger groups (speculating based on other reviews I've read). She took our drink orders and placed small dishes of pickled herring before us to munch on as we reviewed the menu. Here's what we ended up ordering:

+ hanetsuki gyoza - pork potstickers, made from scratch. Beautiful presentation with a nice, chewy consistency on the dough with a flavorful pork filling. 
- yakitori tsukune - chicken meatballs; extremely tender, but I tasted lemongrass and not being a fan of that particular flavor, wouldn't call this one my favorite.
+ liver - likely the best grilled liver I've ever had that was remained tender (and wasn't overcooked to a rubbery texture)
 + tender + wasabi - this was medium rare! Small dollops of wasabi tracked the chicken skewer which were a nice touch. 
- thigh + scallion - neutral on this dish; I bit the scallion off the skewer and the inside layers of it flew out which was a bit embarrassing for me.
+ kabocha croquettes - breading and fry was made to perfection; I wish I could use that breading on everything.
+ keihan - rice with chicken broth, chicken breast, and shredded egg. Extremely hearty and great for a cold day. Lots of flavor which I imagine is due to reducing the broth to achieve it's rich and dark color. We were also given a 2nd bowl because someone had misordered, gratis!
+ tamago - large order; light and fluffy, the chef has apparently been mastering his tamago skills for several years. Served with a topping of minced radish on the side for texture.

They were out of the yosedofu (silken tofu), skin yakitori, chanterelle mushrooms, and the fried swordfish, which was disappointing. I guess next time we need to get there earlier!
 
What elevated our experience was sitting at the bar, talking to Chungah about the restaurant. She made what would likely have been a good dining experience, into an extraordinary night. Her cousin runs the restaurant with the chef, who previously worked under Alice Waters of Chez Panisse, and she shared some additional background about the restaurant style and philosophy. 

Chez Spencer used to inhabit this space, but they never reopened after a fire broke out. In fact, Rintaro kept some of the burnt wood from the fire and incorporated it into the restaurant design. Len Brackett, a well-renowned architect, had saved the cedar wood used for the bar and table tops for years and years, but finally let Rintaro's owner use it to design the restaurant. What's even more impressive is that the cedar wood hasn't been oiled and was made smooth by a Japanese planing beam. The brass bars in the bathroom and bar area were built by Chungah herself. These small touches, beautiful atmosphere, and attentive service along with the well-executed food made for a great night with the BF and old roomie. Will definitely be back and looking forward to using the outdoor area in the future!
author: Johanna L.

description:
love this place.

came with some japanese colleagues, who did all the ordering.

the dishes i remember:

tamago (sweet, fluffy egg)
whole grilled fish
grilled nigiri
a bunch of yakitori
hojicha panna cotta

very friendly and polite servers. one of our dishes came out under-cooked and they replaced it ASAP, no attitude and no questions asked.

the wood interiors really create a warm and cozy japanese-style atmosphere... stepping out onto the sidewalk i had almost forgotten where i was.

they have limited quantities of yakitori, so come early-ish if there's something specific you want to try.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Went in with really high expectations but the meal ended up being a mix of highs & lows, hence the 3 stars.

Let me just start by saying that the restaurant itself is beautiful.  Tons of visually stimulating elements and handmade wood work - a welcome change from the cookie-cutter rustic restaurant design everyone seems to be copying these days.

DRINK: the house sake ($19 for a carafe) was delicious and a great deal.  We got about 4 glasses out of the carafe, so priced otherwise at $8/glass, the carafe is definitely the way to go!

FOOD: This is where things were either major hits or major misses...we had the following:

Liberty Duck & Persimmon Salad (4/5) - generous portion, the persimmons' sweetness went perfectly with the medium-rare thinly sliced duck breast, slightly overdressed/salty but still very enjoyable way to start the meal.

Housemade Silken Tofu (3/5) - texture was very creamy, almost cheese-like but without the tang.  accompanied by freshly grated ginger, scallions, & bonito flakes.  I guess tasty for what it was, but really just too boring.

Yakitori - we ordered two skewers, chicken meatballs (5/5) and breast with ume (3/5), both were cooked perfectly, juicy and delicious.  definitely preferred the meatballs and wished we had ordered more of those.

Chicken Katsu (5/5) - hands down the best dish of the night, I could eat this every day!  not your traditional katsu in that they stuff the chicken with cheese, almost like the french cordon bleu. but damn, that panko breading was perfectly fried and the impossibly juicy chicken was magic!

Braised Pork Belly (3/5) - this dish could benefit from a better description on the menu.  I expected something more of a stew consistency with succulent chunks of pork belly. instead you get a plate with a piece of belly that has been stewed already, but has no sauce and served with a poached egg and some boiled turnip.  the dish was hard to eat with chopsticks, pork belly was dry and at $15 the dish is way overpriced.

Matsutake Gohan (1/5) - we ended the meal with this dish, listed in the "Final Dish" section of the menu and I really wish we hadn't!  As a closer for an otherwise decent meal, this was an embarrassing dish for a restaurant of this caliber to serve.  It was essentially a clay pot filled with rice and about sliced matsutake mushrooms.  No broth, no scallions, no ginger...no flavor.  $15 for some rice and a mushroom.  We took two bites and left the rest.

Total price for 2 people (tax+sf surcharge+tip) = $135

Despite the inconsistency on some of the dishes, I would probably go back because there were several other dishes coming out of the kitchen next to me that looked worth trying.  The sashimis were beautiful and the chicken wings (and probably anything else being panko breaded and fried) are probably amazing.
author: R S.

description: Fantastic!! Lovely new interior, great wait staff, great intro to real Japanese food. Fabulous--I would recommend this place as being reasonably priced, very fresh foods & a great change from the overly designed, precious places in SF. i had an easy time parking on 14th as well.
author: Freda S.

description: We had a great time here on our anniversary. Yakitori was so good...husband wouldn't let me get the gizzards, so i'll have to go back! Gyoza so tasty... we lived in Tokyo for years; really miss that yakitori feel... and the greeting as you enter irashai mase...arigato! in our neighborhood as well... loved Chez Spencer too.  So happy to have this place .... Chez Spencer would be pleased!
author: Amanda J.

description:
I am often hesitant to visit brand-new restaurants, since it sometimes takes a while for the staff and kitchen to hit a groove. Not so with Rintaro--I visited a few nights after they opened, and was treated to one of the best and most memorable meals I've ever had in San Francisco. 

The food is extraordinary--this is izakaya-style food, yes, but utterly unlike the stuff you're used to. It manages to be delicate and sophisticated but also extremely comforting and filling--and, hey, great with beer and sake. The chef's gyoza are the best I've ever had, as is the sashimi and whole fried fish. I am not a vegetarian but if I were I would come here just for the kabocha squash croquettes, which are a freaking miracle.

The space is one of the most beautiful in the city--it smells like fresh wood, and the bar is (amazingly!) carved out of a single huge piece of cedar. The open kitchen and friendly staff made the entire experience feel very comfortable and personal. It was too cold to sit outside on their gorgeous patio, but rest assured, I will be back once the rain stops to enjoy some snacks and a drink.
author: Emily T.

description:
while we enjoyed our experience and the food, it was somewhat expensive
The food was good---but NOT a caliber for the Bon Appetit rating of ## 8 in the country
The Bay area has many more 'way better' Japanese restaurants of all kinds
author: Sheri S.

description: Possibly the best food I've ever eaten.  We got almost everything on the menu and it was all amazing.  The staff are all friendly and the food comes piping hot.  So goooood!
author: Steve A.

description: We made a reservation for 9 pm and were not seated until 9:45! The staff were very flip about the long wait and gave us tiny 2-sip beers as compensation while we awkwardly stood by hostess stand. Only after I complained did the staff seem a bit more accommodating. Also found out they were out of some dishes we wanted when we got to our table. The pork katsu was basically a block of fat deep-fried. The rest of the dishes were fine, but nothing spectacular. Skip it.
author: Maya S.

description: This is my first and only time writing a review for a place, and unfortunately it's not the best one for Rintaro. I have dined here multiple times before, and it was one of my favorite restaurants in the city. The food is amazing and the service has always been good, I always sit at the bar so sometimes it's tough to flag down your server, but usually it works out. The food is usually so good that it makes any service issues irrelevant! However tonight I had an experience that has ruined the restaurant for me. I decided to come here for my birthday dinner with my girlfriend. We sat at the bar and everything was fine while we placed our order. However halfway through the meal I received a dish I had not ordered(I believe the server had been a little confused about a question I had asked),and I mentioned it to the server. She insisted that I had ordered it but reluctantly took it away. I saw that it became an issue in the kitchen, when the manager and one of the chefs was discussing what to do about the dish. From what I heard it sounded like they thought I had ordered the dish, and just chosen not to accept it when it was brought by. However that was not the case. Throughout the meal our food has been paced moderately, with us receiving one or two dishes at a time. However after this mixup we receive the rest of our order all at once. Three large dishes brought at the same time to share between me and my girlfriend, and to boot one of the dishes is supposed to be a finishing dish to be enjoyed at the end of the meal. Unfortunately the Udon was cold by the time we got to it, and our appetites were overwhelmed by the amount of food in front of us. I just hope in the future the server does not take out her frustration on a guest who is trying to celebrate his birthday with his girlfriend, and ruin the rest of his dinner. It's unfortunate because I loved this restaurant, however I doubt I will be going back again.
author: Sarim T.

description: My wife and I dined here on Friday night and had a great time.  Others have already commented on the beautiful interior and food, so I won't add much there other than we fully agree.  We sat at the bar and got a great view of all of the stuff being made from scratch.  One guy was in charge of the udon, another guy the whole fish, another guy the yakitori station.  A well manged concert.  Not a lot of talking, just real chefs/cooks doing their jobs and doing it well.  I will just add that around half the staff were Japanese...always a good sign.  Our bill came out to around  $170 with tip, so kinda expensive.  Overpriced?  You decide.  Another reviewer has already said a similar meal would probably be 1/3 of the price in Tokyo.  Probably, but you are in SF, and if you want this type of authenticity, care, love, and dedication to the craft, you are going to pay.  Another note, street parking is the only option and can suck, but we found a spot with relative ease.
author: Pablo P.

description: A very good meal.  While all the dishes were somewhat unique, the favorites were the fried chicken and cheese (chicken katsu), the odd bits yakatori (chicken meatballs), and the cod.  The sake fleet was terrific.  Service was very accommodating, but at times could have been a bit more attentive.
author: Harold B.

description:
Food was worth two stars, service three and a half stars, overall value/experience sadly but one star.

This is a review solely based on the $75 a person prix fixe menu served on Valentine's Day. This was our first time there, and as big fans of izakayas, we had been looking forward to this meal. Upon entering the place we were pleased with the modernist/traditional decor and the fresh plants and flowers, unfortunately for us, the hostess took us to the backroom which is probably a converted storage room and now looks like an Eastern European cafeteria. This room was as far from romantic as you could get (there was even a sink) and we asked to be seated at the bar and so were then seated at the chef's table. What followed was nothing but small mediocre plates one after another seemingly intended not to satisfy the eater but to maximize profits while pretending to look like a chef's tasting menu.

First course consisted of one plate to share of miso paste with a couple of radishes and carrot pieces with their leafy stems in place. Meh. 

Second course was a tiny piece of rolled omelette, we each got our own. Nothing special, kind of hard to screw up an omelette after all.

Third course was  three small night smelts per person. Yawn.

Fourth course was a few bluefin tuna sashimi pieces with two oysters to share. The fish came out as if it hadn't been properly thawed.

Fifth course was a few pieces of thinly sliced steak and duck to share. The duck was very chewy and the two meats together made a puzzling combo.

Sixth course was a bowl of rice topped with steelhead roe. This was good, but hardly a dish whose flavor could be attributed to the chefs.

Dessert was advertised as a chocolate financier, but what we got were two chocolate madeleines. Absurd.

Total bill came out to be $270 with tip, as we had two sake flights as well. This was one of the most underwhelming meals I've ever had--not even one yakitori skewer--and it left us hungry and walking over to Mission Chinese to get the cod fried rice.

A place that chooses to gouge its customers on a special day as opposed to feeding them is not a restaurant, it's a criminal enterprise and should be avoided out of principles and at all cost.

Don't waste your money here and trek somewhere else.

EDIT: shortly after this review went up I received a private message from someone who works at Rintaro expressing sorrow I had had a bad experience. This shows that at least one person cares, and I'll be bumping up my star rating to two, in hope that this was just some Valentine's Day shenanigans. The restaurant business is very tough, but that's why it's important that new restaurants try even harder. There's a place for an upscale izakaya in the heart of the city and I hope they can rebound from this night and be it.
author: Stefan D.

description: 3.5 stars, really.  Place was quaint and cozy, but I must admit the food didn't wow me too much.  LOVED the eggs, veggie yakitori, and fried chicken wings, but everything else was nothing too memorable.  I would come back if reservations aren't hard to come by or if the wait time for drop-ins isn't too long...which doesn't seem to be the case for either.
author: Katie K.

description: According to Wikipedia--and confirmed by my own experience in Kyoto--an izakaya "is a type of informal Japanese gastropub." But while Rintaro may offer izakaya style food and drink, an informal gastropub it is not. The hassle of getting reservations is off-putting, to put it mildly. And the lack of grace on the part of the hostess when we arrived--without a reservation, but quite early, just after 6:00--was amazing, particularly since the entire counter was empty. (Or..maybe the counter seats were reserved too? She didn't say.)  Others may not feel the same way, but Rintaro is now off my list of go-to places....
author: m n.

description: What a sweet and cozy spot this is. We were warmly welcomed on a Monday night. The food, overall, was delicious and quickly delivered. Like many, we enjoyed the meatballs and the grilled thighs with onion. Another highlight was the sushi (mackerel, if I recall); our kids wanted to order several more of that clean and flavorful dish. The persimmon and duck salad and heirloom tomato sunumono  were also a hit. The only dish we really did not like was the mushroom rice, as the rice was undercooked and sadly flavorless. The green tea panna cotta dessert was divine. Our family now wants to move to Japan!
author: Hilary B.

description: Wow-what an amazing transformation from the old Chez Spencer location. My husband and I sat at the bar which gives you front row seats to the lively open kitchen. The food was delicious-don't miss out on the chicken meatballs and the amazing chicken and rice soup. The staff was great too. The only thing they can work on is their beer selection-they actually ran out of most by the end of the night but hey, they've only been open 11 days so I'll give them a pass. Definitely would go back!
author: Cynthia L.

description:
5 stars for ambiance.  Slightly sketchy-looking part of the neighborhood after dark, tiny little sign on a gate that opens up like a portal into a San Fransokyo courtyard.  The interior is gorgeous, lots of Japanese-crafted wood and nature/ikebana-esque touches.

4.5 stars for the food and service.  Classic Japanese izakaya food with a hipster-Bay Area approach/sourcing.  Would probably pass on the tuna tartare starter again, and the globs of dashi gelee completely overwhelmed the oysters on the half shell.  Salad was passable; the house made bergamot tofu is not for everyone, but very special for tofu fans.  

Moving on through the menu, the skewers were very well executed - gizzards just the right amount of chew, chicken "oysters" some of the most succulent and flavorful bits I've ever tasted, chicken ume and thighs as well as the king trumpets also pretty good.  Natto-don was okay, very mild and not super fermented, as natto goes.  Really enjoyed their take on ochazuke - the broth was so delicate and divine.

Our server was very nice but did have a little trouble answering some questions about the sake we ordered and distinguishing between the various chicken parts skewered on our table.

4 stars for value - high quality food, but you're definitely paying for the privilege.

All in all, Rintaro was a very enjoyable experience.  Would love to come back to give it another try and finish tasting the rest of the menu (deep fried whole sole, I am definitely looking at you).
author: Audrey L.

description:
{ OVERALL :: 4 stars }
came here for dinner last week, after a major craving for yakitori and a lack of desire to drive all the way to Berkeley and wait in line

{ FOOD :: 4.5 stars }
^ STAND OUT DISHES ^  :: liberty duck yakitori, steamed sole? (it wasn't fried), chicken thigh yakitori
^ DISHES TO SKIP NEXT TIME ^ :: oysters w/ponzu, fried fish w/tartar sauce - not bad, just not worth it (to us)

{ SERVICE :: 4 stars }
staff was helpful and friendly

{ ATMOSPHERE :: 3.5 stars }
* love the decor, very simple/clean/sleek
why such a low star rating your ask? 
answer: BAR STOOLS in front of the grill.  Those stools are TINY!! my butt was bigger than the stool area and I don't even have a big butt!!  What was worse than the tiny circumference of the seat was the lack of stability of the stool.  the seat itself was wobbly, so much so that I felt like I was going to fall off each time I had to move/turn in one direction or another (so the servers could place the food in front of us).  I tested other stools and they had the same issue, so there was no point in trading stools.  My husband and I were extremely uncomfortable during the duration of our meal.  so sad.. if it weren't for this issue, I probably would've given Rintaro 5 stars 

{ TIPS / MISC INFO }
* we did not receive complimentary peanuts, not sure if they don't do it anymore or if we're not VIP enough
* street parking available, but can be difficult to find
* reservations accepted for parties of 4 or more
* large private room in the back area, also used as overflow
* beer + wine only
* people come later here, if you go around 6:30 PM on saturday, you should have no problem being seated immediately.  after 8, you may have to wait  -- see what I did there? mc. rapper in da house. jk, i am so not.

happy eating!
author: Tina F.

description: Delicious food and nice inside. Unfortunatly, like many SF restaurants, it is crowded and you may nicely be asked to leave if you are talking for too long and people are waiting for a table. That portion of the street is sketchy; with a lot of homeless people sleeping on the sidewalk. But, again, the food is amazing so it is worse going. We got apetizers then a udon each. Everything was tasty.
author: P. C.

description: Superb. the karaage was crispy and flavorful. tamago and yakatori were also fantastic.
author: Sue P.

description: Sylvan and his cooking are amazing!  I have followed him for years and his Japanese bistro style reminds me of eating under the tracks in Tokyo- only in a nicer location. Perfect food, perfect service, a real stand out from the crowd. I would go here any day of the week- so comforting. Yum!!!
author: Abe W.

description: The skewers are great but the service is a little weird. No napkin, and the back room is rarely visited by waiters.
author: Benjamin S.

description: This place has taken food to another level. I was overwhelmed from the moment I entered till I walked out. I was greeted with a warm welcome, in Japanese, (as is everyone it seemed). The exterior, the terrace (check out their old Japanese wood stove with an integrated rice cooker); and the interior are all beautifully designed. The interior is designed with Japanese style timber frame construction, incredible joinery and clean lines. I ate here this summer and sat at the bar for a light meal. It happened to be when Bon Appetit was taking photos for their article on the top ten restaurants in the country. (Little did I know). Had a great view of all the action. Saw Sylvan cut two daikon radishes into two massive paper thin strips...very impressive skills. It was the most organized, we'll run kitchen I think I've ever seen. They have their system Down! Sylvan and his entire staff were very friendly and answered all my questions. I had the salmon head and a tuna sashimi dish that had been lightly torched before being sliced and served with some raw Japanese greens. Both were delicious and I'm looking forward to returning to enjoy a full meal soon!
author: Don R.

description: Lived up to prior great reviews and our expectations. Wonderful variety and quality of food, great service. Great service. A bit pricy but so is most great Japanese food, really fair for the quality. Probably our new favorite Japanese restaurant in bay area.
author: Richard S.

description:
The atmosphere is top notch. I truly felt as if I was in Japan, and I am from Japan. The interior design is simply stunning. I love how they added the arch pillars on the ceiling to produce a shrine-like space. 

The food and drink selection is meh... Disappointing... I still gave it 3 stars because the restaurant is relatively new, and they may improve the selection of food and drinks later. But as of now Jan. 2015, their menu was not impressive at all. The food was nothing spectacular, unfortunately.
author: D M.

description: Had dinner there 2 weeks ago. Eat at the bar. What a great place.  Good was great - so was the service.  The decor did not resemble a stereotypical Japanese restaurant which is why I liked it so much.  Fish was off the charts.  So was Udon.  Be back soon
author: Allan B.

description: This place is delicious!! I recently organized a birthday for my dad and Virginia, the office manager, helped with so many details- dietary restrictions for the prix fixe menu and beautiful printed personalized menus. All the food was stunning and the service impeccable. Thanks Tomoka!! Try the karage if they have it and always get the fresh tofu and panna cotta.
author: Kate F.

description:
I feel so lucky to have been able to check this place out before it became the new spot! It just opened and a friend raved so I decided to see for myself. 

I love the interior. Natural woods and really nice smells. It feels pure and honest and definitely hip. Very authentic Japanese style. The bathrooms are gorgeous, the hanging lanterns cast a beautiful shadow around the bathrooms. Everything is so simple but so perfect. 

The staff was very friendly, and it was refreshing for me (not knowing what I was getting into) to feel like this place spoke my values. They explained everything they served - where it came from (everything that we ate was Bay Area local and that was so neat to me), what all the different tastes are, how you eat it. For someone not so experienced in this style of food, it was really fun to learn more about this style of food and learn more about the restaurants values that seem pretty well aligned with mine. I appreciated them taking the time to share about each dish. 

For drinks - SOJU! This stuff is divine. Nectar of the gods. I'm not joking! I don't know why it isn't bottled and sold at Birite (there's an idea). I would buy this by the bottle if I could. Amazing drink (plum wine). If you've ever had "plum wine" before you might make a face while you're reading this. Believe me - this is not THAT plum wine. This is Rintaro's soju and it will totally knock your socks off. How do I even explain it. I can't, just please try it and smile for me. This place is my new go-to for drinks because the only drink I want anymore is Soju. I'm serious. 

For food - everyone was oooohing and aaahhhing over the chicken skewers. So tender and juicy. I've never had anything like it. The flavors were amazing. All the skewers came with spices and sauces. So delicious! 

I also loved the tamago. We ordered a million things including a fish fried whole! Everything was incredible and I have found my new spot. 

I would recommend asking what they recommend. I read up on the owner and he used to work at Chez Panisse. He knows what he is doing, so get their recommendation and some Soju and enjoy yoself.

P.S. Love the little lovely smelling wood planks with rolled wet cloth for wiping your hands. So sweet. 

Thank you Rintaro!!
author: Danielle G.

description:
The service is good but the setting is too cold. The  menu offers limited selections.
And the food is far from what the Chronicle Food critics declares "great".  Getting a booth is tough unless you have three. Otherwise, you sit at the counter with an lousy chair. The beer menu is awful.
Totally disappointed.
author: Alex W.

description: Everything was artfully plated and delicious. I want to go back already. Omakase is the way to go if you can swing it. Can't wait to return. Thanks, Rintaro!
author: Megan M.

description:
Wonderful food and concept but one star off because of the loud music and less than stellar way to be greeted and taken to a table. And since there is so much tofu and soy sauce involved, I wish they would say that they are using organic sources for that.

Service/Atmosphere: We had a reservation and arrived early to a 20% filled front room but were put in the dark back room, which was cold, had  strange smells and even louder bad music. We asked to be reseated. That took a long time, even though there were many open places available throughout our dinner. So, not very well run in terms of customer comfort.  

The architecture/woodwork is stunning and the open kitchen is nice. Looks like they are going for a urban hipster experience which has limited appeal and should not mean loud Japanese bar music. Maybe we were there at a poorly managed time.

Food: The food was very well prepared and nicely presented. We loved both the soft and fried tofu dishes and yakitori. The chicken wings were suberb if a bit salty, but the lemon slices helped that. We did not like the mushy shumai and it seemed out of place on the menu of Japanese food. The chicken tenders were too spicy but overall the dishes we ate were excellent. Some of the nice hand made dishes were chipped already, and the (sobacha) buckwheat tea (why is that not on the menu?) was delicious but not as nice to drink from a chipped cup.

Menu: I would have liked to know that the tofu was made with organic soybeans and that the soy sauce was organic. Much of soy is now genetically modified and should be avoided. Since Rintaro makes the effort to source local food and name it on the menu, it should also give customers that information. And I would expect a choice of shoyu sauce, such as tamari, a wheat free option. 

Over all the potential for greatness is there but I agree with the reviews that it still is a work in progress.
author: Violet R.

description: This is one of the best restaurants in town.  The chicken Yakitori as well as  the chicken and Cheese Katsu are a must.  The wings are absolutely delicious.  This place has great service, great restaurant ambiance and of course...delicious food.  You will not be disappointed if you come here.
author: Eddie M.

description: Great new izakaya restaurant located right next to Nihon Whiskey Lounge.  I'd definitely recommend my friends to come here.  Menu is small so we almost tried everythingo n the menu!  We had their chicken karage and it comes out SO amazing that we got another plate.  All the dishes are quite small portioned with the exception of their whole deep fried fish (watch out for tiny bones). Their pork belly is also a MUST GET.  It literally melted in the mouth.  They also have different types of croquettes that were all very good.  If it is up to me, I would order less of the yakitori and go with more of the other hot items on their menu.  Knocked out one star for some of the staff seeming confused on what yakitori grilled items were coming out of the kitchen and onto our table.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Rintaro is my favorite Japanese restaurant outside of Tokyo. Their menu is innovative, beautifully presented, flavorful and very affordably priced.  I loved the charcoal gilled chicken meatball skewers, yozu tofu, and the chizu tori katsu (new dish to me which was amazing - friend chicken breast with melted cheese katsu inside).  Rintaro also has a brief but well chosen selection of Japanese beer, wine and shochu.  The staff seem to really care about providing doting top notch service.  Feels almost like an undiscovered neighborhood hangout.  We even found parking right across the street (can't guarantee that for everyone in the future though...:)
author: Mighty M.

description: So wonderfully accommodating of my gluten intolerance, even though we were a large table.  I really appreciated it and the best part of all was that the food was delicious!!!! I would definitely go again, so amazing, chicken wings fried to perfection, rice porridge delicious, chicken skewers grrrrrrrrreat!, green tea panna cotta was to die for!!!! fantastic!!!
author: I Love S.

description: My awesome boyfriend took us here to celebrate this year's Valentine's Day. We loved the speakeasy style and ambiance. Service was excellent and the sake selection interesting. We tried the Chef's special, so didn't really get a feel for the depth of the menu. Hence, the 3-stars. I thought the Chef's special fell short in term of flavors and variety. It seemed like it was pulled together last minute. I do remember enjoying the tuna sashimi served with baby oysters and the slices of beef and duck. The tea was tasty too. I was hoping to find a second "Nihon Lounge" spot that is my go to in this area, but unfortunately I don't think Rintaro made the cut for me.
author: Jessica V.

description: Great spot !! truly authentic with a hip atmosphere !!!!
author: Michael B.

description: The silken tofu, the chicken liver and duck breast yakitori, the hand rolled udon in broth, the mochi ice cream dessert were all great. Service was attentive without being intrusive. The music was too loud, but I guess I'm too old. In sum: authentic, delicious, and worth coming back.
author: Daniel T.

description:
had a great time, and a great meal... 
was seated in a comfy cozy booth with a great vantage of the night.
have been coming back frequently and it's really hitting it's stride.

great atmosphere and people. unlike any other place in SF...
california meets tokyo in both food and the vibe.

looking forward to seeing how the menu progresses throughout each season...
author: Crumbs C.

description:
I have been dying to eat here ever since we stumbled inside for dessert and drinks a few months ago. The first moment I walked through, I loved the ambiance and immediately wanted to book the place for a party. 

Unfortunately, the meal was expensive and extremely disappointing. Liholiho deserves to be one of the top 50 new restaurants. Rintaro does not. There are so many better izakayas in the Bay Area serving tastier yakitori and small dishes. We sampled a lot for two people and nothing stood out (not even the desserts this time). Sadness!!! I'd say it's more of a 3 star but putting 2 to balance out all the flawed reviews. Please season your food better!!! Plus, the waitress forgot to bring us our tea but we didn't bother asking for it again. 

Early Girl Tomato Sunomono: I regret ordering this dish. Not worth it. 
Liberty Duck Salad: The duck was good and overall the dish had nice flavor combo, but it also cost a lot. 
Chicken Breast w/ Ume Yakitori: SUPER BLAND!!! 
King Trumpet Mushrooms: tasty but tiny. 
House Grilled Fish Cake: nice grill on the fish cake. 
Karaage/Chicken Wings: not bad but reminded me of SO's chicken. For $9, I could get three times the portion elsewhere. 
Riverdog Chicken Katsu w/ Cowgirl Creamery Cheese: probably one the better dishes. Perfect fry on the chicken. 
Teuchi Udon w/ Hot Spring Egg: presentation very nice, taste was bland. Udon had a nice texture because they make it in house. broth could have been water and I wouldn't know the difference.
Mushroom Clay Pot: overall very flavorless!!! $15 for rice and mushrooms. :(
Apple Tart: maybe I just don't like tarts. This one was very dry and not very tasty.
Ginger Ice Cream: overall tasty but not very special

I suspect the hype will die down soon...
author: Q C.

description:
just got a message from someone at the restaurant that said it was not cool that I post about them not calling us to cancel the reservations I had made the night I was supposed to take a friend for his b-day.  the rain had stopped n the power was not out n u couldn't make a phone call
well now zero stars n f-u for trying to tell me off 
just shows u people do not appreciate your neighbors n ur clientele 
hope u lose it all
author: patrick d.

description: Excellent.  Authentic.  Much love and care put into the food, decor ... into the entire experience.
author: Brett C.

description: Rintaro is especially amazing. No perfect words to describe. Every dish is made with lots of love and attentions. Sublime. Wish I could eat there every night.
author: S H.

description: I love izakayas so when my friend suggested this place, I was looking forward to it.  We got reservations for 9:30pm.  The decor is nice, lots of light wood everywhere with a comfortable feel. Unfortunately we were told we would have to wait, so we sat at the bar.  After 20 minutes the bartender had not even acknowledged us and we were still waiting.  Finally we were seated and offered a mini beer for the delay.  The menu seems a bit limited, compared to other izakayas I've been to.  Having just moved from LA, that is my comparison point  (and LA has some amazing spots).  I will say most of the dishes we got were executed well and very tasty (minus the green beans, which were bland).  The yosedofu was silky and light.  The karaage was some of the best I've tasted, perfectly crispy.  Our server did forget one of our yakitori orders and with the limited selection to begin with, that was a bummer.  The ones we did try were delicious, especially the skin. Our waitress also brought out the wrong dessert, the panna cotta, but we tried it and enjoyed the nutty, not too sweet sauce. Hopefully it was just an off night for inaccurate hearing on the waitress' part and if I could, this night would be more like 3 1/2 stars. But overall, I liked the place and hope they continue to expand the menu.
author: Heidi D.

description: We had dinner at Rinatro because of the review in Bon Apetit.  The food was tasty, but hard to apprecaite because the music was so loud.  We asked our wait person to turn down the musci 4 times. -- no results.  There is a serious disconnect between the ambiance that the chef is trying to create with his cooking and the loudness of the music.  Delicate Japnese flavora do not pair well with thumping music.  Will not go back. D. Deamer
author: ditty D.

description:
Okay, let me first say that maybe my expectations were a tad too high given this restaurant just received the award of one of the 10 best restaurants in America from Bon Appetite.  Please, tell me there was a mistake!  My dining companion kept saying that it wasn't the restaurants fault. Bon Appetite gave them this honor, they didn't claim it. But it was so far away from even the most mediocre restaurant in America that words can not describe what we had. 
Started with "nasty" green beans. Totally flavorless concoction with a walnut cream sauce.  Then a tuna "sashimi" dish which was ok but could have gotten a better version at any one of my neighborhood restaurants. They were out of most of their yakitori dishes except for the trumpet mushrooms, meh nothing special. Then came the fried sole which was the best dish of the evening but not even close to what was expected. The last two dishes we ordered they told us were sold out as they were about to be delivered so we ended with the hot udon dish. Again meh, nothing to write home about. 
Bon Appetite has lost all credibility with me. The restaurant never claiming to be the best remains an ok neighborhood restaurant but certainly NOT one of the 10 best.
author: Lisa S.

description: This is the nicest looking restaurant I've ever been to. It's worth going there just to see it. The grilled duck was amazing as was the Sashimi. I will be back many times .
author: Andre K.

description:
great japanese food and simple rustic chic atmosphere.
wish they had a soup on the menu though.
author: eric s.

description: We ate here this evening. It was okay but not great. And, noisy.  The hirami was hidden beneath a mound of very tough arugula salad and it didn't make sense. The food came out very quickly and it all seemed rushed. I felt sorry for the wait staff because they were hurrying around as though they were working in a very busy diner.
author: Rachele F.

description:
delicious food. 

seems like good date spot or pre-game spot for chill friends.

downstairs tables hard to eat at.  really more for drinking and lounging.  upstairs was quite strict about having reservation. but looked cozy and shiek.

all in all will def go back
author: Lauren R.

description: Went here on a Tuesday night.  Fantastic meal, service, ambiance.  Food was flavorful, served at the right temperature and just beautiful presentation.  I'd suggest sampling a bit from each section of the menu.  We had tofu, katsu, gyoza, multiple skewers, the rice soup.  Will recommend to friends to go here and come back again soon
author: Josh R.

description: Decor and general vibe is cool but the food was average at best and the service was slow and inattentive. Overall, a very disappointing dinner.
author: James S.

description: Rintaro is a true gem, everything is exquisite an authentic. The food was as much art as sustenance, the house made plum wine is not to be missed. Peanuts boiled in sweet soy were super yummy and a fun appetizer that even the kids loved. My party ordered many items an I got to try a bit of each, they all blew my mind, fresh, simple and satisfying. Don't expect bento boxes and the run of the mill offerings here. I also like that Rintaro was easy on my budget as well, bonus! As a side note, some of the friends I was with were carpenters and they pointed out the outstanding real Japanese craftsmanship that went into every detail of this place. The bar is made out of a solid slab of Port Orford Cedar which I guess is a pretty big deal and collected by wood enthusiasts the world over. What I liked about the wood is that it smelled incredible! Sniff the bar if you get a chance even if people look at you funny. But if there are too many people at the bar you can also huff the tiny wood plank that your hot towel comes on.
author: Jade W.

description: The maguro tartar, grilled trout, chicken (stuffed with cheese, breaded and fried), and udon were favorites of everyone in our party. The Japanese among us thought the sunomono needed a touch more acidity, but it was very refreshing. The wait staff was exceptionally friendly and took good care of us, though there seemed to be some communication issues between them (example: one member of our party ordered sake after the other drinks had been served. After a considerable wait, he asked one of the staff about it. A little later, another staff member walked by with the sake, went several tables down the aisle, and was obviously confused about where the drink should go. My friend had to wave (pretty enthusiastically) several times to finally get the person's attention and get his drink. As we were finishing, another waitperson tried to serve us another bowl of udon that belonged to a different table. That aside, everyone was very pleasant and helpful, the decor was great, the food delicious and healthy and we had a great time.
author: Carla K.

description: almost perfect;  beautiful traditional Japanese design inside, very good simple food; however the loud techno music doesn't fit the decor and makes the atmosphere uncomfortable; change the music and i would definitely return
author: Ted M.
